fields.headline: The Go-Betweens reincarnated
fields.standfirst:
The Go-Betweens
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
**
fields.trailText:
The Go-Betweens
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
**
fields.body:
It seems a thousand years ago that The Go-Betweens were banging out albums such as Send Me A Lullaby and Before Hollywood, gradually establishing themselves as a presence in Indieland UK. The band's roots go back to 1977, when Robert Forster and Grant McLennan were arts students at the University of Queensland in Brisbane. For fans of whimsical guitar tunes with concealed fangs, the six albums they made before imploding in 1989 linger on as peerless specimens of the genre.

Their current reincarnation follows a decade in which the duo pursued solo careers, and arrives on the heels of a reunion album, The Friends of Rachel Worth.

The Go-Betweens, 2000-style, serve up a familiar menu, though perhaps with a dash more of the relaxed insouciance that 20-odd years of experience bring.

The tall, languid Forster took the stage in a rust-coloured striped suit, and could easily pass for a somewhat louche snake-oil salesman in a travelling carnival. McLennan wore jeans and a sweat-shirt, grinning amiably as he thrashed chords from his guitar. The duo looked about as tense as a pair of cats snoozing in a hammock.

Unfortunately, while the The Go-Betweens had pulled in a rowdy cross-section of London's Antipodean subculture, I could not share their enthusiasm. The fact that they have built such a lengthy career on so limited a palette of melodic devices is a minor marvel in itself, while their long litany of songs based around the same featureless strumming rhythm gradually builds up an excruciating nails-down-a-blackboard effect.

There were a few pleasant pieces, though. Streets of Your Town is a classic specimen of Go-Betweenism, splicing a lyric about wife-battering to an agreeable country-pop tune, while it was almost possible to glimpse what it was about Spring Rain that once very nearly made it a hit single. Best of the lot was Forster's thespian-like treatment of his solo piece, Danger in the Past - or "P-a-a-a-h-h-hst", as he pronounces it - delivered as if he had been studying videos of Noël Coward in Las Vegas.

 At Manchester University (0161-275 2959) tonight.

fields.headline: Los Amigos Invisibles
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
**
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
**
fields.body:
Although Venezuela has never heard anything like Los Amigos Invisibles before, the rest of the world heard it ad infinitum in the 70s. It is true that the Amigos' new album, Arepa 3000: A Venezuelan Journey Into Space, has some sleek techno flourishes and a smattering of acid-funk-jungle flashbacks. But when the combo hit the stage in the flesh, suddenly we are on a nightmare ride back to the era of furry dice, Afros and satin loons.

Which only goes to show that there is a fine line between cutting-edge hip and tragically uncool.

It is true that at various times the Venezuelan sextet threatened to fulfil all that steamy southern-hemisphere promise. A piece like Cuchi-Cuchi is a whomping party-down groove embellished with Mexican wave vocals and plasticky Mike Flowers keyboards.

Caliente, meanwhile, finds the combo stretching out into a streamlined Latin lope with Tito Puente percussion and pointillist rhythm guitar stabs, courtesy of Jose Luis Pardo, possibly a thousandth-remove relation of Carlos Santana. But 75% of the time the Amigos lapse hopelessly into dog-eared disco drivel, banging out brain-dead grooves.

Their tunes are like ghosts of these-you-have-loved - a slice of Village People here, a quote from Kool & The Gang there, an echo of the O-Jays floating in from stage right.

The Amigos seem pretty clueless about how to pace their set, too. Instead of kicking off with something titillatingly and exotically Latino, they introduced themselves with a couple of disco carthorses that would have put James Last into a coma.

If it was supposed to make Juan and Juanita Punter feel that irresistible urge to start spinning each other ecstatically across the floor, a return trip to the drawing board is urgently required. Maybe they will get less boring as they get older.

fields.headline: Faust breathe life into Nosferatu
fields.standfirst:
Faust/ Nosferatu
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Faust/ Nosferatu
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
It was a marriage made in heaven (or perhaps hell): the Krautrock legends Faust and FW Murnau's classic silent horror movie Nosferatu, made in 1921. Drawing on music from their 1997 album, Faust Wakes Nosferatu, which was itself inspired by the film, Faust accompanied a screening of the movie with an enthralling, apocalyptic river of sound.

The audience was more Faustian than silver-screen. Indeed, a number of Nosferatu purists soon abandoned their seats in horror. Even Faust's fans seemed uncertain of what to expect from a band that uses anything from wind machines to paint-daubed nudity in live performances. The stage set-up directly under the screen included a thunder sheet and brazier alongside drums and guitars, all draped in spider's webs.

The band took to the stage casually and began playing some 10 minutes before the film began. Though the audience initially focused more on Faust than on the film, the movie's extraordinary, powerful imagery soon took hold. Max Schreck's rat-like Nosferatu is one of cinema's most powerful icons, rising flat-packed from his coffin, looming in distorted, Gothic doorways, but Faust matched his intensity.

In an unbroken two-hour performance, they delivered an uncompromising, powerful sonic attack that rose and fell, ebbed and pulsed to evoke in heady, abstract music the power of Murnau's primal, poetic imagery.

The piece of music perfectly matched Murnau's primitive expressionism. The director absorbed Max Rheinhardt's expressionist ideas early on in his career, and Nosferatu achieves its haunting effects through classic distortions of lighting, staging, and brilliant, imagistic editing.

Tracking the film's dream-like, nightmarish qualities, Faust's uncompromising battery of sound was pure 1970s kosmische freakout heaven, yet in a resolutely contemporary performance. Faust are no museum piece or retro act, and Nosferatu is as timeless as anything in cinema history.

As the band felt their way instinctively through the film with a choreographed progression of dirty electronics, flute, cello, distorted guitars, percussion and the kind of arc-welding equipment you can find at any tool hire shop, the sparks literally flew.

The music and film reached a kind of mutual climax as Nosferatu rose up at the heroine's bedroom window in the last reel, awaiting her submission to his spell. It was a wonderful moment.

fields.headline: Bournemouth's incredible string band
fields.standfirst:
Bournemouth Symphony/ Daniel
Wessex Hall, Poole
***
fields.trailText:
Bournemouth Symphony/ Daniel
Wessex Hall, Poole
***
fields.body:
The Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra is between principal conductors: Yakov Kreizberg left at the end of last season, and his successor has yet to be announced. The current programme is being shared between guests, though Kreizberg and his predecessor, Andrew Litton, are returning to work with the orchestra. On Wednesday it was the turn of Paul Daniel, who is no stranger to the BSO, having made a number of recordings with the band.

The programme was a solid, old-fashioned one. The BSO is constrained in what it plays by the need to keep its conservative constituency in Poole happy and by its mission to take orchestral concerts to parts of the southwest that others do not reach. So Wagner's Siegfried Idyll, Saint-Saëns's First Cello Concerto and Berlioz's Fantastic Symphony it was, in the decidely unflattering acoustic of Poole's Wessex Hall.

Perhaps it was the tendency of the auditorium to add an unpleasant brassiness to anything played above forte that persuaded Daniel to use the entire string section for the Wagner; it is, after all, a piece that sounds well with a chamber orchestra, but the extra strings do provide a plusher cushion for the wind solos, allowing more latitude in what he could do dynamically, and in shaping the long musical paragraphs.

The accompaniment for the concerto was scaled down a bit, allowing Paul Watkins's nimble and fluent account of the solo part to emerge without the need for extra force, and Watkins consistently made good use of it.

The Fantastic Symphony was more problematic. Daniel had plenty of ideas about the piece - he was very careful with detail and took every opportunity to give the music a heightened sense of drama; the theatrical dimension of the score, and its debt to Weber, were unmistakable.

But the BSO were not really up to delivering their conductor's vision - it is rare nowdays to find a British orchestra in which the string section is more impressive than the wind, but that seems to be the current condition here. There were too many slips and uncertainties in some crucial solos: someone to restore their confidence cannot arrive too soon.

 This concert is repeated at the Hexagon, Reading, tonight. Box office: 0118-960 6060.

fields.headline: Fallen Angels
fields.standfirst:
Apollo Shaftesbury, London
***
fields.trailText:
Apollo Shaftesbury, London
***
fields.body:
In 1925 Noel Coward's Fallen Angels inspired the public to one of its periodic fits of morality. Bishops and self-appointed censors campaigned against it and the Daily described its twin heroines as "suburban sluts". Now it seems a harmless divertissement that survives largely as a vehicle for its performers.

What caused the furore? Clearly the fact that two married women, living a life of passionless boredom, whip themselves into a state of sexual excitement over the return of a former lover. In the play's celebrated central act they get riotously tipsy as they await the nocturnal arrival of the Gallic Romeo. But, having stoked up the sexual fires, Coward banks them down again in the overly symmetrical final act as each woman falsely believes the other has had a secret assignation with the Gallic intruder.

Coward makes some sharp points about male hypocrisy: in particular, the middle-class Englishman's belief that wild oats are things that only chaps may sow. But it's a one-joke play that teases out its central idea to the point of nervous exhaus tion. Coward clearly recognised the problem by beefing up the text in 1958 to give extra prominence to an all-purpose maid, a kind of beskirted Jeeves who exudes an alarming omniscience.

But it is the famous drunk scene that people come to see and, in Michael Rudman's production, it is given a frenzy by Felicity Kendal and Frances de la Tour. Kendal is all disintegrating demureness as she tumbles over sofas and strangles herself in telephone cords; de la Tour is more like an inebriated camel as she lopes unsteadily about the stage and peers mournfully at the bottom of empty glasses. Rudman's best innovation is to hint at a suppressed lesbianism as the two dance clingingly together and pass a cigarette from one mouth to another. But the scene would be funnier still if it were less full of expertly choreographed business.

Good as they are, the stars are overshadowed by Tilly Tremayne as the sharp-featured maid who knows about everything from golf to tropical medicine and caps her employers' every remark. Stephen Greif wittily plays the French lover as an ambulatory shrug and Eric Carte, angry in plus fours, wonderfully embodies husbandly outrage. The stars do their thing; but it is the supporting actors who, by never overstepping the modesty of nature, justify this revival of Coward's attenuated farce.

 Until March 2001. Box office: 020-7494 5070.

fields.headline: Sightsonic
fields.standfirst:
Various venues, York
****
fields.trailText:
Various venues, York
****
fields.body:
You can't even sit at home these days without dealing with something "digital": a toaster, a camera, a television... It can't be long before the advent of digital pyjamas. In the arts, however, "digital" should mean a certain breed of work - modern and, hopefully, creatively exploiting new technology.

Sightsonic, York's festival of digital arts, occasionally stretched that definition: Elephant Talk used commonplace technology in quite a conventional way; there was an element of the "Because we can" to some of the abstract projections that accompanied the Sonic Arts Network's late-night Diffusion gig.

But at its heart Sightsonic had a courageous mix of works, from Viennese record label Mego's sonic battering - laptop DJs surfing the line between noise and music - to short films, drop-in have-a-go sessions and children giving concerts using new technology.

Most innovatively, some of the works were responsive to their surroundings. Ambrose Field's Frontier X had an intriguing take on "background" music. Set up in the bar of the City Screen, it used sensors similar to those of an alarm system to read the movement and number of people in the room. Behind the scenes, a computer was knitting together sounds from a huge bank of possible sounds or ambiences. It was rarely intrusive, but always present: one minute jungle noises, then those of an airport; the gentle sound of lapping water; a clap of thunder.

Over at the City Art Gallery, Chaotic Constructions (by Peter Fluck and Tony Myatt) was also celebrating unpredictability. A rotating wall-mounted sculpture of interconnected lines, curves and coloured shapes (like elements from a Kandinsky painting orbiting each other) is tracked by a video camera, and the movement of certain points is again used to influence music that a computer is creating to its own complex set of rules. A brief glance will yield little satisfaction, but the longer you look and listen the harder it is to walk away. It will never, ever repeat itself. Hopefully this festival will.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/ Schiff
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Not so long ago, performances of Bach's Passions using authentic forces were unusual. Now they are the rule rather than the exception - so much so that a professional performance of the St Matthew Passion on modern instruments, such as this one by the Philharmonia, is almost an event in itself.

This was the penultimate concert of the Bach series presided over by Andras Schiff, and his second as conductor rather than keyboard soloist. Though his forces were unfashionably modern, their style of performance nodded towards "authentic" practices, with light bow strokes and sparing use of vibrato from the strings.

Schiff kept the tempos generally brisk, but at times the music could still be stolid, the phrasing directionless. For all his efforts - and his movements were expansive to the point of flamboyance - something was not quite getting across, and a handful of ragged entries from both chorus and orchestra suggested that he doesn't yet have the authority as a conductor that he has as pianist.

The high points of the evening all stemmed from the soloists. As the Evangelist, the German tenor Peter Schreier sang the whole work (more than three hours long) without a score, assuming the role of storyteller as if taking the audience into his confidence. Unsurprisingly for a singer who made his stage debut more than 40 years ago, Schreier can no longer sing the role as beautifully as he once did, but his compelling, often pictorial, delivery more than made up for one or two moments of struggle. There was no doubting the bitterness of the gall given to Jesus on the cross, or the mocking sound of the cockerel as it crowed after Peter's denial.

Robert Holl, who has been singing Hans Sachs at Bayreuth for the past few summers, brought power to the role of Jesus with his substantial bass. This role is often sung rather politely, but there was nothing meek in Holl's interpretation.

The bass arias sung by Thomas Quasthoff, mellifluous and superbly direct, were another of the evening's highlights, and the velvet-toned mezzo Monica Groop got better and better as the performance went on.

But even though Schiff dedicated the concert to the legendary Otto Klemperer, who made several Bach recordings with this orchestra, on this occasion it was the soloists rather than the conductor who made the performance memorable.

fields.headline: RLPO/ Bergamin
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.body:
This night revolved around a twin debut that should never have happened: conductor Peter Bergamin and violinist Jack Liebeck were filling in for husband-and-wife team David Shallon and Tabea Zimmermann, after Shallon's sudden death. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, the results were mixed.

Liebeck, who began performing at the age of 11 and is currently studying at the Royal Academy of Music, seems well on his way to an impressive solo career.

It may be that he found the circumstances of his sudden debut unsettling, or that he was slightly underprepared. His account of Mendelssohn's concerto got off to a shaky start, with some intonation problems and gabbled passages. By the time he reached the first movement cadenza he began to sound more settled; but his composure seemed to falter again with the start of the second movement, which skipped along at a comfortable allegretto rather than andante. A rather fast, nervy vibrato throughout gave the first two movements an agitated and breathless quality that constrained their breadth and sweep.

Technically assured as many aspects of Liebeck's performance were, his uniformity of tone, lack of colour and reluctance to explore the lyrical side of this work marred his performance. Dialogue between soloist and orchestra became impossible as he rushed his way through the finale; Bergamin, currently artistic director of the Vienna Taschenoper, and the RLPO kept pace with their wayward soloist admirably. However, the result was a dry, almost clipped account of a work sadly stripped of warmth and passion.

If the RLPO had little chance to shine in the Mendelssohn, Bergamin's intelligent, imaginative shaping of Rachmaninov's Second Symphony made up for it. The ultra-romantic slow movement drew some especially fine playing from the wind section, who shone throughout the concert, and it was clear that the rapport between conductor and orchestra was a happy one; the RLPO were on stunning form.
fields.bodyText: This night revolved around a twin debut that should never have happened: conductor Peter Bergamin and violinist Jack Liebeck were filling in for husband-and-wife team David Shallon and Tabea Zimmermann, after Shallon's sudden death. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, the results were mixed. Liebeck, who began performing at the age of 11 and is currently studying at the Royal Academy of Music, seems well on his way to an impressive solo career. It may be that he found the circumstances of his sudden debut unsettling, or that he was slightly underprepared. His account of Mendelssohn's concerto got off to a shaky start, with some intonation problems and gabbled passages. By the time he reached the first movement cadenza he began to sound more settled; but his composure seemed to falter again with the start of the second movement, which skipped along at a comfortable allegretto rather than andante. A rather fast, nervy vibrato throughout gave the first two movements an agitated and breathless quality that constrained their breadth and sweep. Technically assured as many aspects of Liebeck's performance were, his uniformity of tone, lack of colour and reluctance to explore the lyrical side of this work marred his performance. Dialogue between soloist and orchestra became impossible as he rushed his way through the finale; Bergamin, currently artistic director of the Vienna Taschenoper, and the RLPO kept pace with their wayward soloist admirably. However, the result was a dry, almost clipped account of a work sadly stripped of warmth and passion. The ultra-romantic slow movement drew some especially fine playing from the wind section, who shone throughout the concert, and it was clear that the rapport between conductor and orchestra was a happy one; the RLPO were on stunning form.

fields.headline: Kelly Joe Phelps
fields.standfirst:
Renfrew Ferry, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Renfrew Ferry, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
With the backcloth blocking out a choppy, gale-lashed Clyde, Kelly Joe Phelps pads on to the Renfrew Ferry stage without a hint of fanfare and sits down to commune with his 12-string guitar. It is as if the substantial crowd is not even there, and he looks as if he is about to rehearse on a ghostly, displaced Mississippi riverboat. Yet the intricate waterfall of notes that suddenly pours from his blurring fingers indicate that we are in the presence of a guitar maestro in the making.

Now 37, Phelps came late to the blues, having spent more than a decade playing jazz in Washington, figuring out the chordal structures and tensions of Charlie Parker and Ornette Coleman.

About seven years ago he heard Mississippi Fred McDowell, an epiphany that left him standing at a crossroads between northern freeform jazz and Deep South blues. He went with the blues.

This was a solo performance devoid of frills. Yet it was filled with a fusillade of tingling notes. The songs are founded on the classic blues possess a contemporary but alienated edge. Phelps's vocals move from a rough, slurring rasp to a high falsetto reminiscent of early John Martyn, but it is his guitar-playing that raises him above the crowd.

The only action on stage occurs when Phelps exchanges his 12-string for a six-string lap-top slide guitar for Wandering Far Away, a stepping blues number with a beautiful light touch from his latest album, Shine Eyed Mister Zen. He follows on with an emotional drop-kick into his first ever composition, Black Crow, in which a lengthy talking blues floats along on percussive scrapes and some terrifying slide guitar breaks.

Never taking the easy route into foot-tapping standards, Phelps carried a rapt audience into a vortex of weaving, off-beat blues. With a slight smile and a single wave, the quietest guitar alchemist around was gone. The Beck of the blues.

 At the Neptune Theatre, Liverpool (0151-709 7844), tomorrow, then touring around the UK.

webTitle: Thumb your nose at financial fraud

fields.headline: Thumb your nose at financial fraud
fields.trailText: Leaving a thumbprint on your cheques and credit card receipts is the easiest and cheapest way of preventing financial fraud, says the company behind the Thumbprint Signature Program, a new anti-fraud technique.
fields.body:
Leaving a thumbprint on your cheques and credit card receipts is the easiest and cheapest way of preventing financial fraud, says the company behind the Thumbprint Signature Program, a new anti-fraud technique.

According to Thumbsup Security, shoppers would be asked to leave a thumbprint on their financial receipts and documents using a special invisible ink. If a card was stolen and used fraudulently, the customer would be able to prove they did not make the purchase as prints on till receipts would not match theirs. The police would then have the option of pursuing the culprit using their fingerprint.

The company claims the technique would protect consumers from the moment their cards are lost or sold, saving them, the police and the courts upwards of £400m a year.

Retailers would not have to verify the shopper's thumbprint. Instead, the system would work primarily as a deterrent, stopping thieves going into shops which use it. However, to be effective, it needs to be used in as many retail outlets as possible.

The technique could also be used for internet and mail order shopping. James Jaimeson of Thumbs up Security said: "With mail order shopping, most of the theft occurs around the time of delivery. If the van driver took a thumbprint when the goods were delivered, this could be stopped. In the same way it could prevent fraud involving hire purchases and NHS prescriptions."

The technique is being tested in Kent's Bluewater shopping centre where police say it has been very effective. Shop owners say they have had no reports of theft or fraud since introducing it during the summer and a spokesperson for Kent police said it has had enquiries from police forces throughout the country.

In the US, where the technique is more widespread, Thumbs up Security claims that 99% of shoppers have no objection to leaving their prints and retailers have seen a 75% drop in fraud.

The company hopes to convince banks to put the program logo on their credit and debit cards, as well as cheques; and to get retailers to display the logo in their shop windows and buy the ink pads.

The thumb print system is understood to be dramatically cheaper to use than the electronic signatures and microchip solutions currently being promoted by the banks and their clearing houses. Thumbs up Security's invisible ink pads only cost around £10 each and, apart from buying the pad, all retailers need to do is advertise the fact that they are using the system.

webTitle: Why Hodgson is the wrong man for England

fields.headline: Why Hodgson is the wrong man for England
fields.trailText: With Wenger and Eriksson seeming increasinly less likely to take the England job, Roy Hodgson is becoming a favourite - and that concerns me
fields.body:
With Arsène Wenger out of the running and Sven Goran Eriksson making noises about staying at Lazio, the popular perception seems to be that Roy Hodgson is favourite for the England job. I have to say that concerns me.

I wouldn't argue that Roy's record with Switzerland was commendable. He took them first to the 1994 World Cup and then to Euro 96. But in terms of profile and expectancy, what he dealt with there was not even close to the pressure that would be heaped on him with England. Much of his coaching has been like that.

Although he had a brief spell at Internazionale, where he was working under the cosh, the first real chance he had to manage here - with Blackburn Rovers - could hardly be described as an overwhelming success. If the same run had happened at Manchester United or Arsenal there would have been far more of a to-do made of it.

Roy took over a club with a strong base, had a good start and then went downhill so rapidly that he was sacked after 18 months with Blackburn bottom of the Premiership. When things started to go against him he did not seem able to put his finger on the pulse and stop the rot, even with plenty of money from Jack Walker.

In fact when you look at some of his purchases, such as splashing out £7.25m on Kevin Davies and £4.25m on Nathan Blake, you wonder about his record in terms of selection. And I believe the England job is mainly about selection and strategy.

Roy is highly regarded as a coach and although the England job encompasses an amount of coaching, you are not going to improve the players' technique that much in the few days you have got them. What you've got to do is make sure you have a group of players who can fit into the pattern you lay down.

When you're with a team like Switzerland you haven't got that big a pool to choose from, so the side more or less looks after itself. In England he would have a greater choice and that can create its own problems.

Two lads might be performing as well as each other for their clubs and you have got to know who's going to fit better into the international sphere, particularly with the spotlight England's players are put under.

I don't want to decry Roy because he has worked very hard to get where he is but we are talking about the England national job here. Someone who has been as successful as him in Switzerland is Christian Gross, but would anybody be touting him as Kevin Keegan's successor?

If the FA wants a man with World Cup coaching experience who's possibly available then there's someone up in Newcastle with a better pedigree than Roy Hodgson and that's Jackie Charlton. And he's won a World Cup winner's medal to boot.

I know a poll in the Sun this week showed 52% support for Roy Hodgson, 31% for Wenger and 17% for Eriksson but that was a bit false. What people were saying was that they wanted an Englishman rather than a foreigner. If they had put Roy up with Terry Venables and Bobby Robson he may not have got a vote.

I'm not opposed to bringing someone in from abroad and believe Eriksson has the right mentality and knowledge for the job. But if I were to choose an Englishman I would sooner go for Peter Reid, John Gregory or in particular Bryan Robson now that Venables has apparently been ruled out.

I certainly don't like what the FA has done in appointing Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren. I rate Steve highly and think Peter has the potential to become a top coach, but he's only done a couple of months as a Premiership manager. It's miles too early and I think the pair should be concentrating on their clubs.

In any case it's not right to put Peter in that position. If we go to Italy next month and take a spanking, does that set him back four or five years in people's eyes?

I know he had a fine record with the Under-21s and went down well with the players, but if he had lost four games at that level no one would have taken the blindest bit of notice. It wouldn't even have merited a headline.

The full England team is a different kettle of fish. There will be people waiting for him to fail, and it's put him under added pressure he doesn't need at this stage of his career.

webTitle: Red-hot Flintoff comes of age in heat of the night

fields.headline: Red-hot Flintoff comes of age in heat of the night
fields.trailText: On a bleak autumn day in England, in the week before the clocks go back, it was a thrill to be warmed by Tuesday's cricket from Karachi. Andrew Flintoff's fulminating innings was red hot and as startlingly out of the blue for early evening television watchers as it was stunning to the packed and presumptively celebrating throng in Pakistan's national stadium. The young man's powerful and unafraid batting has shaken England's winter tour into one of vibrant and relishable possibilities.
fields.body:
On a bleak autumn day in England, in the week before the clocks go back, it was a thrill to be warmed by Tuesday's cricket from Karachi. Andrew Flintoff's fulminating innings was red hot and as startlingly out of the blue for early evening television watchers as it was stunning to the packed and presumptively celebrating throng in Pakistan's national stadium. The young man's powerful and unafraid batting has shaken England's winter tour into one of vibrant and relishable possibilities.

Because the floodlights accentuated the television pictures into even bolder relief, English viewers could savour the sharp flavours which make cricket on the subcontinent unique - the kites lazily planing against the vivid sunset backdrop, the white moths flickering against the jagged pelmet of mosques on the skyline, the broiling heat of the 22-yard crucible, the emerald green of the outfield, the blood red of the competition and, particularly, the perspiration cascading down the white men's faces as they screwed their brows to the task . . . Mad dogs and Englishmen, and they knocked off 305 to win by five wickets with more than two overs to spare.

First up, of course, the English bowlers had by no means revelled in the daylight prologue. Dismissively dispatched far and wide, to a man they continued the obsession with their new toy - reverse swing. "Studying the Pakistanis showed me how to perfect it," said Darren Gough. Ah, the simple application of science - and a decade ago there were high court cases in London charging Pakistani bowlers with "ball tampering to achieve reverse swing". All that is forgotten now.

At Alec Stewart's tantrum on being given out, the mind filled with memories of Chris Broad flatly refusing to walk at Lahore 13 winters ago. The immovably belligerent Broad also came to mind when Flintoff was fingered off at the apogee of his grandstand finish. For lip-readers around the world he mouthed the most flamboyant of four-letter exclamations in glorious Technicolor close-up.

Twelve summers ago, given out leg-before against West Indies, Broad mouthed a silent same on his way back to the pavilion and was promptly dropped from the Test team for his pains. Perhaps that was because it happened at Lord's, not Karachi.

For the dramatic unities, however, it was, if truth be told, a four-letter pity that Flintoff could not see out the victory he had conjured. The heat was on, the dust of war was in his nostrils and he was a revelation. In mid-summer I saw him whiff a few late blows for 30-odd to beat Zimbabwe at Manchester, but remained unconvinced. On other occasions I had seen him either solemnly block long-hops or rashly attempt to dismiss good balls from the arena. Then to summon up comparisons with Ian Botham seemed sacrilege.

But Wisden's Matthew Engel had, the year before, seen the 20-year-old from Preston precociously impress his presence in a princely manner for Lancashire at Edgbaston and, in this very corner column, had next day effusively pronounced his imprimatur and, daringly, prophesied the certainty of Flintoff's progress. Tuesday in Karachi underscored the spot-on "spot".

Best of any sportswriter's "spot" was surely by Anon, the hack sent by the Sydney Morning Herald to a boys' trial match at the SCG in November 1926 - "at No7, 18-year-old previously unseen upcountry boy DG Bradman made 37, and although on the small side he showed supreme confidence and the further he went the better he shaped". Which last thought, of course, just about crystallised the Don's career.

I still have a dog-eared parchmenty cutting from the Daily Telegraph of May 23 1974, the day after EW Swanton first clapped beady eye on two Somerset tyros at Hove: "The mature-looking young Antiguan, Richards, sees the ball early and hits it mighty hard. If he can curb himself just a little, he might in a year or so be wearing the plum cap of West Indies. When Richards was out, skying to Greig a ball that might have stopped a bit, a youthful all-rounder from Yeovil, Botham, showed a certain style in making a brisk 26."

Anyway, the clocks go back, winter sets in, rugby league cups and all, but young Flintoff, if he does nothing else, has set up England cricket's summer in Pakistan.

fields.headline: Malcolm on the move
fields.trailText: Leicestershire have signed the former Derbyshire and England fast bowler Devon Malcolm on a two-year contract.
fields.body:
Leicestershire have signed the former Derbyshire and England fast bowler Devon Malcolm on a two-year contract.

The Grace Road club, who swooped for Malcolm after he was released by Northamptonshire, were keen to strenghten their pace attack which struggled last season following the departures of Alan Mullally and David Millns.

Malcolm said: "I look forward to playing alongside an already strong group of players. I know I can help build on recent success and add more trophies to the club's cabinet."

webTitle: Flintoff's power play may earn Test reprieve

fields.headline: Flintoff's power play may earn Test reprieve
fields.trailText: Andrew Flintoff has been made an official stand-by, as a batsman, for the Test series against Pakistan and Sri Lanka following his match-winning innings of 84 off 60 deliveries against Pakistan in Karachi on Tuesday evening.
fields.body:
Andrew Flintoff has been made an official stand-by, as a batsman, for the Test series against Pakistan and Sri Lanka following his match-winning innings of 84 off 60 deliveries against Pakistan in Karachi on Tuesday evening.

There is also a slim chance he might remain on this tour and not return to England, as scheduled, at the end of the one-day series next week.

Mark Ramprakash and Vikram Solanki were originally named as the stand-by batsmen, although yesterday the coach, Duncan Fletcher, seemed to think John Crawley, due to play for the A team in the West Indies, had been named and not Ramprakash.

However Fletcher confirmed that Flintoff would now be on call and given that he is match fit, as a batsman at least, there seems little doubt that he would get the nod ahead of Solanki or Ramprakash.

Before the party left England it was understood that Flintoff would only play in the Test series as an all-rounder, and would therefore have to prove his fitness as a bowler.

Last week it became clear that his spinal condition - there is evidence that he suffered stress fractures some years ago - would not allow him to bowl. The identity of his replacement, Alex Tudor, essentially a bowler who can bat, underlines the importance of the bowling role the team management wanted Flintoff to play.

But Fletcher said yesterday: "We think he can play. He hits the ball harder than almost anyone I've seen. He hits it harder than Graeme Pollock.

"At the moment Freddie is going home next week. But who knows, the tour here has only six weeks to run."

The radio reporter from England was most disappointed with the England coach Duncan Fletcher yesterday. "He doesn't say very much, you see. Give me David Lloyd any day."

"Rubbish," said another media man. "If you want nonsensical soundbites, then Bumble's your man. Fletcher's quiet. But there's much more interest in the England cricket team when we're actually winning a few matches."

The consensus was with the second speaker. There is still a shyness about Fletcher, despite his 52 years, and there is an uneasiness in his dealings with those he does not know. But he has something, the respect and following of the players for one thing. Thoughtful and meticulous, firm but not without compassion, he is the best coach they have had.

He may be quiet but it was easy to see he was bursting with pride and pleasure yesterday following England's remarkable victory in Karachi's National stadium on Tuesday night, when they overhauled Pakistan's 304 with five wickets and 16 balls to spare.

"It was one of my most satisfying wins," he said yesterday. Top of the list, probably, remains Zimbabwe's astonishing victory over Australia at Trent Bridge in the 1975 World Cup. Fletcher, the captain, scored an unbeaten 69 and, with four for 42, was man of the match.

What gave him particular pleasure the other night was that this was a team performance. Andrew Flintoff got the headlines to add another twist to the brief, complex career of an essentially uncomplicated cricketer and man. But this was a team achievement, born of a fresh spirit and a positive attitude. In the recent past England's isolated victories have usually been down to an act of individual excellence.

"Four players scored half-centuries and each one did exactly what he was earmarked to do," said Fletcher. "I want them to get used to their positions in the side because we have still played a lot fewer one-day internationals than other countries."

Even the captain Nasser Hussain, who is miscast at No3, looked the part on Tuesday when wickets fell early, though he got out at the right time when he did not have the power to put away the softening ball.

Graeme Hick, at four, is still their best batsmen at this level and he continued his eye-catching form with a fluent fifty. Graham Thorpe, with his ability to work the ball, to make and scurry ones and twos, is the perfect five, just as Neil Fairbrother was before him.

Fletcher, however, is admirably dissatisfied. "We have to look at our bowling. On these pitches it is essential that we maintain line and length. You get punished if you don't. In England, if you bowl a bad ball, it might still seam or swing so there is a chance of getting away with it. But not here."

Mark Ealham, however, bowled beautifully, at least for his first seven overs, which cost 18 runs. It must have been tempting to run him through his spell. His last three overs went for 31 and in the last over, after being struck a painful blow on the ankle, his next two deliveries went for six and four.

Ashley Giles, whose eight overs cost 37, also impressed and Andy Caddick recovered from a nightmare start. Darren Gough and Craig White were the expensive ones.

Pakistan, meanwhile, are beginning to wonder what they must score to win a match. This was the third occasion they had failed to defend a total of more than 300. "England snatch victory from jaws of defeat," ran the headline in the newspaper here yesterday, which was a bit unfair. At 13 for two, and chasing a tall target, their position looked hopeless. But from there they started winning all the way and at the end it was a bit of a romp.

Most reporters here would not mind if a Trappist was put in charge of England's fortunes provided he could produce like this. And those who think only an Englishman can run the national football team should look this way.

webTitle: Short at odds on job hiring

fields.headline: Short at odds on job hiring
fields.standfirst: NHS should not poach staff from developing countries, says minister
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, has warned the NHS not to poach highly trained staff from the poorest countries to cover skill shortages.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, clashed with government policy yesterday when she warned the NHS not to poach highly trained staff from the poorest countries to cover skill shortages.

Her call was also an indirect criticism of the education secretary, David Blunkett, who is planning to relax work permits to lure computer operators from developing countries.

Ms Short was speaking during Commons question time after the Tory MP Andrew Rowe accused the NHS of trying to employ qualified nurses from poverty-stricken sub-Saharan Africa.

He asked: "Do you not find it almost obscene that one of the richest countries in the world should be sending teams to sub-Saharan Africa to recruit nurses for the NHS when they should be left in the countries [where] they have been trained?"

Ms Short replied: "I very much agree with your fundamental point, that when countries like us and many others say we have skill shortages and we want to recruit internationally - and it is good for people internationally to share their skills and travel to each other's countries - we should not be recruiting highly skilled and expensively trained people from some of the poorest countries."

A spokesman for the NHS said it was not responsible for individual recruitment campaigns run by health authorities and trusts. National guidelines on recruiting staff from abroad had been sent to them.

The Department for Education and Employment announced this month that foreign nationals might soon be allowed in to look for jobs and then seek a work permit.

fields.headline: The invisible man
fields.standfirst: Scotland's new first minister, Henry McLeish, is going to have a hard time holding on to power
fields.trailText: Scotland's new first minister, Henry McLeish, is going to have a hard time holding on to power
fields.body:
Today the Scottish parliament will formally elect a former professional footballer as the second first minister since devolution. Henry McLeish's brief spell with East Fife is always mentioned in profiles. It is one of the few immediately interesting things about this 52-year-old man.

The late Donald Dewar did not want Henry McLeish to succeed him. He told the world that, when he brutally snubbed Mr McLeish's suggestion that he should become deputy leader of the Scottish Labour party.

In private Dewar went further. Just weeks before his death, he reminded me of an incident which, he implied, underlined Mr McLeish's unsuitability for leadership. The occasion was the closure of a tyre factory outside Edinburgh. The Scotsman newspaper had given the Scottish executive a roasting after the factory owners leaked suggestions that they had not received government support they thought they had been promised. The executive said little in its own defence.

I had to call Mr Dewar to ask him to explain the silence. Mr McLeish was responsible as the enterprise minister. But I explained that Henry McLeish was not available for comment. He had gone on a private lecture tour to the United States.

It seemed strange that a minister with a crisis on his patch had disappeared from view - (stranger still that the Scotsman's then political editor, now widely expected to become Mr McLeish's official spokesman, worked hard to keep the absence secret).

When we last spoke, Mr Dewar reminded me of that incident. His concern was Henry's habit of crouching behind the parapet when controversy approached.

Mr McLeish has never served in cabinet. If he has any of the intellectual energy or passion of his predecessor he has kept it hidden. As Senator Lloyd Bensen might have put it: "I knew Donald Dewar. I worked with Donald Dewar. Donald Dewar was a friend of mine. Mr McLeish, you are no Donald Dewar."

Formal parliamentary endorsement of Mr McLeish's new status is a legal requirement. The Scotland Act obliges MSPs to elect a new first minister within 28 days of the departure of his predecessor. If they don't, a general election is called.

So, having won the leadership of his party in an emergency contest against finance minister Jack McConnell, Mr McLeish can be confident that he will be anointed. He and his new wife are looking forward to moving in to their elegant official residence in Edinburgh.

From that moment on, things will get difficult for the man the Daily Record in Scotland has dubbed King Henry. He is the leader nobody wanted.

Mr McLeish was nearly beaten on Saturday. Among the Labour backbenchers whose votes were not mandated by the occupants of Numbers 10 and 11 Downing Street, he was comprehensively beaten. He squeaked through on the payroll vote. Cynics suggest this is why the Scottish executive has three times as many ministerial positions as it needs.

Mr McLeish faces two immediate problems. His backbenchers voted for his opponent. His ministers only supported him out of resid ual loyalty to London. Henry McLeish has a lot to prove. His response to his wafer-thin win was to make quasi-nationalist comments, transparently crafted to woo the very backbenchers who voted for his opponent.

This is alarming. His election must be endorsed in December by a proper ballot of Labour's electoral college. A deputy leader will be elected simultaneously. It is plain that a deputy elected by the proper procedure will have at least as much authority as a leader who was not.

McLeish was protected from defeat this time around because that is what London wanted. The parallels with Labour's Welsh debacle are being discussed.

Mr McLeish is indelibly marked as Gordon Brown's man. If his response is to be more nationalist than thou, London may abandon him. That becomes more likely if he fails to set an ambitious agenda. The incompetence, caution and sloth which has characterised devolution so far was only tolerated because Donald Dewar was a towering figure. Henry McLeish lacks that status and has little time to build it.

He will have to make hard decisions fast. The devolution project is threatened by public disappointment and nationalist advance. If Mr McLeish cannot unite his own party and defeat the SNP in the looming byelections, the second first minister could soon be replaced by a third.

There are brighter ministers serving in the executive. Wendy Alexander and Susan Deacon can both point to accomplishments considerably more solid than those of Mr McLeish.

Scotland has not yet approached the point when the fairer sex could anticipate justice in politics. But there are still some radicals who suspect that an Alexander/Deacon leadership might be four times as dynamic as the rule of the invisible man.

Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman. Between 1985-88, he worked as research assistant and press officer to the late Donald Dewar.

fields.headline: Rules watchdog is caught out
fields.trailText: The Conservatives scored a hit on Labour on the running tit-for-tat battle over parliamentary sleaze            yesterday when, Robert Sheldon, the veteran Labour chairman of the Commons standards and            privileges committee , fell foul of the disclosure rules.
fields.body:
The Conservatives scored a hit on Labour on the running tit-for-tat battle over parliamentary sleaze yesterday when, Robert Sheldon, the veteran Labour chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee , fell foul of the disclosure rules.

As Mr Sheldon was criticised for not declaring a financial interest in four textile firms during debates on the small business sector, Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards , simultaneously found in favour of Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor.

Similar complaints had been laid against Mr Portillo for failing to register correctly fees paid for speeches outside parliament. After a two month inquiry he was cleared - but not former treasury minister, Mr Sheldon.

Mr Sheldon was cleared on seven complaints made by Tory MP, Ian Bruce, but caught out on two, with both sides point scoring over ever tighter disclosure rules in the post-Nolan era. Mr Portillo had been accused by Labour's Chris Leslie. In her report on Mr Sheldon, MP for Ashton under Lyne since 1964, Mrs Filkin said: "Given the nature of (his) business interests, it would have been advisable for him to make a declaration in all of the 12 debates. This conclusion is not affected by the fact that in none of his interventions was (he) seeking assistance specifically for the textile industry."

On Tuesday the committee, chaired by Labour's Alan Williams after Mr Sheldon withdrew, upheld the report but decided against further action on a "marginal" case where the MP had declared his interests in writing, but not in debates he thought "too broad and diffuse" to be relevant.

In Mr Portillo's case the MP had, after some delay, registered speaking fees after seeking guidance from Mrs Filkin, but Mr Leslie claimed he had an unregistered "employment contract" with a speakers bureau.

Mr Sheldon's case was complex and spread over many years. Mrs Filkin, a stickler for the rules, concluded it would have been "advisable" for him to explain his ties during economic debates.

webTitle: Cash from Palestinian group mars Hillary's fight

fields.headline: Cash from Palestinian group mars Hillary's fight
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton's path to a seat in the United States senate was fouled yesterday by the embarrassing revelation that her campaign had accepted money from a group whose leader supports the right of Palestinians to use armed force against Israel.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton's path to a seat in the United States senate was fouled yesterday by the embarrassing revelation that her campaign had accepted money from a group whose leader supports the right of Palestinians to use armed force against Israel.

The American Muslim Alliance collected $50,000 (£34,5000) for her at a $500-a-ticket fundraiser in Boston in June. Mrs Clinton was present and received a plaque from the alliance honouring her work for human rights.

Agha Saeed, national president of the alliance, says Palestinians should seek to establish their own state in the West Bank and Gaza through peaceful means but if that fails United Nations resolutions "say specifically that they have the right to resist by armed force."

Mrs Clinton's shifting attitudes towards the Middle East have caused her more problems than most issues in her contest against Republican congressman Rick Lazio for the right to represent New York state in the senate.

Jewish voters account for at least 12% of those expected to go to the polls on November 7 and precedent suggests that any Democratic candidate must secure about two-thirds of these to win. Recent polls show Mrs Clinton ahead of Mr Lazio by a factor of two-one among this sector and leading by seven points generally.

Mrs Clinton has spent much of the time since her campaign started 16 months ago distancing herself from her 1998 support for an independent Palestinian state. But her true intentions were at best obscured at the end of last year when she embraced Suha Arafat, the wife of Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, after she delivered a speech claiming that Israel was poisoning Palestinian children. Mrs Clinton said that she was misled by an inadequate translation.

Since then, she has courted Jewish voters assiduously, interrupted only by the publication in the summer of a book that claimed she called a campaign aide a "fucking Jewish bastard" more than 20 years ago. Mrs Clinton denied the charge and enlisted the president in her support.

Last month she denounced a UN security council resolution condemning Israel and spoke on the platform of a pro-Israel rally in Manhattan two weeks ago. "Hillary is a strong supporter of peace and security for Israel," her spokesman, Howard Wolfson, said yesterday.

The Clinton campaign claims that the Boston fund-raiser was not sponsored by the alliance but by another group even though the plaque she received was inscribed with the words American Muslim Alliance.

Mr Wolfson said the event was sponsored by members of the Boston Muslim community rather than the alliance, which was not mentioned on the invitations. "All my fund-raising people say it was not hosted by these folks. It was hosted by two other individuals. Someone who was at the event just handed her a plaque."

Tahir Ali, the alliance's Massachusetts chairman, said his group took over the sponsorship about a week before it was held and that he did not regret raising the money for her in the light of her recent actions backing Israel.

"The idea is to win the election," he said. "She must change her tune. But that doesn't mean anything. It's just at the spur of the moment that she must say these things and we understand that."

Mr Wolfson said that a $1,000 senate campaign contribution would be returned to Abdurahman Alamoudi, a member of the American Muslim Council and a guest at a White House reception despite his support for Hamas, which is considered by the state department to be a terrorist organisation because of its attacks on Israeli civilians.

webTitle: When governments don't level with the people

fields.headline: When governments don't level with the people
fields.standfirst: The BSE inquiry has shown that looking on the bright side can be hazardous to the people's health, writes David McKie
fields.trailText: The BSE inquiry has shown that looking on the bright side can be hazardous to the people's health, writes David McKie.
fields.body:
During the second world war there used to be a criminal offence of "spreading alarm and despondency." If you went around saying, "the government's claims that the war is going well are all nonsense, you know; we are losing the battle and suffering grievous losses; it is going to end in defeat", then someone could report you, and you could end up facing prosecution. Even had you been right.

There is a problem here for governments, even democratic ones who declare their intention of levelling with the people. It is easy to spread alarm, easy to fan that alarm into panic. Some of the panic buying during the recent fuel crisis showed that. Or take terrorist threats: pass them all on to the public, and you cause perpetual disruption... But fail to pass on a genuine one, and people will die.

The 16-volume report of Lord Phillips's inquiry into BSE and its human equivalent vCJD catches many good people in government trembling before this dilemma. Pass on to the public all the scientific assessments, however hard to comprehend and however dire, and alarm and despondency - they told themselves - might break out all over the country.

In this fix, civil servants and ministers - though civil servants here take more of the blame, since ministers in this sense are mere amateurs, dependent on professional advice - tend to say to themselves: the worst may never happen. Why worry people unduly? Let's not be afraid (the next, fatal step in the argument) to look on the bright side. Had they been right, and the worst had not happened, they might have earned our gratitude. They were wrong, and a fearful price has been paid. All that is bad enough. What is perhaps even worse is when decisions are taken at last to deal with the threat on the scale that it deserves, and action is not carried through. Belatedly, a ban was imposed in 1989 on bovine offal entering the food chain. But that ban, Lord Phillips and his colleagues, conclude, was never properly enforced. Down the line, risks were taken by people who also told themselves the worst would not happen. Last night, in his excellent TV history of Britain, Simon Schama took as his subject the Black Death which ravaged the country in the 14th century. We know now why it happened: the screen was full of lurid pictures of death-dealing fleas. At the time, though, all sorts of wild theories floated about: the kind of fog which came to be known as miasma was blamed.

Suppose a Black Death struck now... We would surely be far more fortunate. We would have the technology to establish a working hypothesis on the causes with relative speed. But we'd need to proceed from the outset with a sense of urgency which could only come from government playing straight with the scientific analysis, not minimising the threat, and above all dealing openly, rather than lulling the country into a false complacency by keeping the bad news from it - as happened here.

But it can help to change the climate. Ministers did not lie about CJD, the report concludes: they simply played down the links between BSE and human involvement. We can at least hope that on any future occasions in any way parallel with what happened here, that lesson will be at the front of official minds right through the system.

The new Freedom of Information legislation won't help, by the way: it would not give the public the right of access to any of the information denied it in this case.

If you went around saying, "the government's claims that the war is going well are all nonsense, you know; we are losing the battle and suffering grievous losses; it is going to end in defeat", then someone could report you, and you could end up facing prosecution. Even had you been right. There is a problem here for governments, even democratic ones who declare their intention of levelling with the people. It is easy to spread alarm, easy to fan that alarm into panic. Some of the panic buying during the recent fuel crisis showed that. Or take terrorist threats: pass them all on to the public, and you cause perpetual disruption... But fail to pass on a genuine one, and people will die. The 16-volume report of Lord Phillips's inquiry into BSE and its human equivalent vCJD catches many good people in government trembling before this dilemma. In this fix, civil servants and ministers - though civil servants here take more of the blame, since ministers in this sense are mere amateurs, dependent on professional advice - tend to say to themselves: the worst may never happen. Why worry people unduly? Let's not be afraid (the next, fatal step in the argument) to look on the bright side. Had they been right, and the worst had not happened, they might have earned our gratitude. They were wrong, and a fearful price has been paid. All that is bad enough. webTitle: The IRA makes an offer the unionists can refuse

fields.headline: The IRA makes an offer the unionists can refuse
fields.standfirst: As Tony Blair visits Northern Ireland to try to boost the peace process, Derek Brown examines the latest offer and hints from the IRA
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair visits Northern Ireland to try to boost the peace process, Derek Brown examines the latest offer and hints from the IRA.
fields.body:
Little by little, Ulster's bitterly divided Unionist party is being nudged and cajoled towards a more full-hearted commitment to the Good Friday peace process.

Tony Blair is in Belfast today, talking to all the parties involved in the power-sharing peace deal. But one man, first secretary David Trimble, holds the key.

On Saturday, the ruling council of his Ulster Unionist party will meet to consider a plea from Trimble's hawkish rival Jeffrey Donaldson for a phased withdrawal from the institutions of devolved government in the province.

There has been a flurry of initiatives to help stiffen the resolve of Trimble's supporters. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has offered them a symbolic but potent little victory over republican Sinn Fein, by ordering that the union flag be flown over ever public building on important national holidays and commemoration days - including the offices occupied by Sinn Fein ministers.

This afternoon, no doubt timed to coincide with the Prime Minister's visit, the Ministry of Defence has announced a life-saving order for new ships to Belfast's ailing Harland and Wolff yard.

But the biggest carrot that is being dangled before the unionists is being offered by its sworn enemies in the Provisional IRA.

They have agreed to another independent inspection of arms dumps, and have said that they are willing to consider talks in the future on a more permanent disarmament process.

Donaldson, predictably, has dismissed the IRA statement as nothing new.

Indeed, on the face of it, the Provisionals are only offering to let the independent inspectors have another look at what they have already seen - presumably to make sure it's still there.

The second part of the offer is more intriguing, for it holds out the prospect, however distant, of genuine disarmament.

The IRA, in its customary convoluted way, says it will talk again with General John de Chastelain - the head of the independent disarmament commission, and surely the least employed man in Ulster - when it is satisfied that such talks would advance the peace process.

Decoding that cumbersome formula is not too difficult. The IRA is saying, without pinning itself down in any way, that it expects lots of new concessions from the British government and from the unionists, before it makes its next significant advance towards peace.

That means further building work on the cross-border all-Ireland institutions established by the Good Friday accord.

Most of all, it means steady progress towards a thorough reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

This is the most sensitive issue of all for both communities in Northern Ireland. For republicans, the RUC is a hated symbol of oppression; for unionists, it is an equally potent symbol of their links with Britain.

It is this issue which, more than any other, threatens to tear Trimble's party asunder. Already, there are clear signals that the right wing is being tugged in the direction of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists or one of the other smaller factions competing for the 'no surrender' vote.

This year, Northern Ireland's first minister has already survived one bruising internal party debate, and a bid for the leadership. Both votes were desperately narrow.

With yet another challenge looming, he will be in no mood today to jump at the IRA offer as proof that the peace is holding. Rather, he will be demanding greater proofs from the republican movement that it really intends to keep the peace.

And he will be pleading with Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson to tone down or delay their police reform legislation.

fields.headline: Stanley, Sven, and Sugar
fields.trailText: IT'S THE LAST CHANCE SALOON FOR STANLEY (copyright all media publications, 1997)
fields.body:
IT'S THE LAST CHANCE SALOON FOR STANLEY (copyright all media publications, 1997)

Sometimes the Fiver wonders whether it worries too much about Stanley Victor Collymore. His bedroom lock-in for example, which nearly left the Fiver on medication, was actually a precursor to a glamorous move to Leicester City and a night out in Spain with a fire extinguisher. Now, after we had sweated buckets when Foxy boss Peter Taylor put Stanley on the transfer list, the former Southend marksman has upped and left for Bradford until the end of the season on a free transfer! Without even calling!

Obviously this is not the time to start getting on Stanley's back. He needs the Fiver's help more than ever now that he's joined a bunch of relegation certainties who've only scored four league goals this season, and have a chairman who increasingly appears to be dictating first team affairs. Geoffrey Richmond started the week by threatening manager Chris Hutchings with the sack if results did not improve, and he was on equally emphatic form this morning. "We are well aware of the Stan[ley] Collymore story, and we consider this to be a legitimate gamble", he said, failing to clarify who he meant by 'we'. "We hope the signing of Stan[ley] will act as a catalyst for the rest of the team - and we hope it will happen fairly quickly."

So Stanley better make sure he gets that hat-trick against Leeds on Sunday afternoon, otherwise it'll be trouble. But aside from the laughable idea of Stanley as a booster of morale, there are other reasons for Bradford fans to be concerned. Stanley's arrival is unlikely to have caused the wage bill to shrink for starters, and he will only add to the contingent of Bradford players who prefer to play pretty than win dirty. Finally one must actually wonder whether, nowadays, Stanley is any more capable of ending a goal drought than Benito Carbone or Ashley Ward. Now do you see what we mean about our nerves?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PLONKERS

Yesterday, the Fiver gave the impression that the wonderful city of Copenhagen was in Holland. Perhaps we had been spending too much time in Christiania because the Danish capital is in fact in Denmark. Thanks to all the clever readers who wrote in to point out our mistake, especially those from New York, Spain.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SVEN WILL IT ALL END?

Keeping up with the activities of Del Boy Crozier and his FA cronies is - for the Fiver at least - a mightily confusing business. One day, it seems that Copenhagen, Denmark, is the focus of their operations. But then night comes and everything changes: suddenly Coy Roy Hodgson is yesterday's news, replaced by a new England manager of choice: sexy Swede Sven Goran Eriksson. Certainly the Lazio manager seems up for it, today telling the London Evening Standard: "I feel like I could do the job."

However, despite Eriksson's declaration, the Fiver - in its own indiscreet way - isn't building a sauna and getting out its Best of Abba: Volume 2 CD to welcome the new man just yet. Because no sooner had Sven uttered those tentative words, than he suddenly changed his mind. "Right now I am very satisfied with the situation here and I feel good about Lazio," he claimed, adding: "No one has asked me about the England job and I have not had any formal offer or approach."

But then sexy Swede Sven changed track again. "If it is the case that I am on the (FA) shortlist then that is a great honour," he gushed. "It's an interesting job and it's always good to change." So does he want it or not? That's for Eriksson to know and Del Boy Crozier to find out, we guess. But with Real Madrid and Olympiakos both believed to be monitoring the situation - and, according to reports, willing to pay Sven £3m a season - the FA might be advised to put all its airmiles towards a trip to Denmark.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The strange thing is that at the time I didn't fully realise how close we had come. It was not until a year or so later that it dawned on me just how important that semi-final was. I wasn't used to playing two legs in a semi and perhaps that's why it didn't seem like one to me. Now that I think back, we should at least have got to the final."

Robbie Fowler reminisces on Liverpool's splendiferous Cup Winner's Cup defeat at the hands of Paris St Germain in 1997 [thanks to Kevin Rainey].

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SUGAR RUSH

"The thing about Spurs right, is that Alan Sugar. Too cautious he is, too much of a businessman. Thinks with his head, not his heart innit. Rather see his accounts in the black than Ronaldo on the pitch. And you can tell him I said that." Supporters, eh, what do they know? That's right, absolutely nish, because if Sugar really was the businessman everyone makes him out to be, why is his club in the red?

The simple explanation for that is, that it's getting ever harder for big clubs to turn a profit. Just like Chelsea, who reported a £3.5m loss over the past 12 months, Spurs' wage bill is constantly on the up and up, rising 21% in the past year to £26.2m. They also spent £23.4m on new players (cue mass scenes of scalp scratching on the Seven Sisters Road). So this meant that, while Spurs' income rose by a healthy 13%, they still posted an overall loss of £750,000.

The only way for Spurs to remedy this situation is to win a trophy, or something equally drastic. Sugar today described last season's performances in the Uefa, Worthy and FA Cups as "very disappointing", but until that trend is reversed the club will continue to find itself in a vicious circle of spending to keep alive the possibility of profit.

No wonder then that the Sugar's second statement today was to declare his intention to fight the FA's £150,000 fine, imposed after Spurs and Leeds duked it out at Elland Road last season. "We are still appealing strongly against this decision," Sugar said. And who wouldn't wish him well in his endeavours? Actually, don't answer that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Milan have offered Internazionale contract rebel Alvaro Recoba a five-year deal, worth £100,000 a week, if he switches clubs, "sources close to the player" have revealed to onefootball.

Chelsea are preparing to sell 19-year-old striker Mikael Forssell to Bayer Leverkusen for £3m, according to reports.

Meanwhile, Tore Andre Flo could also be set to leave the Blues. "I need to speak to the manager to find out what exactly is going on," the Norwegian international admitted. "I don't want to leave but I just need to know where I stand. I have played nearly 50 games for my country and I hope it is not going to be a regular thing to sit on the bench."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Scottish Premier League have backed Arthur Numan's efforts to overturn his Champions League red card at Sturm Graz last night. The Dutchman was dismissed for a second bookable offence - however today he insisted that his first booking, for re-entering the field of play, was a "disgrace" because referee Antonio Lopez was actually waving him back on to the pitch.

Michael Bridges could be out of action for up to eight weeks after damaging ligaments in his ankle during the goalless draw against Besiktas in Istanbul. "Michael needs an operation - his leg is a total mess," said Leeds manager David O'Leary O'Leeds. "I don't know exactly how long he will be missing for but it looks like being a long time."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC 1: Match of the Day Live: Liverpool v Slovan Liberec (8.05pm) To add spice to tonight's game, the Fiver will down two fingers of Czech vodka if Motty uses the phrase: "This will be Liberec's biggest game in their history, by some distance."

ITV: World Football (3.10am) And we will partake in three fingers of the clear stuff if Motty claims that "Slovan are so small they don't even have floodlights at their ground," and follows that observation up with "but they are installing them just for the second leg."

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.15am) And we'll go completely alco-crazy if Motty screams: "That's Czech mate!" when Liverpool seal an improbably victory in injury time.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am) Just a reminder: whenever Motty laughs at his own joke = one finger. And Barry Davies commentating = turn on the radio instead

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (8pm) Where you are bound to hear some bloke ranting on about weak tea, spectators in his way and how Motty is always blanking him...

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm) It's unlike Sky not be repeating this show at least three times during the day. We're suspicious.

Fifa TV (7pm) And this is only on once too. Time to call the cops, perhaps?

Sky Sports 3: Spanish Football (7pm, SS1 2am) Ah, be still our beating heart. Normal service is resumed...

fields.headline: Andersen Consulting unveils £121m rebranding drive
fields.trailText: 5pm: Andersen Consulting is to pump £121m into a global rebranding campaign when it changes its name to Accenture next year, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Andersen Consulting is to plough a massive £121m into a global rebranding campaign when it changes its name to Accenture next year.

The management consultancy has announced that it is changing its name on January 1, when it splits from sister company Arthur Andersen.

Since the move was confirmed in August, Andersen Consulting has been searching for a new name in a multimillion pound process that has involved law firms in 49 different countries, a team of linguistics specialists and the international branding consultancy Landor Associates.

The new name was devised by an Andersen Consulting employee in Norway and chosen from an initial list comprising a staggering 5,000 names.

Jim Murphy, Andersen Consulting's worldwide marketing director, said: "This is a unique undertaking given the size of the firm. Our name is everything and we wanted the new name to reflect the fact that we do a lot more than just consultancy work."

The rebranding campaign will begin on January 1 and will run through to August 2001.

It will include advertising, PR and direct marketing and will be conducted through the Young & Rubicam group of marketing companies, which includes the direct marketing agency Impiric and the PR agency Burston Marsteller.

The firm split from Arthur Andersen because the accountancy firm had set up its own strategic consultancy arm, making it a competitor to Andersen Consulting.

Andersen Consulting then went to an independent arbitrator claiming Arthur Andersen's decision to build a consultancy business put it in breach of an agreement between the two firms.

The arbitrator ruled that Andersen Consulting should be allowed to split from its sister company, but in so doing it lost the right to its brand name.

It will include advertising, PR and direct marketing and will be conducted through the Young & Rubicam group of marketing companies, which includes the direct marketing agency Impiric and the PR agency Burston Marsteller. The firm split from Arthur Andersen because the accountancy firm had set up its own strategic consultancy arm, making it a competitor to Andersen Consulting. Andersen Consulting then went to an independent arbitrator claiming Arthur Andersen's decision to build a consultancy business put it in breach of an agreement between the two firms. The arbitrator ruled that Andersen Consulting should be allowed to split from its sister company, but in so doing it lost the right to its brand name.

fields.headline: Boom! Boom! Basil Brush is back
fields.trailText: Entertainment Rights has licensed Hasbro to make a range of Basil Brush toys and merchandise, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Shopping aisles up and down the land could soon be filled with children shouting "Boom! Boom!", the catch-phrase of popular TV character Basil Brush, following a deal between the property's owner Entertainment Rights and toy manufacturer Hasbro.

Entertainment Rights, the UK intellectual property exploitation company, has licensed Hasbro to make Basil Brush glove puppets and other toys, backpacks, games and puzzles. Deals are already in place for a range of Basil Brush stationery and greetings cards.

The new merchandising range could hit UK high streets as early as next spring. The consumer marketing launch is likely to be tied to a new Basil Brush TV sitcom that is being developed by Talent Television.

Entertainment Rights is talking to the BBC and ITV about the TV show. Mike Heap, its chief executive, said: "This agreement is a significant step forward in Entertainment Rights strategic vision to establish Basil as a global character. Character licensing is expected to make a significant contribution to the group's annual revenues by 2002, and Basil will be a major contributor to this."
