fields.headline: Ten O'Clock News ratings dip
fields.trailText: 12.45pm TV ratings: BBC1's Ten O'Clock News continued its ratings slide, dipping below 4m viewers for the first time. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The ratings for BBC1's Ten O'Clock News continued to slide last night, dipping below 4m viewers for the first time since the bulletin moved to a later slot last Monday.

The Ten O'Clock News averaged just 3.6m and an 18% share, according to unofficial overnights.

It is believed that the BBC's flagship evening bulletin has only fallen below 3.6m on three other occasions this year.

Last Wednesday the bulletin took 4.3m, while the final Wednesday night Nine O'Clock News averaged 5.1m two weeks ago.

The BBC1 bulletin was up against a late evening Coronation Street, displaced from its usual 7.30pm berth, and Tonight with Trevor McDonald, on ITV. The soap drew 9.8m, while Tonight averaged 5.5m and a 32% share - the sort of numbers that will have BBC current affairs producers looking on enviously.

The Ten O'Clock News was also not helped by a poor inheritance from drama Scarlet Pimpernel, which disappointed again on its second outing. The Richard E Grant swashbuckler managed only 5.7m - and a 25% share - against the start of Corrie and a one-sided Champions League football game on ITV.

Arsenal had already qualified for the next round of the competition and killed the game as a contest with two goals in the first five minutes, but live coverage of their eventual 4-2 defeat of Sparta Prague still averaged 6m and a 30% share 7.30pm.

There was better ratings news for the corporation on BBC2, where Simon Schama continued his popular stroll through British history with a look at the Black Death. A History of Britain by Simon Schama picked up a healthy 3.2m and 14% share from 9pm on its fourth outing and looks like becoming one of the documentary hits of the year.

BBC2 controller Jane Root must be glad she has another 12 hours of this stuff on the shelf, given the way BBC1 keeps ferreting away her best rating shows.

On Channel 4 last night Brookside was extended to a full hour to give Jackie Corkhill's blossoming lesbian affair the coverage it deserved. The 60-minute special did not disappoint on the ratings front, pulling in 2.7m and a 12% share.

A movie repeat yet again provided the ratings high for Channel 5, which ran Basic Instinct from 10.15pm. The Michael Douglas/Sharon Stone knee-trembler averaged 1.7m and a 16% share.

fields.headline: Collymore joins Bradford
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has taken another step on his tortuous career path this morning by leaving Leicester to join Bradford on a free transfer. The 29-year-old striker could go straight into the Bantams squad to face Leeds United at Valley Parade on Sunday.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has taken another step on his tortuous career path this morning by leaving Leicester to join Bradford on a free transfer. The 29-year-old striker could go straight into the Bantams squad to face Leeds United at Valley Parade on Sunday.

Collymore's time at Leicester had been running out ever since Peter Taylor put the former England international on the transfer list last month. Taylor had wanted to partner new signing Ade Akinbiyi with Collymore up front this season but, following pre-season demands for an improved contract, and an appearance as a substitute against Everton described by Taylor as "not acceptable for a professional footballer", he changed his mind. Collymore's departure was only hastened when he became involved in a fight with team-mate Trevor Benjamin during a reserve team fixture 10 days ago.

Collymore's move north will be seen as yet another last chance after his failed spells at Liverpool, Aston Villa and, now, Leicester. But in truth Bradford themselves are in equal difficulty, having scored only four league goals this season.

Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond however does not see the signing of Collymore as a risk. "We are well aware of the Stan Collymore story, and we consider this to be a legitimate gamble", he said.

"But there is a clear problem in the goalscoring department. We hope the signing of Stan will act as a catalyst for the rest of the team - and we hope it will happen fairly quickly. We are 19th, the team are struggling and the fans are not happy, and understandably so. We want to give them something to cheer about."

Richmond's urgent tone will be no comfort to manager Chris Hutchings, who has already been warned by his chairman that his job is on the line should results fail to improve. There is little doubt that the improvement will be expected to start this weekend.

webTitle: Microsoft spins $1bn web relaunch to challenge AOL

fields.headline: Microsoft spins $1bn web relaunch to challenge AOL
fields.trailText: Microsoft is to spend $1bn (£690m) relaunching its web-based services in an attempt to topple America Online as the world's leading internet service provider.
fields.body:
Microsoft is to spend $1bn (£690m) relaunching its web-based services in an attempt to topple America Online as the world's leading internet service provider.

The group said the global marketing campaign begun yesterday was designed to make MSN, its online brand, as well known internationally as Windows, the operating software used on more than 90% of the world's computers.

Few other companies have spent as much on advertising their online products, although few are as wealthy as Microsoft. The company has cash on hand of almost $24bn after gaining $3bn from operations in the past three months alone.

Analysts were sceptical about the company's ability to improve dramatically the popularity of MSN by spending huge amounts of money on a marketing campaign.

"They want to close the gap [with AOL] and so they're throwing money at it," said one. Shares in Microsoft fell slightly in a difficult market for the hi-tech sector.

Microsoft has just 3.5m subscribers compared with AOL's 25m. MSN also ranked third in the September web league tables compiled by Media Metrix, the online data group, behind AOL and Yahoo!

The company came relatively late to the internet with its Internet Explorer web browser. Wall Street has also blamed the legal battles with the US government for hampering its expansion plans. As the company's anti-trust trial moves into the appeal stage, one analyst said yesterday: "They have no choice but to step up their growth prospects."

Some $150m of the marketing campaign will be used on television advertising across north America, Europe and Asia. The first advertisements, designed to show how the internet can improve home life, were aired last night.

Microsoft has also fitted out a Manhattan loft with the latest company products. The "Microsoft home" in Tribeca is an attempt to show how the company's internet-friendly devices can "simplify daily tasks, keep us connected, and help us have fun and relax in the home".

The rest of the $1bn will be spent over the next year on partnerships with retailers, cross-promotions, rebates and other marketing campaigns.

The initiative, which includes a new multicoloured in ternet browser, is designed to make it easier to swap services from software to the internet. As such, it is part of the company's new strategy, .NET, which was introduced in June.

Deanna Sanford, product manager for MSN marketing, obliquely positioned the new-look services as a direct challenge to AOL by saying: "We are making MSN the easiest way to get online, not only for new users but also for those users out there who for whatever reason are unfulfilled."

webTitle: In brief: Tom Jones to blast out next Bond theme?

fields.headline: Tom Jones to blast out next Bond theme?
fields.trailText: Plus: Ridley pays tribute to Ollie the Sex Pistols' way, UK Bedazzled to get extra character, brushed aside Van Dyke calls it a day, Spock's lugs under the hammer, Hackman join the Tenenbaums and Charlie's Angels get Gorey
fields.body:
 Reports suggest that the producers of the next Bond movie are seeking Welsh crooner Tom Jones to perform the title song; Jones previously belted out the opening track to 1965's Thunderball. "It's early days, but we are desperately keen to have Jones do it," a source is quoted as saying. Recent themes have not been huge successes, but Tom Jones is a legend and the song would almost certainly be massive.

 Gladiator director Ridley Scott has cut together a special montage paying homage to Oliver Reed, who died while filming the Russell Crowe blockbuster. The montage may be released on the DVD of the smash Roman-era film. The four-minute tribute, spliced together from outtakes of the heavy-drinking actor, is accompanied by the Sex Pistols' version of Sinatra's My Way. Scott says: "I would like to think the Sex Pistols would say, 'Oh fuck it, let's give it to Ollie...' but it may come down to whether we have to pay for performing rights and whether DreamWorks say it's worth it. It's very amusing and very emotional and moving because right at the end Ollie says, 'That's enough for now.'"

 Liz Hurley flick Bedazzled is to be released in the UK with added scenes. A character modelled on members of Britpop outfits Oasis and Supergrass will appear in the British version of Bedazzled, despite having been cut from the US film after test audiences gave it a bamboozled thumbs-down. The star of the Satan-based film, Brendan Fraser, says the rock star was his favourite character in the movie, and that the scene in which the character appeared "sort of became our homage to Sid And Nancy. We thought we were doing a spoof, like This Is Spinal Tap". Bedazzled opens in the UK on November 10.

 Mary Poppins cockernee Dick Van Dyke has retired from his glittering career on film and in US TV. "It's time for me to go to pasture", the 74-year-old star announced. "Tastes have changed. Television's going, as far as I'm concerned, downhill, and I'm an anachronism." The star's landmark Dick Van Dyke Show ran on America's CBS network from 1961 to 1966. He's known to audiences in Britain for his appearances alongside Julie Andrews as the Chim-Chiminee chimney sweep in Poppins and for his role in the much-loved movie Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.

 The Los Angeles outlet of Christie's is to auction four pairs of Vulcan ears that Leonard Nimoy wore when he played Star Trek's Mr Spock. The mould that was used to produce the ears is also for sale. The sci-fi artefacts go on sale on November 15, alongside the Spanish Civil War diaries of Errol Flynn.

 Gene Hackman will star in hot young director Wes Anderson's comedy The Royal Tenenbaums. Joining Hackman will be Ben Stiller, Gwyneth Paltrow, brothers Owen and Luke Wilson and Bill Murray. Tenenbaums is about a dysfunctional family of geniuses who wind up as adults living under the same roof, and is created by the team behind last year's offbeat hit Rushmore.

 For those in need of heavyweight advice in advance of the US presidential elections, the three Charlie's Angels (Drew Barrymore, Cameron Diaz, and Lucy Liu) have been wearing anti-George W. Bush T-shirts while promoting the film. Says Diaz, "I gave over 50 interviews today by satellite and encouraged everyone to vote, and to vote for Gore".

fields.headline: Ivory Coast
fields.standfirst: The despotic military ruler of the Ivory Coast has just been chased out by a popular uprising. Here's our guide to the best sites on this West African nation
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: The despotic military ruler of the Ivory Coast has just been chased out by a popular uprising. Here's our guide to the best sites on this West African nation
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. Once again, a despot has been sent packing in a Serbia-style popular uprising.

2. This time, it has happened in the Ivory Coast, one of the West African countries racked by military and political upheavals.

3. Unlike Liberia and Sierra Leone, Ivory Coast has mostly enjoyed relative peace and plenty since it won independence from France in 1960.

4. For more than three decades it was ruled by Felix Houphouet-Boigny, a benign autocrat who died in 1993.

5. After the death of the Old Man, as he was known, the one-party system disintegrated. At the end of last year the former army chief Robert Guei staged a bloodless coup. He promised, like all barrack-based rulers, to clean up the country and restore it to the people.

6. Instead, he declared himself an independent candidate in this month's presidential election.

7. He rigged it, still lost it, but declared himself the winner anyway.

8. Ivorians may be impoverished, but by the standards of the region they are politically sophisticated, and did not take kindly to having their election stolen.

9. They took to the streets.

10. After 24 hours of bloodshed the army deserted Guie and went over to the real election winner, veteran social democrat Laurent Gbagbo. Guei's whereabouts are not known.

fields.headline: Prince Andrew tours Silicon Alley
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Prince Andrew is taking a leaf out of his mother's book and plunging into the internet, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Prince Andrew is taking a leaf out of his mother's book and plunging into the internet.

Just days after the Queen watched the value of her internet stock fall by £500,000, Prince Andrew is going on a whistle-stop tour of three Manhattan internet consultancies.

Next Tuesday, the Duke of York will visit London-founded new media agency Bluewave in New York to find out more about how internet companies work.

He is expected to stay for just over an hour and will to be greeted by Robert Adair, chief finance officer and managing director of Bluewave USA, sales and marketing director Alex Barnett, and Damien Drake, studio manager at the US office.

He will also visit Boston Consulting and DoubleClick, one of the biggest online sales networks in the world.

Prince Andrew is an avid user of the internet and met Tim Berners-Lee, the founder of the web, in San Francisco three years ago.

A spokesman for the duke said: "Andrew has a passion for the internet and has done so ever since he met Tim. He knows a lot about the internet. He does a lot of internet chats and uses email on a regular basis."

The hi-tech tour was arranged after the duke expressed an interest in visiting a UK internet company in Silicon Alley, and had asked Thomas Harris, HM Consul General to the US who spoke at a Bluewave event in New York earlier this year, to set up a number of meetings.

A spokesman from Bluewave said it would be taking the duke through the process of setting up a website up and show him the work it did for the Royal Horticultural Society www.rhs.org.uk.

He added: "He is keen to highlight the fact that there are a number of British companies entering the US internet market and becoming very successful."

fields.headline: The Anglo-Australian South African
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your question
fields.trailText: My buddy swears that Tony Greig was born in Australia. I maintain that it was South Africa. Who buys dinner? asks Howard Yappett from New Haven, Connecticut, USA
fields.body:
My buddy swears that Tony Greig was born in Australia. I maintain that it was South Africa. Who buys dinner? asks Howard Yappett from New Haven, Connecticut, USA

You can leave your cheque-book at home: Tony Greig was born in Queenstown, South Africa, in 1946. He was a tall (6ft 7ins) gangling allrounder - a hard-hitting batsman and medium-pace bowler who sometimes throttled back and bowled offspin. He played for SA's Border province from 1965-66, then moved to England to join Sussex, for whom he hit 156 in his first Championship match in 1967. He qualified for England (he had British parents), and played 58 successive Tests between his debut in 1972 and 1977. Greig captained England 14 times, but was sacked when it emerged that he was secretly plotting to set up Kerry Packer's World Series Cricket. In Tests he scored 3599 runs at 40.43, with eight centuries, and also took 141 wickets (32.20), including 13 in one match in West Indies in 1974 with that occasional offspin. He was also a fabulous fielder, who took 87 catches in Tests, most of them at second slip. When World Series Cricket started (1977-78) he moved to Australia, and when it stopped he began a long career there as a high-profile commentator for Packer's Channel Nine cricket telecasts, a role in which he remains to this day. His brother Ian also played for Sussex and England, and captained Surrey too.

I wonder if you can help me. I am working in Germany and some workmates were asking me about the laws of cricket. I tried to remember that funny poem which has lots of "outs" and "not-outs" in it. How does it go exactly? asks Tim Pearce

That piece is called "Cricket as explained to a foreign visitor", and goes like this:

"You have two sides - one out in the field and one in. Each man that's in the side that's in goes out and when he's out he comes in and the next man goes in until he's out. When they are all out the side that's out comes in and the side that's been in goes out and tries to get those coming in out. Sometimes you get men still in and not out. When both sides have been in and out, including the not-outs ... That's the end of the game."

It's available on a tea-towel which you can get from the MCC Shop at Lord's

My husband's great-great-great-uncle was John Wisden, who played cricket for Sussex. Is he also the founder of John Wisden & Co.? asks AE Sturrock

He most certainly is. John Wisden was born in Brighton in 1826 and died in London in 1884. In between he had a successful sporting career as a bowler, mainly with Sussex, and started a publishing institution. Although he was on the short side he was a useful fastish inswing bowler, who once took all ten wickets in an innings, for North v South in 1850. That year he founded John Wisden & Co., which made sporting equipment for many years (that side of it was eventually taken over by Gray-Nicolls). In 1864 he branched out by publishing a cricket annual: 137 years later Wisden Cricketers' Almanack is still going, stronger than ever.

What were the exact dates of Brian Lara's 375 against England in Antigua in 1993-94? asks Annemarie Kane

Lara started his record innings early on April 16, 1994. He came in when West Indies were 11 for 1, with Stuart Williams was out: it was soon 12 for 2, when Phil Simmons departed for 8. Lara and Jimmy Adams (59) put on 179, and by the first-day close the score was 274 for 3. Lara had 164 and Keith Arthurton 25. They took their stand to 183 next day, before Arthurton was out for 47. By the end of the second day Lara had made 320 and Shivnarine Chanderpaul 41. After a restless night, Lara came out on April 18 with 46 needed to beat Garry Sobers's old Test record of 365 not out, set in 1957-58. It was nervy stuff, and Lara was stuck fast on 347 for 18 minutes, during which time he played and missed at Angus Fraser and was then nearly yorked by him. "Don't suppose I can call you a lucky bleeder with 347 on he board, can I?" observed the frustrated bowler. Eventually Lara reached 365, to equal the record. Then a swivelling pull off Chris Lewis took him to 369 and a place in the history books. There was a crowd invasion, and a few minutes afterwards Lara was caught behind by Jack Russell off Andy Caddick for 375. In all he batted for 766 minutes, faced 538 balls, and hit 45 fours. West Indies declared at 593 for 5, of which Chanderpaul's share was 75 not out. He and Lara put on 219. England matched West Indies' total exactly, with Mike Atherton making 135 and Robin Smith 175. The match, not surprisingly, was drawn.

Can you tell me something about Geoff Pullar? asks Norman Strange

Geoff Pullar was a stylish left-handed opener who played 28 Tests for England between 1959 and 1962-63, scoring 1974 runs (43.86). He made four Test centuries, the highest of which was 175 against South Africa at The Oval in 1960, when he put on 290 for the first wicket with Colin Cowdrey, who made 155. Pullar suffered a lot with injuries - he hurt his knee in Australia in 1962-63, and never played for England again, then arthritis cut short his first-class career in 1970. He played most of his county cricket for Lancashire (1954-68), although he finished up with Gloucestershire. He was nicknamed "Noddy", because he was reputed to be able to nod off to sleep at any time. After he retired from cricket he moved back to Lancashire and ran a sandwich bar.

Who were West Indies' wicketkeepers between Jeff Dujon and Ridley Jacobs? asks Anil Pandit

Dujon played his last Test in 1991, and since then West Indies have tried out four wicketkeepers without finding anyone who has approached his panache with the bat and behind the stumps. First to try was David Williams, the tiny Trinidadian: he won 11 caps. Although he didn't have much success a batsman, he did play a vital innings of 65 in West Indies' narrow victory over England in the first of the two nailbiting Port-of-Spain Tests early in 1998. Then came Junior Murray, the first Grenadian to play Test cricket (31 caps). There was a brief flirtation with Courtney Browne, the first West Indian Test player to have been born in England (13 caps), then the selectors turned to the Antiguan Ridley Jacobs (21 caps so far). Jimmy Adams, the current captain, also kept wicket in several one-day internationals (but not for any significant length of time in a Test). Jacobs and Browne are the two keepers for the tour of Australia which starts shortly.

Can you tell me the scores from the Nottinghamshire v Surrey county match of 1962? asks Martin Barned

Surrey beat Notts by 156 runs at Trent Bridge in June 1962. Surrey scored 380 for 5 declared and 187 for 2 dec. Notts replied with 224 and 187. It was a good match for Surrey's England players: John Edrich, who was to make his Test debut the following year, scored 216 in the first innings, and Ken Barrington 102 not out in the second. And Tony Lock, the balding left-arm spinner, took 4 for 91 in Notts' first innings and 6 for 45 in the second. The teams also met at The Oval early in August, but that game was a rain-affected draw: Surrey made 233 and Notts 86 for 1.

webTitle: Bulger killers could soon be free

fields.headline: Bulger killers could soon be free
fields.trailText: The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, today cut the minimum sentences to be served by Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the child killers of toddler James Bulger, and effectively granted them their freedom early next  year subject to a parole board decision.
fields.body:
The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, today cut the minimum sentences to be served by Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the child killers of toddler James Bulger, and effectively granted them their freedom early next year subject to a parole board decision.

"I set a tariff that will expire today. This will enable the very difficult task of deciding if and how these young men should return to society to begin," Lord Woolf told the high court in London.

The judge added: "I emphasise that the final decision as to whether they should be released, and conditions of release, are the responsibility of the (parole) board and nothing I have said is to interfere with the board's discretion."

After the judgment, Denise Fergus, mother of the murdered toddler, sank her head and sobbed.

Lord Woolf said: "Because of their behaviour they are entitled to a reduction in the tariff to eight years, which happens to be the figure determined by the trial judge.

"An eight-year tariff would expire on the 21st February 2001. I have already pointed out that it would not be in their or the public's interest for these two young men to be transferred to a young offenders institution.

"In all probability, if the tariff period expired today it is likely that it would be after February 2001 before the parole board could decide whether they should be released and, if so, for the necessary arrangements to be made to enable this to happen."

The ruling meant the boys could soon be freed on parole, Dominic Lloyd, the lawyer representing Robert Thompson, said.

Lord Woolf said the boys had done everything open to them to redeem themselves, although their crime remained "horrendous".

He said of the killers, both ten when they were convicted in 1993: "The one overriding mitigating feature of the offence is the age of the two boys when the crime was committed.

"However grave their crime, the fact remains that if that crime had been committed a few months earlier, when they were under 10, the boys could not have been tried or punished by the courts."

The teenagers are believed to have been told of Lord Woolf's decision shortly before he announced it in public.

Today's decision fell to Lord Woolf after a European Court of Human Rights ruling that judges, not the Home Secretary, should determine jail terms for juvenile killers.

Lord Woolf is to set terms in 140 cases, with today's being the first and most controversial.

His decision came after more than six months' consultation with the relatives of James and the youths' lawyers.

Robert Thompson and Jon Venables were ordered to be detained at Her Majesty's Pleasure at Preston Crown Court in November 1993 for murdering James in February of that year.

They had dumped the child's body on a railway line after abducting him from a shopping centre in Bootle, Merseyside.

The trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, recommended that they serve a minimum of eight years. The then Lord Chief Justice, the late Lord Taylor of Gosforth, increased that to 10.

The tariff was raised again in July 1994 by the then Home Secretary Michael Howard to 15 years but that was quashed by the House of Lords after judicial review proceedings in 1997.

Last December, the European Court of Human Rights ruled that it was wrong to try the pair as adults and wrong for politicians to play a part in sentencing. The current home secretary, Jack Straw, then referred the issue of the minimum tariff.

Lord Woolf decided to announce the tariff in open court today because of the huge public interest in the case.

Denise Fergus and Ralph Bulger, the parents of the murdered two-year-old, were invited to put forward their views before a decision was reached.

Three years ago, Lord Woolf criticised Michael Howard for raising the tariff for the young killers.

Both Robert Thompson and Jon Venables have been held in a local authority secure unit since they were convicted.

Mr Straw has stressed that the tariff set was only a minimum and has insisted neither would be freed until they no longer posed a danger to the public.

webTitle: The cries then screams that led a mother to discover her 14-year-old daughter had CJD

fields.headline: The cries then screams that led a mother to discover her 14-year-old daughter had CJD
fields.standfirst:
Harrowing film shows family's agony over girl's painful death
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: On the eve of today's publication of the report into the BSE fiasco in Britain, the nation was shown harrowing images of a child suffering a slow, painful death from the human form of mad cow disease.
fields.body:
On the eve of today's publication of the report into the BSE fiasco in Britain, the nation was shown harrowing images of a child suffering a slow, painful death from the human form of mad cow disease.

Zoe Jeffries, 14, once a healthy, active child, was pictured lying almost motionless as her mother and sisters attended to her needs at the family home in Wigan, Greater Manchester.

Her mother, Helen, 39, allowed cameras into the house to film her sick daughter, providing the first real glimpse of the devastation vCJD has wreaked on its victims and their families.

In the interview broadcast by Channel 4 News, she described how Zoe had been a popular girl with a passion for sport before showing the first symptoms of the illness two months after her husband died in May 1998.

She said: "One morning she got up and just didn't do anything. She just cried. It was as though she went to bed one person and got up a different person." Zoe cried solidly for two weeks, Mrs Jeffries said, then she began to scream all the time, refusing to leave the house and screaming when she went to school.

Doctors assumed she was suffering a delayed reaction to her father's death. She was prescribed anti-depressants but by the end of the year her mobility was affected.

Mrs Jeffries said: "It was about October when I noticed that she wasn't walking properly. She held her arms out and dragged one foot behind. She kept her balance most of the time but you could tell she was making an effort to do that."

Mrs Jeffries said she had taken Zoe, her eldest child, to a neurologist after waiting three months for an appointment, and the doctor knew almost instantly what was wrong with her.

She said: "You just feel like someone has hit you on the head with a hammer. Zoe was sat outside waiting and I just remember walking out of the room and looking at her and I couldn't tell her. I have never told her since. I didn't really cry - something died inside me and I couldn't cry."

She described how her other children had "sobbed their hearts out" when she broke the tragic news to them.

Mrs Jeffries said that it took until April 1999 for doctors from the CJD Surveillance Unit to officially diagnose her daughter's condition as vCJD.

She told the programme she was angry that help from social services, since Zoe was diagnosed, had been patchy at best and non-existent at worst.

The occupational therapist assigned to Zoe said that the family could not have a stairlift because their stairs were too narrow, and that they could not have an extension to the house "because she wouldn't live long enough".

"It's more than anyone can cope with. We had to fight for everything - even incontinence pads I had to go to my MP for," said Mrs Jeffries. "We shouldn't have to do all that."

Zoe's breathing now stops on occasions and she has to be given emergency oxygen to keep her alive.

Her mother said: "I don't know if it's the right thing to do _ I hope that when the time comes I can say 'leave her be'. I'm not sure I can do it but I'm going to have to, for her."

Mrs Jeffries said that she wanted the BSE report to name those to blame in the crisis, adding: "It's just as if someone had stuck a knife in Zoe's body - I really do think she has been murdered. If she were a cow and I was a farmer then we would get everything I needed."

fields.headline: Respecting our fears
fields.standfirst:
The lesson of the BSE fiasco is that the authorities should be open about their uncertainties and let consumers decide for themselves

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The lesson of the BSE fiasco is that the authorities should be open about their uncertainties and let consumers decide for themselves, says Anna Bradley.
fields.body:
Today's launch of the BSE report rekindles the debate about how our society should balance choice and risk. I believe the right way to protect the public in the face of a potentially serious but as yet unknown risk such as BSE, GM foods or the radiation caused by mobile telephones is by the judicious use of the precautionary principle, sometimes paraphrased as "better safe than sorry".

Steps should always be talen to avoid the legacy of irreversible harm. When a threat is hard to assess by conventional "probabilistic" risk assessment methods, it is better to do something than to do nothing. Later, when the risk is better known, precautions can be scaled down.

These can range from suppression of a product (as in the EU's ban on artificial use of beef hormones) to restriction of use (antibiotics for animals) and advice (use of mobile telephones by children). This approach does not mean that all innovation should be stopped or slowed the minute risk rears its head. Consumers cannot be 100% protected until all risks are known. Consumers want the benefit of new technologies and sometimes we want the right to take risks.

Preventative measures sometimes have costs which we consider unacceptable: for example a mass ban on mobile telephones. To serve consumers well, policymakers need to make a political judgment in the round, balancing the dangers of over-reaction to false reassurance and examining the costs and benefits of both doing something and doing nothing.

The story told in the BSE report shows how the precautionary principle could have been applied. The government ignored warnings issued as early as 1979: subsequent delays and mixed messages compounded public fear, eroding trust in government, farming and the food industry. Officials and ministers are criticised for "cherry-picking" good news, ignoring scientific caveats and growing doubts, because of political pressure to produce success stories.

The precautionary principle was eventually applied, but too flabbily and too late. For example, beef offal was banned from babyfood in February 1988, but BSE did not become a notifiable disease until June, four months later. And the government did not introduce a ban on specified bovine offal material for human consumption until November 1989. Later, a failure to give farmers 100% compensation for cattle killed in a compulsory slaughter scheme ended up being an incentive for concealment. When the link between BSE and the human variant, nvCJD was confirmed in March 1996, the government's inconsistency and delays became obvious.

The chief problem was that public statements appeared to be founded on certainty - that beef was safe to eat - but they were accompanied by an acknowledgement of uncertainty. The precautionary principle, properly applied, avoids this pitfall by recognising the limits of knowledge in situations where public health may be under threat. Uncertainty and ignorance are part of the normal spectrum of scientific data and policy-makers should accept that there is no shame in saying: "We don't know."

Indeed, it may be the proper thing to do. It is hard to quantify the potential value of the principle, compared to conventional risk assessment, precisely because it is best applied in cases where the risks are unknown. It may be possible to apply actuarial rules to calculate the value on each individual life lost through CJD, but no one yet knows the total likely number of casual ties or the timescale over which that will unfold. Nor can one ever calculate how many people might have died from CJD if the government had not eventually taken precautions at a cost of £4bn, or if the money would have saved more lives if it had been spent differently - on heating insulation for the elderly, for example.

The main argument against the precautionary principle is that it is not scientific. A fierce professional debate is raging in which risk assessors warn against the use of "precaution" to "trump science". My view is that a dual approach is best, and that the precautionary principle is entirely compatible with scientific principles. It applies precisely when risk assessment reaches its limits.

Consumers are often accused of being irrational and inconsistent about risk: large numbers of people happily drive at high speeds despite a road death toll which dwarfs the total number of all deaths from CJD, recorded over a 10-year period. However, consumers make subtle risk calculations every day of the week. It is scientists and policymakers who should understand consumers better, rather than the other way round. It is after all, consumer trust which so badly needs rebuilding.

Inconsistencies in public attitudes should be seen as inevitable, rather than neurotic. Consumer reaction is coloured by the fact that the risks, real or perceived, are seen as being unnecessary, because the products could be avoided by consumers if sufficient information were given. What angered consumers about BSE was the idea that a risk was being "foisted" on them unnecessarily and dishonestly.

The public has the right to know the scientific basis and the political justification for a risk decision. Science cannot give us all the answers to the issues raised with new technologies. Acknowledging the limits of knowledge should be seen as a strength and will allow us to adopt a level of precaution that will properly protect public health.

 Anna Bradley is director of the National Consumer Council.

Officials and ministers are criticised for "cherry-picking" good news, ignoring scientific caveats and growing doubts, because of political pressure to produce success stories. The precautionary principle was eventually applied, but too flabbily and too late. For example, beef offal was banned from babyfood in February 1988, but BSE did not become a notifiable disease until June, four months later. And the government did not introduce a ban on specified bovine offal material for human consumption until November 1989. Later, a failure to give farmers 100% compensation for cattle killed in a compulsory slaughter scheme ended up being an incentive for concealment. When the link between BSE and the human variant, nvCJD was confirmed in March 1996, the government's inconsistency and delays became obvious. The chief problem was that public statements appeared to be founded on certainty - that beef was safe to eat - but they were accompanied by an acknowledgement of uncertainty. The precautionary principle, properly applied, avoids this pitfall by recognising the limits of knowledge in situations where public health may be under threat. Uncertainty and ignorance are part of the normal spectrum of scientific data and policy-makers should accept that there is no shame in saying: "We don't know." Indeed, it may be the proper thing to do. It is hard to quantify the potential value of the principle, compared to conventional risk assessment, precisely because it is best applied in cases where the risks are unknown. It may be possible to apply actuarial rules to calculate the value on each individual life lost through CJD, but no one yet knows the total likely number of casual ties or the timescale over which that will unfold. Nor can one ever calculate how many people might have died from CJD if the government had not eventually taken precautions at a cost of £4bn, or if the money would have saved more lives if it had been spent differently - on heating insulation for the elderly, for example. The main argument against the precautionary principle is that it is not scientific. A fierce professional debate is raging in which risk assessors warn against the use of "precaution" to "trump science". My view is that a dual approach is best, and that the precautionary principle is entirely compatible with scientific principles. It applies precisely when risk assessment reaches its limits. Consumers are often accused of being irrational and inconsistent about risk: large numbers of people happily drive at high speeds despite a road death toll which dwarfs the total number of all deaths from CJD, recorded over a 10-year period. However, consumers make subtle risk calculations every day of the week. It is scientists and policymakers who should understand consumers better, rather than the other way round. It is after all, consumer trust which so badly needs rebuilding. Inconsistencies in public attitudes should be seen as inevitable, rather than neurotic. Consumer reaction is coloured by the fact that the risks, real or perceived, are seen as being unnecessary, because the products could be avoided by consumers if sufficient information were given. What angered consumers about BSE was the idea that a risk was being "foisted" on them unnecessarily and dishonestly. The public has the right to know the scientific basis and the political justification for a risk decision. Science cannot give us all the answers to the issues raised with new technologies. Acknowledging the limits of knowledge should be seen as a strength and will allow us to adopt a level of precaution that will properly protect public health.  Anna Bradley is director of the National Consumer Council. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Former ministers targeted in BSE report

fields.headline: Former ministers targeted in BSE report
fields.trailText: Senior politicians are expected to be accused of a "public betrayal" over their handling of the BSE crisis in a report published today.
fields.body:
Senior politicians are expected to be accused of a "public betrayal" over their handling of the BSE crisis in a report published today.

It accuses civil servants and politicians, including former Tory agriculture minister John Gummer, of failing to heed scientists' warnings over BSE. The report says they did not act quickly enough when evidence started to emerge that humans were being infected.

"This is the core criticism that involves everyone from the cabinet down," said one government source. "It is clear he (inquiry chairman Lord Phillips) regards it as an act of public betrayal."

Families of some of the 84 victims human form of the disease - vCJD - will gather in a London conference centre this morning hoping to get some answers about why their loved ones died.

The 16-volume report follows a £27 million inquiry that has spanned the past two and a half years.

It focuses on government failures to enforce abattoir controls which were designed to ensure that any potentially BSE-infected beef was removed from the food chain.

The publication came as a consumer group warned that there were still "uncertainties" over controls aimed at preventing transmission of the infection to humans.

The Consumers' Association (CA) said today that the crisis was still not over and said there were doubts that safety controls were adequate.

Sheila McKechnie, director of the CA, said: "The crisis is by no means over.

"Many questions still remain. What will the real toll be? "And are there adequate measures in place to deal with them? The disease is in the human population and we need to take steps now to prevent its spread."

Clinical signs of BSE were first detected in 1985 and the disease was officially recognised in 1986. Almost from the outset there were fears, expressed loudly in the media, of a threat to human health.

Despite the government controls, recorded cases of BSE rose through the 1990s, reaching 100,000 in July 1993. Between November 1986 and November 1985, a total of 154,592 cases were confirmed on 32,906 UK farms.

On May 21 1995, a 19-year-old called Stephen Churchill died in hospital after suffering a terrible illness that caused him to hallucinate, become mentally confused, and lose control of his movements. He was later diagnosed as the first known victim of a completely new form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease that had never been seen before. Two other young people died the same year from what came to be called variant CJD, or vCJD.

A year later, scientists confirmed ministers' worst fears, that the most likely cause of vCJD was BSE, also known as "mad cow disease". It is thought to have appeared as a result of cattle being given feed containing both the remains of sheep infected with scrapie, and other cattle.

webTitle: Defence boost as Labour bids to hold seats

fields.headline: Defence boost as Labour bids to hold seats
fields.standfirst:
'X-rated Hague' warning in run-up to four polls
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government will today announce defence orders worth millions of pounds as it gears up to defend Labour majorities in four byelections, probably on December 7.
fields.body:
The government will today announce defence orders worth millions of pounds as it gears up to defend Labour majorities in four byelections, probably on December 7.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, will award long awaited orders for four roll-on/roll-off military ferries to the Maersk yard on Merseyside, but he is also expected to steer a troop carrier order to the Govan yard in Glasgow, some of whose workforce live in the late Donald Dewar's Anniesland constituency.

The popular Scottish first minister had a majority of 15,154 in 1997. But the four-party system in Scotland is highly volatile and the Scottish nationalists will try hard for an upset. They come second in what is mostly a deprived constituency in west Glasgow.

As Labour HQ in Millbank plans its defence Tony Blair yesterday used the weekly meeting of Labour backbenchers to urge them to campaign on four key themes against what he called the "X-rated fantasy film" of a Hague government. In a pep talk at Westminster Mr Blair cited economic stability, public investment rather than Tory cuts, help for the most vulnerable whom the Tories would abandon and leadership in Europe. Not all his listeners feel that is enough to get their core voters out.

Potentially riskier for Labour in Scotland is Falkirk West, where the maverick leftwinger, Dennis Canavan, who was expelled after standing for the Scottish parliament as an independent socialist, has said he will resign the seat shortly. He had a majority of 13,783 which would take an 18% swing to shift.

The timing of the byelection would be in Labour's hands as would those in Preston where Mark Hendrick, the late Audrey Wise's successor as Labour candidate, was picked this week. Mrs Wise's 18,680 majority would need a 19% swing to fall.

Far riskier is Betty Boothroyd's seat at West Bromwich West which was not contested by the main parties in 1997 because she was Speaker. In 1992, her majority was 6,174 over the Tories in this old industrial seat, vulnerable to a 6.6% swing in theory.

Three local councillors had already been picked to fight the contest before she formally resigned on Monday. Labour will hold all four contests together, but Scottish considerations may be uppermost in the minds of business managers. If they say so, the polling date may be changed.

The four MoD "ro-ro" ferries have been a big prize for months and today's decision will give no comfort to yards on the Tyne, especially since the smaller troop carrier order should tide Govan on the Clyde over until Type 45 warship orders can be placed.

Mr Blair predicted yesterday that once campaigning began in earnest on the "big issues", the Conservatives will look vulnerable and the government strong. MPs must stress constant explanation of Labour's record "on these real choices".

With a general election expected in May and Labour's Commons majority impregnable the prime minister wants his troops out campaigning vigorously now.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 27.
fields.trailText: October 27: The forthcoming broadcasting white paper will recommend the abolition of the 15% limit on viewing share for broadcasters.
fields.body:
Broadcast reports that the forthcoming broadcasting white paper will recommend the abolition of the 15% limit on viewing share for broadcasters.

BBC2 controller Jane Root is to axe Modern Times after its next run in the new year to make way for a more flexible documentary strand with more room for historical documentaries.

Brookside and Hollyoaks creator Phil Redmond has warned independent producers that in selling their companies they could be "selling their birthright" because they don't yet know the value of their intellectual property in the online age.

Journalist and TV chef Nigella Lawson is setting up her own production company, MYC, to produce the second series of Nigella Bites for Channel 4.

And Big Brother winner Craig Phillips is to get his own regional DIY show, Renovation Street, in the new year.

webTitle: Comment: Former footballer new Scottish first minister

fields.headline: The invisible man
fields.standfirst:
Scotland's new first minister, Henry McLeish, is going to have a hard time holding on to power
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Today the Scottish parliament will formally elect a former professional footballer as the second first minister since devolution. Henry McLeish's brief spell with East Fife is always mentioned in profiles. It is one of the few immediately interesting things about this 52-year-old man.
fields.body:
Today the Scottish parliament will formally elect a former professional footballer as the second first minister since devolution. Henry McLeish's brief spell with East Fife is always mentioned in profiles. It is one of the few immediately interesting things about this 52-year-old man.

The late Donald Dewar did not want Henry McLeish to succeed him. He told the world that, when he brutally snubbed Mr McLeish's suggestion that he should become deputy leader of the Scottish Labour party.

In private Dewar went further. Just weeks before his death, he reminded me of an incident which, he implied, underlined Mr McLeish's unsuitability for leadership. The occasion was the closure of a tyre factory outside Edinburgh. The Scotsman newspaper had given the Scottish executive a roasting after the factory owners leaked suggestions that they had not received government support they thought they had been promised. The executive said little in its own defence.

I had to call Mr Dewar to ask him to explain the silence. Mr McLeish was responsible as the enterprise minister. But I explained that Henry McLeish was not available for comment. He had gone on a private lecture tour to the United States.

It seemed strange that a minister with a crisis on his patch had disappeared from view - (stranger still that the Scotsman's then political editor, now widely expected to become Mr McLeish's official spokesman, worked hard to keep the absence secret).

When we last spoke, Mr Dewar reminded me of that incident. His concern was Henry's habit of crouching behind the parapet when controversy approached.

Mr McLeish has never served in cabinet. If he has any of the intellectual energy or passion of his predecessor he has kept it hidden. As Senator Lloyd Bensen might have put it: "I knew Donald Dewar. I worked with Donald Dewar. Donald Dewar was a friend of mine. Mr McLeish, you are no Donald Dewar."

Formal parliamentary endorsement of Mr McLeish's new status is a legal requirement. The Scotland Act obliges MSPs to elect a new first minister within 28 days of the departure of his predecessor. If they don't, a general election is called.

So, having won the leadership of his party in an emergency contest against finance minister Jack McConnell, Mr McLeish can be confident that he will be anointed. He and his new wife are looking forward to moving in to their elegant official residence in Edinburgh.

From that moment on, things will get difficult for the man the Daily Record in Scotland has dubbed King Henry. He is the leader nobody wanted.

Mr McLeish was nearly beaten on Saturday. Among the Labour backbenchers whose votes were not mandated by the occupants of Numbers 10 and 11 Downing Street, he was comprehensively beaten. He squeaked through on the payroll vote. Cynics suggest this is why the Scottish executive has three times as many ministerial positions as it needs.

Mr McLeish faces two immediate problems. His backbenchers voted for his opponent. His ministers only supported him out of resid ual loyalty to London. Henry McLeish has a lot to prove. His response to his wafer-thin win was to make quasi-nationalist comments, transparently crafted to woo the very backbenchers who voted for his opponent.

This is alarming. His election must be endorsed in December by a proper ballot of Labour's electoral college. A deputy leader will be elected simultaneously. It is plain that a deputy elected by the proper procedure will have at least as much authority as a leader who was not.

McLeish was protected from defeat this time around because that is what London wanted. The parallels with Labour's Welsh debacle are being discussed.

Mr McLeish is indelibly marked as Gordon Brown's man. If his response is to be more nationalist than thou, London may abandon him. That becomes more likely if he fails to set an ambitious agenda. The incompetence, caution and sloth which has characterised devolution so far was only tolerated because Donald Dewar was a towering figure. Henry McLeish lacks that status and has little time to build it.

He will have to make hard decisions fast. The devolution project is threatened by public disappointment and nationalist advance. If Mr McLeish cannot unite his own party and defeat the SNP in the looming byelections, the second first minister could soon be replaced by a third.

There are brighter ministers serving in the executive. Wendy Alexander and Susan Deacon can both point to accomplishments considerably more solid than those of Mr McLeish.

Scotland has not yet approached the point when the fairer sex could anticipate justice in politics. But there are still some radicals who suspect that an Alexander/Deacon leadership might be four times as dynamic as the rule of the invisible man.

Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman. Between 1985-88, he worked as research assistant and press officer to the late Donald Dewar.

webTitle: Note reveals 23 survived initial Kursk blast

fields.headline: Note reveals 23 survived initial Kursk blast
fields.trailText: A note that was found on one of four bodies raised from the sunken Russian nuclear submarine Kursk, revealed today that at least 23 people remained alive after powerful explosions killed most of the crew.
fields.body:
A note that was found on one of four bodies raised from the sunken Russian nuclear submarine Kursk, revealed today that at least 23 people remained alive after powerful explosions killed most of the crew.

The report, from the ITAR-Tass new agency, was the first sign that anyone had survived the initial blasts that tore apart the submarine and sunk it in the Barents Sea on 12 August.

The note did not indicate any cause of the catastrophe.

Russian navy chief Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov quoted from the note, which was found in the pocket of a seaman who was identified only as Lieutenant DR Kolesnikov.

"All the crew from the sixth, seventh and eighth compartments went over to the ninth. There are 23 people here. We made this decision as a result of the accident. None of us can get to the surface," Admiral Kuroyedov read.

"The note went on to mention the figures 13 and five and then added 'I am writing blindly'," the admiral told families of the crew, who were gathered in the northern Russian port of Murmansk.

Many Russian officials had suggested that some crew members could have remained alive after the disaster, as indicated by reports of tapping sounds which were detected from the submarine in the first days.

But others discounted the reports as unsubstantiated and said that the sounds could have been caused by collapsing equipment or the submarine settling into the seabed.

The note may indicate that the survivors of the initial explosions died of drowning, hypothermia or high pressure.

Russian and Norwegian divers have recovered four bodies after five days of painstaking work to cut holes in the top of the submarine.

The complex underwater operation is being performed with leading-edge diving equipment, including robots and mechanical arms. Divers used an instrument that sprays pressurised water mixed with diamond dust to cut the Kursk's two-inch thick inner steel hull.

Officials say that up to two-thirds of the crew were probably blown to dust by powerful explosions in the weapons room in the submarine's bow.

Admiral Kuroyedov had warned that he might cancel the recovery effort if experts said that divers' life was in danger.

Two widows of the Kursk crew members visited the Regalia yesterday and, on behalf of all the families, pleaded with the divers not to take excessive risks.

But Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, had promised to recover the bodies at an emotional meeting with the crew's relatives shortly after the disaster, and the government seems determined to conduct the costly effort despite the shortage of funds for the military.

Some Russian media have pointed out that, by stubbornly continuing this risky policy, the government wants to vindicate its confused response to the sinking of the Kursk, when it resisted foreign help for days while botching its own rescue efforts.

The cause of the disaster remains unknown, with authorities pointing at a collision with a Western submarine, second world war mine or an internal malfunction as possible reasons.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip puts a wager on itself to become Speaker of the House of Commons. And guess what? It pays off!
fields.trailText: Arsenal will make a move for Crystal Palace midfielder Hayden Mullins, according to the Sun, after the 21-year-old was put on the transfer list by manager Alan Smith. Mullins, along with fellow youngsters Clinton Morrison and Jamie Smith, are all up for sale after Smith claimed: "There are people at this club who are not showing the right attitude and I won't put up with it any longer." The Sun says that Arsene Wenger has already had a £1.5m offer for Mullins rejected.
fields.body:
Arsenal will make a move for Crystal Palace midfielder Hayden Mullins, according to the Sun, after the 21-year-old was put on the transfer list by manager Alan Smith. Mullins, along with fellow youngsters Clinton Morrison and Jamie Smith, are all up for sale after Smith claimed: "There are people at this club who are not showing the right attitude and I won't put up with it any longer." The Sun says that Arsene Wenger has already had a £1.5m offer for Mullins rejected.

Steve McManaman has told Spanish journalists that he will not be leaving Real Madrid for Rangers. The England man, who made an appearance as a substitute in Real's 4-0 Champions League win over Sporting Lisbon last night, will continue to fight for his place at the Bernabeu. Real's sporting director, Jorge Valdano, claims there has not been any official contact from the Glasgow giants. "If there is interest, and the player authorises it, we will speak with the Scottish club," Valdano said. "But only if McManaman authorises us to do so."

The Daily Express says that Chelsea have put their teenage Finnish striker Mikael Forsell up for sale. Forsell, who has made only 15 appearances for the club, would cost £3m. According to the Express, German side Bayer Leverkusen have already declared an interest.

webTitle: Anne Frank rights snapped up by Fox

fields.headline: Anne Frank rights snapped up by Fox
fields.trailText: Anne Frank rights snapped up by Fox
fields.body:
Fox Studios have ended Tinseltown's long fight to remake The Diary of Anne Frank , after landing the rights from the Switzerland-based copyright holders Anne Frank Fonds.

Oscar-winning Driving Miss Daisy scriptwriter Alfred Uhry will script the adaptation, using prose from the actual diary.

"The vision of the project", says Fox president Elisabeth Gabler, "is to portray [her] not as a saintly child, but a real girl who came of age during horrific circumstances. It's a compelling way to tell her story, particularly with Alfred, who took his granddaughter to the actual house when doing his research and experienced those things with her. Directors have already shown interest".

One obvious director who won't be involved is Steven Spielberg , whose DreamWorks studio have dropped out of an ABC TV serial based on the famed Holocaust memoir.

Spielberg was reported to be troubled by the Frank estate's long-term reluctance to engage with Hollywood - members of Anne's family even wrote to the Schindler's List helmer to discourage him from working on the series.

webTitle: Day-Lewis gets stuck into meaty role for Scorsese

fields.headline: Day-Lewis gets stuck into meaty role for Scorsese
fields.trailText: Daniel Day-Lewis is working in a London butcher's shop to prepare for his role in the Martin Scorsese flick Gangs of New York
fields.body:
Daniel Day-Lewis is working in a London butcher's shop to prepare for his role in the Martin Scorsese flick Gangs of New York.

The obsessive actor is clocking several hours a day in W Head and Co, practising his chopping and carving skills in rehearsal for his part as Bill "The Butcher" Poole in the movie, toplined by Leonardo DiCaprio. The starstruck butcher in question has been prevented by Miramax from talking to the press.

Day-Lewis is notorious for his maniacally in-depth role preparation. He gave himself a hernia getting into shape for Jim Sheridan's The Boxer, having spent two years training with Ireland's featherweight boxing champ.

For Last of the Mohicans, he spent five months carrying a primitive flint rifle, and for Nicholas Hytner's The Crucible, he passed several weeks tilling fields with 17th-century tools. On the set of My Left Foot, in which he played the paralysed Christy Brown, Day-Lewis never walked once.

"I find it helpful", the actor once commented, "to create the illusion, or delusion, whichever way you look at it, of occupying someone else's shoes in my work. That's where I find pleasure. I love it when people feel that another life has been told them and it's not recognisably one's own. But I've never achieved any explanation that made any sense".

Gangs of New York, which also stars Cameron Diaz, is to be released in autumn 2001.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Pilot error

The pursuit of wealth is more stressful than poverty, judging by recent surveys. So what a happy thing it is that you can now buy peace of mind with those riches. Indeed, high-street electrical stores are said to make more from marketing this precious commodity than from their sales of merchandise. No sooner have you spied a gadget and succumbed to the salesman's list of its life-enhancing virtues, then he will predict the havoc that it could cause you if you don't spend half as much again on a warranty. But of what value is such a thing, except to said salesman who gets to pocket a commission? Tracey Bowen of London paid £47 for Dixon's Coverplan policy to protect her new Palm Pilot. When a fault developed Coverplan airily told her to contact the manufacturer's helpline since her policy did not cover Palms. This proved useless and 10 calls and 10 days later no one at Coverplan was able to tell her how else to proceed. Eventually, through her own efforts, she got Palm to dispatch a replacement machine from France, but eight letters to Dixons requesting a refund of her policy fee have gone unanswered.

Dixons says that it always arranges for items to be repaired if a fault develops within the first year, but that "in certain circumstances, depending on our contractual relationship with the supplier or the type of item, we will advise the customer to contact the repair centre direct". This interesting interpretation of the consumer law is apparently for the sole benefit of the customer who will find the repair process "speeded up" if they do all the donkey work themselves. In Bowen's case, Dixons apologises for an "unacceptable" delay in processing the repair, but insists that since her Palm was neither stolen nor accidentally damaged it was not covered by her insurance plan. It is, however, prepared at last to refund the price of the policy.

Laptop goes Awol

Initially Tom Greatrex, also of London, had better luck with his laptop purchased from PC World, which is part of the Dixons Group. Interestingly, he went straight to the manufacturer who explained that it's the retailer who is supposed to honour its guarantees. The machine was duly collected for repair by Dixons contractor Mastercare, then weeks went by without sight of it. Mastercare insisted that it had been delivered to his office and signed for. A copy of the delivery note was faxed, but, according to Greatrex, the signature did not belong to any of his colleagues and there was no delivery address on the card. "All Dixons have suggested is that I report the 'theft' to the police," says Greatrex, "but as far as I'm concerned it was never delivered here."

Dixons press office has recently developed an energy that its customer services would do well to emulate. Within an hour of Consumer's call, it announces that Greatrex will receive a new laptop. "We're not quite sure what went wrong," says a spokesman.

Left out in the cold

P Waite of Twickenham didn't have the chance to test out her warranty, because her fridge/freezer, ordered from another Dixons Group store, Currys, never arrived. She had chosen Currys because it promised next-day delivery and the removal of her old appliance, provided it was defrosted. Mastercare rang to confirm the deliv ery the following afternoon, so Waite defrosted her fridge/freezer. On the day, however, Mastercare rang back to say it didn't have the model in stock. Another date was arranged but no one came. Mastercare blamed Currys and Currys blamed Mastercare but neither could specify a new delivery date. In the meantime Waites reckons she's lost £150 worth of spoiled food.

Sorry, sorry, sorry, says our friendly Dixons press office. "Unfortunately, around the time that Ms Waite bought her fridge/freezer the manufacturer discontinued the item and the store was unaware of this." At what point they would have become aware of it is anybody's guess because no one updated Waites. Customer services, its arm twisted by the press office, is now offering her an upgraded model for the same price, another model of her choice or a refund plus £150 compensation.

Virgin's unfair fares

Enraged splutterings have greeted Virgin Trains' comments on why it has withdrawn its budget tickets from numerous "commuter" trains. "They say that leisure travellers would crowd out those who need to get to work," bellows John Preston of Birmingham. "How offensive can you get? What about the disabled, those who are ill and cannot work, those who have spent a lifetime working and now have to exist on the pittance of a pension? It's corporate speak for if you cannot pay you are second-class citizens who will be catered for after the fat cats have been fed." Peter Hewis, who subsists on a clergy stipend, finds that saver fares he's paid for 28 years have now been withdrawn from the Nuneaton to Euston route. "My answer is to insist that Richard Branson be made to live on average earnings and use his own trains for travelling off peak."

webTitle: Daldry eyes up second project as Billy Elliot reaps first rewards

fields.headline: Daldry eyes up second project as Billy Elliot reaps first rewards
fields.trailText: Daldry eyes up second project as Billy Elliot reaps first rewards
fields.body:
The first-time director of surprise British smash Billy Elliott is in talks to direct an adaptation of the Pulitzer
Prize-winning novel The Hours for Paramount, reports trade paper Variety.

Stephen Daldry's likely second film has been scripted by his long-time theatre collaborator, playwright David Hare, and may star Nicole Kidman, Meryl Streep and Julianne Moore.

The novel, by Michael Cunningham, is a homage to the Bloomsbury writer
Virginia Woolf, and tells the story of three women living in different periods of the 20th century.

One is Woolf, at work on her novel Mrs Dalloway in 1923; the second is an LA housewife in the late 40s; the last is a young woman in 1990s New York, planning a party for an Aids-suffering former lover who called her "Mrs Dalloway".

Daldry is suddenly hot property in movieland, after Billy Elliott rocketed to the top of the UK box office chart. It looks set to take the States by storm, and Oscars look increasingly possible.

The film accrued its first official accolades last night in London, winning four honours at the British Independent Film Awards: best British independent film, best screenplay, best director category and best newcomer, for 14-year-old star Jamie Bell.

The awards mark the culmination of the Raindance Independent Film Festival. Collecting the gongs, director Daldry said: "it's still a total joy that people are enjoying the film - that's a total surprise".

Other awards went to Gillian Anderson (Best Actress - House of Mirth), Daniel Craig (Best Actor - Some Voices), One Day in September (Best Documentary) and to Kadosh and The Straight Story for Best Foreign Films.

fields.headline: Barclay brothers withdraw Express bid
fields.standfirst: Hinduja brothers firm up Express offer
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: The Barclay brothers' decision to withdraw their offer for Express newspapers has been blamed on United News & Media's failure to produce financial information. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Barclay brothers' dramatic decision to withdraw their offer for the Express newspaper group has been blamed on United News & Media's failure to produce financial information on the papers.

The move is understood to reflect the brothers' concern that their bid - believed to be worth £75-£100m - was not being taken seriously.

A source close to the brothers said: "They felt Lord Hollick was putting their very substantial bid in his back pocket while he waited for something better to come along. They feel this has not been dealt with in the proper manner.

"This move reflects their frustration and amazement at what they regard as very bad business practice. What they were asking for is normal commercial practice."

In a statement issued today, the brothers' company, Press Holdings, said it made its offer on September 18 and, once it had been rejected, requested financial information about the group in order to consider what further action to take.

It continued: "So far this request has been ignored. In the circumstances and in order to prevent further speculation, Press Holdings has no alternative but to withdraw its interest in the Express newspaper group and to consider the matter closed."

Colleagues of Lord Hollick today said they were baffled by the Barclay brothers' statement.

"To say we have kept the bid in the back pocket is pretty heavy. How can we respond to something that we have already rejected?" said one executive.

Company sources said they had rejected the Barclays' bid on September 19 and insisted that no subsequent talks had been held between the two parties.

The Barclays are not the first party to have expressed frustration over United News & Media's response to enquiries.

Statements from United in the aftermath of the takeover of its television franchises by Granada Media proved contradictory.

At first the company moved to quash rumours that Lord Hollick was considering selling the newspaper division.

But after repeated reports of approaches from the Barclays and others, Lord Hollick was forced to admit to staff in an e-mail that he was considering offers from several bidders.

The Barclays' withdrawal paves the way for a two-way battle between former Mirror chief executive David Montgomery and the Hinduja Group, an Indian conglomerate that has tabled a bid in the region of £100m.

A United spokesman denied it had been dithering. "We have been fairly straight and consistent," he said .

webTitle: Smith hits back at Mugabe in Zimbabwe's war of words

fields.headline: Smith hits back at Mugabe in Zimbabwe's war of words
fields.trailText: Ian Smith, the former white minority leader of Zimbabwe, said today that he would welcome the opportunity to stand trial in the country.
fields.body:
Ian Smith, the former white minority leader of Zimbabwe, said today that he would welcome the opportunity to stand trial in the country.

Mr Smith, who is in Britain for a visit to the Oxford Union, said that he would use any judicial action as a platform to denounce President Robert Mugabe to the world as a "gangster", adding that "our country is in total anarchy."

He also claimed that he had more right than Mr Mugabe to be in Zimbabwe, which he ruled for 14 years as Rhodesia, after whites declared independence from Britain in 1965 rather than accept black rule.

His comments came a day after Mr Mugabe told supporters of his ruling ZANU-PF party that he intended to revoke the policy of national racial reconciliation, which was put into place when the country achieved independence in 1980.

In comments that were aired on state television, the president went on to announce that "Ian Smith and the whites who participated in the massacre and genocide of our people, those who fought against us we shall try."

"After all, in Europe they are still hunting the Nazis, those who fought on the side of Hitler. We will look for those who fought on the side of Ian Smith, where ever they are. If they are still in this country, then they must be arrested."

However, some experts voiced the view that Mr Mugabe's threat to arrest Mr Smith and other whites would not stand up in court because of the amnesties that were granted to both sides after the liberation war.

Mr Mugabe's comments came just hours after the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) launched unprecedented impeachment proceedings yesterday.

They cited the economic crisis that sparked food-price riots last week, and government plans to confiscate white-owned farms for black resettlement.

Mr Mugabe has accused whites in Britain and the US of trying to destabilise the country. He has also stated that Zimbabwe's own white community is primarily responsible for providing much of the money to fund the MDC, which won 57 of 150 parliamentary seats in June's election, a result that poses the strongest challenge to his two-decade rule.

As the battle of words hotted up, neighbouring South African saw the rand fall to within sight of a record low this morning. The weakness of the euro was blamed in some quarters, but the political crisis in Zimbabwe has also made the money markets jittery.

In an effort to stop worries that the trouble could spread into South Africa, President Thabo Mbeki used a speech last night to roundly condemn the violent land grabbing that has taken place in Zimbabwe.

fields.headline: Labour of love
fields.standfirst: When  Kate Figes wrote critically about the natural childbirth movement in this newspaper earlier this year she was engulfed in a storm of outrage. So what would happen when she met Sheila Kitzinger, the high priestess of the crusade against medical birth?
fields.trailText: When Kate Figes wrote critically about the natural childbirth movement in this newspaper earlier this year she was engulfed in a storm of outrage. So what would happen when she met Sheila Kitzinger, the high priestess of the crusade against medical birth?
fields.body:
I have to confess to feeling more than a little trepidation at the prospect of interviewing Sheila Kitzinger. She is unequivocally the high priestess of natural childbirth, a household name whose numerous books are hungrily consumed by expectant parents. She has done more to change attitudes to childbirth in the past 40 years than anyone else, conducting a relentless crusade against the medicalisation of childbirth and the detrimental way in which the hands-on experience of midwives has been subjugated to the greater pathological experience of obstetrician.

I, meanwhile, earned the unenviable status of Public Enemy Number One in the eyes of the natural birth movement after writing an article earlier this year for this newspaper. In it I dared to put into print criticisms that countless parents feel once the reality of labour and new parenthood fails to match up to the natural birth ideal. I could barely believe the heated passion of some of the responses. Alongside phone calls and letters of support, I got hate mail, while the National Childbirth Trust (NCT) website appeared to talk of little else for months, with some members taking it very personally and demanding that I be sent on an NCT training course to be "put right". Now, I prepared to enter the laird of the queen bee herself, complete with birthing stools as coffee tables and batiks of birth symbols lining the walls. Would I emerge alive?

Kitzinger shot to prominence in 1962 with the publication of The Experience of Childbirth. The medicalisation of childbirth was at its peak in the late 1950s and Kitzinger's message - that birth was a powerful and exhilarating psychosocial, even sexual event where women needed to retain control - struck a chord with countless parents. There's no doubting her impact: as a result of her efforts, doctors now at least question the need for routine enemas, shaving and episiotomies and accept that the missionary position may not be the best one for giving birth.

But the flip side of this revolution has also been damaging. Childbirth is now more politicised than at any point in its history. Women are caught between two polarised stools of high-tech, medicalised birth and natural childbirth. Two surveys published in the past week alone illustrate the opposite ends of the debate. One based on a small sample found that babies born to mothers under the influence of Pethidine were at a slightly higher risk of becoming drug addicts as adults. The other found that mortality and morbidity rates for breech babies were reduced if they were delivered by caesarean section. The first seemed to strike a blow for natural childbirth, the second to push women further into the arms of the doctors.

Kitzinger, 71, is a likeable woman - funny, intelligent, warm and keenly alert and youthful. She is also that rare thing in the modern western world, a genuine feminist social revolutionary. "We are there, marching. You've got to change the system, you've got to change society, you need revolution!" she exhorts with a large laugh, her fists in the air.
