She has been hurt by accusations from journalists who have blamed her for their own difficulties with childbirth and breastfeeding. "I pretend that it doesn't, but of course it hurts. I thoroughly enjoyed labour and everything I am doing and have always done in childbirth has to do with that joy. But I meet many women who have had terrible experiences, who are deeply traumatised by their birth experiences and I have to take that on board. I must confess that I find depression very difficult to cope with in anybody else because I've never been depressed."

Unlike many in the natural birth movement, she supports women who choose to have an elective caesarean and accepts that some women "feel deceived, cheated by their experience of birth. The NCT teachers would say we don't just teach for women who want drug-free births and that's true, but their whole raison d'etre is just that. The NCT says that women must be able to make informed choices and that's important, but I think we need to go a stage further and acknowledge the emotional pain and all the pressures that women are under. Childbirth has become a performance art and that's so sad because it is an intense living experience involving all our emotions."

Though she was a founder member of the NCT she fell out with the organisation for a time in the 70s when she published The Good Birth Guide. They decided that the book was causing harm, undermining the good relations with senior hospital staff that they had painfully built up over the years, and passed an overwhelming vote of no confidence in her. "It's silly really, but that still hurts."

Clearly she feels many of her ideals have been misrepresented.

"We've failed to see birth as something which is overwhelming and that relates to my image of the waves of the sea. This is not something you learn like you use a computer and have control over it and part of the glory of it is that you are overwhelmed just as you are when you are making love. Lots of people don't understand why I make the sexual analogy but when you're about to have an orgasm, you can't time it or say I'm going to breathe this way and it's going to be just right because I've practised, you go with it and you can't say no to it. It's the same with birth - certainly in the second stage of labour."

Birth may be safer now than it has ever been, but things can and do go wrong and that understandably raises anxiety levels in the mother and all those around her. It was one last passing comment from Kitzinger which made me wonder whether it may be this all-pervasive anxiety about labour that lies at the root of our need to control it, whether that be "naturally" at home in a water pool, or plugged into a monitor in hospital. "People feel the need to give advice because they're anxious. When I start dishing out advice it is usually because I'm not centred and it's usually dumb advice." I did a double-take - her books are full of advice. Is her need to control and inculcate better practise among new mothers actually born of an acute anxiety? Beneath that warrior revolutionary is there just another anxious, bossy, caring but controlling mother who asked me if I needed to go to the loo before I set off for home?

"I try not to say 'should' and I try to explore different things that women do in different circumstances and act as a channel for how women live their lives." So what advice would she give to all those women out there who feel they have failed to have the supremely enjoyable, quasi-sexual experience of childbirth that she is so openly exultant about? "They probably have been let down by what they perceived as 'natural' childbirth, we often tell women that they ought to take control of aspects of their lives in a way which makes them feel failures as soon as it's unsuccessful. What we omit to talk about is the social situation in which they found themselves. If a woman says that she feels she has failed, my first reaction would be to say that I understand that and then I would ask if she felt that there were others who had failed her, and then you can begin to deconstruct it, the pressures that exist on the midwife or obstetrician." The idea that it may be the very ethos of natural childbirth that has failed women does not enter the equation. On with the revolution!

fields.headline: Freeserve unlikely to freefall
fields.standfirst: Freeserve's stars are full of contradictions but by September next year, predicts Maggie Hyde, this Cancerian should be reaping the benefits of its bold nature.
fields.trailText: October 26: Cancerian Freeserve's jitters are no more than that, says the Medium Medium Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Freeserve is the latest internet service provider to run into trouble with unmetered off-peak web access. With many of its 250,000 account holders logged on for hours at a time, its costs were becoming unsustainable and it has trimmed "unreasonable" users and suspended new sign-ups.

The fall in Freeserve's share price has pitched it out of the FTSE 100, and analysts have cast doubt on the ability of its portal to attract revenue through advertising and other services. The collapse of talks with Deutsche Telekom's T-Online last June dented Freeserve's hopes of establishing a Europe-wide link-up to compete with US competitors, and its owner, Dixons, has failed to find another buyer.

Freeserve is full of contradictions and its long-term prospects are difficult to call, for the astrologer as well as the analyst. Its horoscope (June 26 1999) is criss-crossed with oppositions and squares, giving it an erratic and intemperate quality.

The opposition of reckless Mars and extravagant Jupiter is particularly troublesome and the astrological tradition warns of "an inclination to give little and demand much", as well as "a constant tendency to waste and prodigality" (astrologer Charles Carter 1930).

As a homey Cancerian with its Moon in grab-a-freebie Sagittarius, Freeserve has expanded rapidly in the domestic market and its recent troubles are less significant than they might seem, even though the share price might jitter from mid-November right through to early April. Pluto's disruptive conjunction to the Moon in its overseas zone also puts a question mark over foreign expansion.

However, in March its horoscope clicked into a positive new phase as speedy Mercury, planet of trade and indicator of its customer base, moved into generous Leo, coinciding with the introduction of unmetered access.

It will be September 2001 before Mercury reaches the Moon and Freeserve reaps the benefits of its bold strategies. For any investor, including Dixons, that looks like the right moment to take a profit and sell.

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Just a little something I dashed off at the beach
fields.standfirst: The truth about the Impressionists and their instant art, by  Maev Kennedy
fields.trailText: Wandering around the galleries in the excruciatingly picturesque Normandy port of Honfleur, you could easily conclude that it would have been better for art if all the Impressionist painters had been tied up in a sack and drowned like kittens.
fields.body:
Wandering around the galleries in the excruciatingly picturesque Normandy port of Honfleur, you could easily conclude that it would have been better for art if all the Impressionist painters had been tied up in a sack and drowned like kittens.

Even Michael Wilson, exhibitions officer at the National Gallery, seemed to agree - and he is about to unleash a pack of Monets, Cezannes, Sisleys and Renoirs on the British public. "Oh dear," he sighed, gazing in dismay into the window of one of Honfleur's many private galleries.

It was in this town, almost 130 years ago, that Monet painted his gorgeous picture Towing of a Boat at Honfleur. Eugene Boudin, seen variously as the last precursor of Impressionism or the first of the pack, spent most of his long life in the town and painted every corner of it. Almost all the artists dubbed Impressionists (they never labelled themselves that way) came at some stage to stay at a farm on a hill just outside the town - where the landlady gave jugs of cider and long credit - painting sunlight dappling through the apple tree branches. Their long shadows now lie disastrously on the artists who jockey for easel space around the old harbour.

The Impressionists are very big business, arguably the most genuinely mass popular movement in art history. Over a century after they were first exhibited to hoots of laughter and howls of derision, the acres of dapply leaves and ripply waters, bosomy barmaids and paddling moppets are cherished by people who are never likely to buy a reproduction of a Rembrandt, a Delacroix or a Picasso, still less a Hirst or an Emin. The real thing packs auction rooms to the gunwhales; for the megastars, a Van Gogh bootlace or sunflower petal, say, an international frenzy breaks out.

The National Gallery's new exhibition Painting Quickly in France is dedicated to the movement that officially began with an exhibition organised in Paris in 1874 by a group of artists who went under the cumbersome name of the Anonymous Society of Artist Painters, Sculptors, Printmakers, Etc. Among the 165 works was a painting by Monet called Impression, Rising Sun. The rest was art history and 1,000 miles of gifte shoppe tea towels.

The French tourist office knows it is on to a winner. A small fortune has just been spent creating six Impressionist art trails for tourists. You can make pilgrimages following Light, River, Sea, Townscapes, Gardens and the Moment. Visitors to Caudebec-en-Caux, just downstream from Rouen, are invited to stand on the banks of the Seine, ignore the giant car transporters and petrol tankers blotting out the landscape, and turn instead to a panel reproducing Sisley's lyrical dazzle of light on the great wide stretch of still water.

There are panels all along the sea front at Le Havre, a town so devastated by Allied bombing in the second world war that the tourist authorities now market it as "France's only 20th century town". The front, in fact, charts the speed of the rise of the Impressionist movement: at one end, under the cliff at Sainte Addresse, there is a Monet from the early 1860s, flowingly painted but very traditionally conceived and composed. At the other end of the harbour, there is a panel of Rising Sun, painted probably only five years later, with all the details, boats, masts, cranes, huts, dissolved in calligraphic scribbles into the light.

Is it still possible to look beyond the Renoir umbrellas, the Manet Folies-Bergères beer mats and the Monet waterlily silk ties, and actually see the Impressionists? Is there anything new to be said about them, any intellectual justification for another exhibition beyond a guaranteed crowd-pleaser for a gallery overshadowed by the success of Tate Modern?

Absolutely so, say the National Gallery's director Neil MacGregor and curator Rick Brettell, an American art scholar who has also written the exhibition catalogue. "What has not been looked at before is the sheer pleasure of the swirl of paint," says MacGregor. Pleasure is a shocking justification for an exhibition in these days of pity and terror in art. But MacGregor says there's much more to the show than a display of "icons of pleasure". Both men argue that recent scholarship has been hung up on the intellectual and social context of the movement, its classical antecedents, its place in art history, and the startling fact that the subjects of these pictures are generally neither the traditional wealthy patrons, nor the attractively ragged peasants of genre painting, but a new class, the cheerful bourgeoisie.

They suggest that this approach may have paid dividends in terms of art history, but misses the quality that made these pictures seem revolutionary, even shocking to their contemporaries. The Impressionists were exhibiting and selling pictures that would have seemed half-finished a decade earlier, the paint dragged, scraped, swirled and smudged across the surface, often leaving raw canvas showing through. Art history, Brettell argues, has a vested interest in making painting appear dense, multilayered, difficult. "Painting quickly" confounds the scholars.

Brettell approached the exhibition with this belief, but he now has empirical proof of it. The show has borrowed from all over the world, but there are a few gaps. Several institutions were so affronted by the title Painting Quickly, that they refused to lend. Most were sweet-talked around by MacGregor, but one flatly refused to send its treasure just to have it dismissed as a quick trick.

Because the appearance of freedom, freshness and spontaneity was so important to the Impressionists, the exhibition also teaches us to suspect it. One of the origins of the show was the National Gallery's Monet painting of the beach at Trouville, an image of a sunny, windy day on a sandy beach. Microscopic analysis revealed a little patch of blown sand, trapped forever in the tacky paint - just like the legend.

But not all the pictures were dashed off in an hour's lather of perspiration and inspiration. A second's thought is enough to realise that Manet's famous Races at Longchamps couldn't possibly have been done on the spot, or the artist would have ended up as cat meat, trampled under the horses' thundering hoofs. Even Monet's Rising Sun, which appears to have been breathed in one sigh of oil paint and genius straight onto the canvas, is no such thing either. In other works, such as a desolate and icy wintry river landscape painted after the death of his first wife, he carefully left a blank circle of canvas so that he could swirl in a blaze of orange for the sun without the paints smearing. In the Le Havre canvas the sun may be a single, sweeping brush stroke, but it's on top of other paint, and doesn't have the smear of wet on wet, so was added later.

It was ever thus. Although the Impressionists were the first to exhibit and sell such paintings, Brettell points out that such rapid sketches were being made centuries before, either as aides-memoire or as pitches to clients. In the latter case it was also important to give an impression of spontaneity and raging inspiration; the little sketches were often reworked until they told this lie convincingly.

Nevertheless, he defends the title as an accurate description of the unique quality that the Impressionists brought, an influence that he sees stretching far into the 20th century. Jackson Pollock would have been inconceivable without Impressionism. "The pictures may have been constructed in two, three, or even more sessions," he says, "but each of those sessions were painted quickly."

In the catalogue, Brettell issues a seductive invitation: "We are presenting to contemporary viewers pictures that remain contingent, experimental and risky more than a century after they were made. The most benignly attractive movement in western painting deserves to retrieve a little of the oomph that it had in the 19th century." Last week in London he added cheerfully: "This is an exhibition about surface, not depth."

Back in Honfleur, the gallery window was heaving with impressions: sunrise, sunset, sunrise through snow, sunset through mist, boats at anchor, boats under sail, a bouillabaisse of colour, faltering lines and decomposing brush strokes. "Oh dear. Horrible, horrible," said Michael Wilson, with a hint of remorse.

Is it still possible to look beyond the Renoir umbrellas, the Manet Folies-Bergères beer mats and the Monet waterlily silk ties, and actually see the Impressionists? Is there anything new to be said about them, any intellectual justification for another exhibition beyond a guaranteed crowd-pleaser for a gallery overshadowed by the success of Tate Modern? Absolutely so, say the National Gallery's director Neil MacGregor and curator Rick Brettell, an American art scholar who has also written the exhibition catalogue. "What has not been looked at before is the sheer pleasure of the swirl of paint," says MacGregor. Pleasure is a shocking justification for an exhibition in these days of pity and terror in art. But MacGregor says there's much more to the show than a display of "icons of pleasure". Both men argue that recent scholarship has been hung up on the intellectual and social context of the movement, its classical antecedents, its place in art history, and the startling fact that the subjects of these pictures are generally neither the traditional wealthy patrons, nor the attractively ragged peasants of genre painting, but a new class, the cheerful bourgeoisie. They suggest that this approach may have paid dividends in terms of art history, but misses the quality that made these pictures seem revolutionary, even shocking to their contemporaries. The Impressionists were exhibiting and selling pictures that would have seemed half-finished a decade earlier, the paint dragged, scraped, swirled and smudged across the surface, often leaving raw canvas showing through. Art history, Brettell argues, has a vested interest in making painting appear dense, multilayered, difficult. "Painting quickly" confounds the scholars. Brettell approached the exhibition with this belief, but he now has empirical proof of it. The show has borrowed from all over the world, but there are a few gaps. Several institutions were so affronted by the title Painting Quickly, that they refused to lend. Most were sweet-talked around by MacGregor, but one flatly refused to send its treasure just to have it dismissed as a quick trick. Because the appearance of freedom, freshness and spontaneity was so important to the Impressionists, the exhibition also teaches us to suspect it. One of the origins of the show was the National Gallery's Monet painting of the beach at Trouville, an image of a sunny, windy day on a sandy beach. Microscopic analysis revealed a little patch of blown sand, trapped forever in the tacky paint - just like the legend. But not all the pictures were dashed off in an hour's lather of perspiration and inspiration. A second's thought is enough to realise that Manet's famous Races at Longchamps couldn't possibly have been done on the spot, or the artist would have ended up as cat meat, trampled under the horses' thundering hoofs. Even Monet's Rising Sun, which appears to have been breathed in one sigh of oil paint and genius straight onto the canvas, is no such thing either. In other works, such as a desolate and icy wintry river landscape painted after the death of his first wife, he carefully left a blank circle of canvas so that he could swirl in a blaze of orange for the sun without the paints smearing. In the Le Havre canvas the sun may be a single, sweeping brush stroke, but it's on top of other paint, and doesn't have the smear of wet on wet, so was added later. It was ever thus. Although the Impressionists were the first to exhibit and sell such paintings, Brettell points out that such rapid sketches were being made centuries before, either as aides-memoire or as pitches to clients. In the latter case it was also important to give an impression of spontaneity and raging inspiration; the little sketches were often reworked until they told this lie convincingly. Nevertheless, he defends the title as an accurate description of the unique quality that the Impressionists brought, an influence that he sees stretching far into the 20th century. Jackson Pollock would have been inconceivable without Impressionism. "The pictures may have been constructed in two, three, or even more sessions," he says, "but each of those sessions were painted quickly." In the catalogue, Brettell issues a seductive invitation: "We are presenting to contemporary viewers pictures that remain contingent, experimental and risky more than a century after they were made. The most benignly attractive movement in western painting deserves to retrieve a little of the oomph that it had in the 19th century." Last week in London he added cheerfully: "This is an exhibition about surface, not depth." Back in Honfleur, the gallery window was heaving with impressions: sunrise, sunset, sunrise through snow, sunset through mist, boats at anchor, boats under sail, a bouillabaisse of colour, faltering lines and decomposing brush strokes. "Oh dear. Horrible, horrible," said Michael Wilson, with a hint of remorse.

fields.headline: Into the lion's den
fields.standfirst: Visiting Gore Vidal is no small undertaking. The grand old curmudgeon of American letters lives like a Renaissance prince on a cliff above the bay of Naples. But  Erica Jong made the trip, and the two writers spent an evening discussing life, literature and his cousin Al.
fields.trailText: Visiting Gore Vidal is no small undertaking. The grand old curmudgeon of American letters lives like a Renaissance prince on a cliff above the bay of Naples. But  Erica Jong made the trip, and the two writers spent an evening discussing life, literature and his cousin Al.
fields.body:
We arrived at Prospero's domain on a sweltering August night. Behind three gates, reached on foot by means of a path clinging to a promontory half-shrouded in clouds, Gore Vidal's and Howard Austen's villa at Ravello (south of Naples) is indeed well-named: La Rondinaia or swallow's nest. It strangely reminded me of Hitler's eagle's nest at Bertchesgaden - if only in this respect: it, too, is the domain of a paranoid genius. For who but a paranoid genius would so separate himself from the world?

From the tiny port below, Ravello is a death-defying taxi ride along a corniche road like the one on which Princess Grace of Monaco died. Perhaps this is why neither Gore nor Howard drives any more but instead use taxis and chauffeured cars to go back and forth from their inaccessible fortress. The combination of preprandial drinking and hairpin turns would certainly not be good for their health. Indeed the switchbacks carved into the limestone ledges are so narrow that the passage of a bus or a truck stops traffic behind you for several minutes. You have to be truly dedicated to visit Gore Vidal. We were.

I had known Gore since about 1990 when my seventh novel, Any Woman's Blues, was published in Italy and Gore invited me to lunch at his apartment in Rome. It was a chilly lunch. He had a bone to pick with me. In one of my novels, I had quoted a witticism of his that had been repeated to me by a mutual friend, and Gore was pissed off. What I had thought of as a tribute to his wit, he had thought of as a deliberate misquotation or attack and we were off to a bad start. The witticism concerned Princess Margaret, one of his best pals, and Gore was stung. I apologised and we went on with our lugubrious lunch, but I felt unforgiven at heart. Gore was not drinking that day and he seemed terribly depressed. I left his apartment in Rome thinking: this is the saddest man I've ever met. But his rare intelligence intrigued and delighted me (as it always had in his extraordinary books) and I was eager to see him again. He gave me an autographed copy of his edition of the stories of Tennessee Williams and in the front flap I remember writing about the afternoon: "The coldest man I've ever met and the saddest. What is at the root of his sadness? The depression is contagious. I came away very depressed."

Gore represented an enigma to me: a man with the world at his feet who seemed so terribly hurt by the smallest slight. If he could nurse a grudge about a throwaway line in a novel, imagine what melancholy lurked beneath that guarded, aristocratic exterior. He fascinated me. I loved his writing, was dazzled by his intellectual courage, and I was prepared to like the man, but his grievance-collecting got in the way. Still, a mutual friend kept bringing us together. Whenever we met, I sensed great vulnerability in this complex and brilliant man. Maybe I was even a little in love with his fierce intellect. I do tend to fall in love with exceptional brains.

Once in Ravello, a lovely car-free town clinging to the top of a cliff above the sea, you proceed on foot to the gates of a small hotel where you encounter the first set of bells, mounted on a stucco wall. There it says: La Rondinaia. You ring the bell and proceed along a private path that clings to the mountainside. The view is dizzying and will become ever more so as you proceed toward the lair of the maestro. Another gate, another bell. Howard Austen, Gore's companion of 30-plus years, answers, saying in his New York accent: "Go neither left nor right but straight ahead until you can go no more. There will be another gate." (Three gates to the city, hallelujah!)

Another precipitous path, clouds below, cypresses and umbrella pines above. A marmalade cat comes out to greet you with a wriggling grey mouse in its teeth. For this is the house of a cat-lover whose practised hauteur belies his tenderness. Gore Vidal is a brilliant writer who needs to be told constantly how brilliant he is.

We walk along the pine needle- softened path (led by the cat with the dying mouse in its mouth), until we come to the third gate - this one unmarked. Again we ring. Again Howard's voice leads us: "Go neither right nor left but straight ahead." The pool will be below. Again we obey.

Soon we are descending a rocky stair that leads to a dark azure pool and, standing beside it, Prospero himself, an amber sunset whiskey in his hand.

Gore is rather more bearish than the last time I saw him, but still handsome, his leonine head beginning to soften with dewlaps, his fiercely intelligent eyes surrounded by innumerable wrinkles. None of this uglifies him. Ageing has only made him more charismatic somehow.

You think of Byron at Missolonghi, ravaged by life at 36. But Gore is 75 and has had a good long run of looks, love, fame, fortune. Both life and literature have been good to him - if literature can ever be said to be good to any misunderstood genius. Literature is a mean mistress who always betrays her lovers in the end, refusing promised glories, proffering instead out-of-print books, publishing houses sold to movie studios and television networks, decades of passionately-written novels forgotten as a new generation comes along demanding books written in their own voice. But despite all that, it's been a good run. He was a beautiful young man, a bestselling author at 21 and now, living in splendour like a Renaissance prince, he is still writing at the top of his form.

"If I were a great writer," he says, "I could be living in Brooklyn Heights."

He is referring to that dinner party I gave for him in New York a few years ago to which Norman Mailer - who lives in Brooklyn Heights - also came. (The two one-time enemies actually broke bread together.)

"But you are a great writer," I say.

"I know," he says playfully. "But I'd be even greater if I lived in Brooklyn Heights."

"I think Norman's in Provincetown this summer," I say.

"Even better!" Gore roars. "Maybe I'd be great if I lived in Provincetown."

I think how odd it is that he should raise his old enmity with Norman. But I know writers - "ingrown toenails" as Henry Miller (who preferred to hang out with painters) called us. It is not enough to succeed. All your friends and contemporaries must fail. Writers are like this even when we try like hell not to be.

I myself hate that old Hemingwayesque paradigm of the writer as prizefighter and I have tried hard to create an alternate one for myself. When Anne Sexton admonished me, "We are all writing God's poem," I took it to mean there should be no competition between writers because we are all involved in a common project, a common prayer. But to Gore's and Norman's generation, particularly those male writers who served in the second world war, the prizefighter paradigm remains. They still want to KO each other, even at 70-odd. In a way, this is the tragedy of their generation. Their teeth were cut on the war and they never relinquished its us-and-them mentality.

Gore tells us about the house. It is a cliff-dwelling, on many levels, and the rock it perches on is so steep that a glance over the balcony from his study gives me instant vertigo. Once owned by the daughter of an English Victorian lord, La Rondinaia has innumerable acres of terraces where grapes, olives and lemons grow, towering cedars, endless steps and balconies above the sea. It is not accessible by automobile. You must walk to this eyrie, an anomaly that has obviously preserved it as one of the most beautiful spots on earth.

"How does it go?" Gore asks. "Perfection of the life or of the work? One of the stupidest lines in English poetry. Who was it?"

"Yeats," I said.

"Ridiculous," said Gore. "The truth is you don't have to choose."

"Choose what?" I asked.

"Perfection of the life or of the work. Neither is possible."

So we wander up the steps to the house and are shown some of it: the hall leading to the salotto with its 17th-century canvases, the salotto itself with its Graeco-Roman head of Zeus and first century mosaic floor mounted as a wallpiece (which cannot be taken out of Italy, says Howard). Gore seems a bit bored with the house tour as if he has done it a few too many times.

Howard brings us drinks, complaining of the heat. He and I commiserate about global warming. Then we follow Gore into his study overlooking the sea as if from heaven, the guest suite that might have been ours had we been invited to stay, the terrace overlooking the sea where Sting and Trudie, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins sang all night at a July 4th party, the grand dining room with its faux-Roman chairs (from the movie set of Ben-Hur), the sitting room with its framed pictures of old pal Princess Margaret.

And so at last to sup at the newly refurbished Hotel Sasso, a restored palazzo also hanging over the sea. At the main square in Ravello, Gore is greeted by all and sundry as "maestro". An agreeable thing for a famous artist who becomes a habitué of this country is the nod to the maestro that is semi-automatic with Italians. Like Americans, Italians may not read, but they understand that a maestro, even a maestra, is someone to be honoured. If they cannot really distinguish between the brilliance of a Gore Vidal and, say, the pulp of a Danielle Steel, at least they know that a scrittore or scrittrice is a person of consequence.

Tongue loosened by many drinks, Gore discusses his plans for his estate. Upon his demise, La Rondinaia will become a study centre for his alma mater, the St Alban's school - but how to administer it? Gore has reached the age of estate-planning. I am all too familiar with this age and also with the cat-and-mouse game benefactors play with their possible heirs.

Sitting in the bar for yet another round of drinks before dinner, Gore and Howard opine on what a perfect place the Sasso would be as a retirement home. When the universal condition of life - decay and death - catches up with even the most exalted artists, they succumb to primal fear. I realise I am sitting with an elderly gay couple without children who are facing their declining years with trepidation. They may have plenty of money, a fantastic villa on a promontory of the Italian coast, but they have already experienced a few health scares and they know they are no longer immune to death.

That vulnerability is, I think, what makes The Golden Age, Gore's latest novel, so remarkable even in his remarkable oeuvre. He has always been an essayist who fell into the writing of novels and some of his novels seem more essays than novels. But in this one, as in Smithsonian Institution, his last historical fiction, there is an understanding of history and its vicissitudes that no other contemporary writer possesses.

Long before anyone else, Gore identified what he dubbed "The National Security State", a United States that prepares constantly for war while preaching peace, and nailed its root cause: the need to keep the wheels of commerce turning to the tune of billions of dollars of defence spending per year. Like the 18th-century philosophers who framed the Constitution, he is for a true republic in which the people who participate have some grasp of history. He is outraged by the course the United States has taken in the past 50 years, as indeed the framers of its Constitution would be. Gore sees a Congress bought by special interests, and two parties vying to keep the war machine up and running with American tax dollars.

I recently asked Gore what he thought of the-too-close-to-call race between George W Bush and Al Gore, his distant cousin. He replied: "They are both part of a political system neither of them invented, but Albert is much more intelligent. If you have a bad system, the best thing to do is pick the most intelligent leader. Clearly Al Gore is more intelligent. But the rot goes deep and the system will crumble if we just wait. One big plunge of the stock market could topple the corporate interests that run things."

Then he talked about his tour through Britain, speaking at Cambridge and Oxford, encountering huge crowds of students everywhere he went. He was impressed by the young people who came to hear him, far less impressed by reviewers of his latest novel who seemed to have no historical education and therefore no context in which to place his fiction. For a writer steeped in Herodotus and Plotinus to be reviewed by those who have read neither must be galling.

Gore is at heart an 18th-century man who belongs among those framers of the American Constitution - men who knew their Greek and Roman history and philosophy, and took the long, historical view of governments. His living on a promontory surrounded by ancient artefacts is indeed just what an 18th- century philosopher would do. He lives in splendid isolation - aiming fiery feuilletons at a dumb and dumber world.

Gore Vidal understands what America might be if it didn't betray its own ideals - the ideals we gave the world and then renounced in favour of corporate oligarchy and the perpetual war machine.

When we said goodbye after dinner and headed back to the sailboat we had anchored on the coast, I was inspired. Gore Vidal is everything a writer should be: a voice for sanity in a mad world.

webTitle: The threat to humans from BSE

fields.headline: The threat to humans from BSE
fields.standfirst:
As today's report into BSE reveals where some of the fault lay for the crisis, questions still exist about just how much danger CJD poses to humans. Mark Tran and Julian Glover explain.

Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: As today's report into BSE reveals where some of the fault lay for the crisis, questions still exist about just how much danger CJD poses to humans. We explain the issues.
fields.body:
What is BSE?
Bovine spongiform encephalopathy is a slowly progressive and ultimately fatal neurological disease affecting cattle. Commonly known as mad cow disease, it was first identified in 1986. CJD is the human form of spongiform encephalopathy and is caused by eating beef infected with BSE.

What causes BSE?
BSE in the UK comes from using animal feed containing contaminated meat and bone meal as a protein source. Health officials suspect that cattle were contaminated by either scrapie-affected sheep or cattle. Scrapie is a fatal, degenerative disease affecting the central nervous system of sheep and goats.

What is the likelihood of catching BSE?
The information keeps changing. In the latest scare, in August this year, Professor John Collinge said that new research showed that animals thought to be healthy and incapable of acquiring BSE can, in theory, pass the disease on. Experiments on mice and hamsters have suggested that similar diseases could jump between species more easily than previously thought. His findings have sparked renewed concern that humans not displaying variant CJD symptoms but incubating the condition may infect others during medical or dental procedures. However, Professor Smith, acting head of the government's BSE advisory comittee SEAC, today said that the risk of becoming infected now from beef products was very small and "attributable almost certainly to exposure" when the levels of contaminated product was at its zenith in the food chain.

How many people have died?
In total, at least 70 people have died of CJD. Prof Smith said today the final numbers it may yet kill as likely to be from between a few hundred to several thousand people. He said early estimates of an epidemic were "farily implausible".

Has there been a recent outbreak of CJD?
Health officials are investigating a cluster of five cases around Queniborough, just north of Leicester. These included three victims dying within a few of months in 1998, a fourth who died in May 2000 and another patient, still alive, who is thought to be suffering from the disease.

Are people still being infected?
This is what perplexes scientists. Until today's findings, the prevailing scientific opinion was that humans were almost certainly not still being infected. The government's expensive programme of slaughtering all cattle aged over 30 months and - temporarily - banning the sale of beef on the bone minimised public exposure to BSE-infected meat and was thought to have caused the disease to almost die out in Britain's beef herds. But the latest research published by the National Academy of Sciences will cause a rethink.

What was last week's polio BSE scare about?
An oral polio vaccine, Medeva, was recalled last week over fears of CJD. The vaccine, which had been used in up to a third of inoculations for children and travellers, contained tiny traces of a feoetal calf growth serum from potentially BSE-contaminated animals. However, the risks of infection from the vaccine were said to be "incalcuably small". The Department of Health said the firm, also Medeva, had misled them on assurances the vaccine met new BSE safety guidelines.

What did the research revealed in August involve?
Prof Collinge's team found that mice injected with hamster scrapie, a BSE-like disease, carried high levels of infectivity while living into old age without outward symptoms. But when material from the brains of these mice was injected into other mice, it eventually killed them. The worry is that the process created a new strain - or strains - of a more virulent disease.

Do the latest findings contradict recent information?
They do seem to go against research released earlier in August when scientists said CJD could ultimately claim 136,000 lives, a much smaller number than previous estimates. At one point there seemed to be no limit to the numbers potentially at risk. A European committee thought that a single animal with BSE could put up to 500,000 people at risk.

Why were the numbers revised?
In a report in the journal Nature, scientists from Oxford concluded that any sick animal that entered the food chain was liable to infect no more than two individuals, and only 40% of the population was genetically susceptible, leaving the incubation period as the other key factor. If the incubation period was less than 20 years, there could be as few as 63 cases. If the incubation period stretched to almost lifetime length - 60 years - then there were likely to be 136,000. What matters over the next few years is the annual rate of increases. "If the average annual incidence of CJD over the next three years is fewer than 15 cases, then the maximum total number of cases would fall to 20,000," they wrote.

How did the Conservative government deal with the BSE crisis?
Many people think that the issue could have been addressed far earlier. BSE was identified in November 1986 but ministers were not informed about the disease until June 1987. Although measures were subsequently put in place to keep meat most likely to be infected away from the dinner tables, it was not until 1996 that the government admitted that there might be a serious risk to human health. The Labour government launched an official inquiry into the way the crisis was handled. This was the inquiry that reported back today.

fields.headline: NatMags chief defects to Attic
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The commercial boss of NatMags' Affluent group has been poached to run Attic Futura. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The commercial boss of the National Magazine Company's newly created Affluent magazines group, which handles its upmarket glossies, has been poached to run Attic Futura.

Vivien Cotterill will replace Neil Raaschou, who resigned last week as managing director after six years following the failure of an attempted management buyout of Attic from its Australian parent company.

Before being appointed commercial director of the Affluent group four months ago, Ms Cotterill had been publisher of She, launch publisher of Zest and advertisement director of Cosmopolitan.

Ian Meikle, group managing director of Attic's parent company, Pacific Publications, said: "Vivien's energy and vision will keep building on the firm foundation that Neil brought to the business."

NatMags created Affluent to help its glossies - Harpers & Queen, Esquire, Country Living and Focus - compete more effectively against Conde Nast's upmarket titles Vogue and GQ.

The appointment is likely to be greeted with some relief by Attic staff, who feared a troubleshooter would be brought in from Australia to replace Mr Raaschou.

webTitle: Trinity Mirror New Media names Graham Mead head of  IC Network

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror New Media names Graham Mead head of  IC Network
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror New Media has appointed Graham Mead as managing director of the IC Network, the umbrella network housing the ISP and portal ic24, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror New Media has appointed Graham Mead, previously managing director of its regional websites, as managing director of the IC Network, the umbrella network that houses the ISP and portal ic24.

The appointment coincides with a number of changes at TMNM, including a new name for the division - Trinity Mirror Digital Media.

David Clarke, managing director of Trinity Mirror Digital Media, said the developments had come about because the division had grown rapidly and needed a firmer structure.

Mr Clarke said: "It was getting too much for me to manage both elements [the IC Network and group digital strategy] so I needed a good manager to run the IC side of things."

Mr Mead, formerly regional marketing director of Trinity Mirror, was brought into the digital division in April to head up the planned network of IC-branded regional portals.

Having turned around Trinity's Birmingham and Coventry papers in the mid-90s, Mead is viewed as a hard-hitter and commands the respect of staff.

He will report directly to Mr Clarke, who is seeking to fill the vacant position of managing director of regional new media by promoting one of the existing six regional directors.

Mr Clarke added that he would now be able to take a step back from day-to-day operations to focus on Trinity Mirror's digital strategy and ensure the publisher made the right moves.

He said he was keen not to be seen as a copycat with "me-too" products for the company's move into new platforms, such as mobile, broadband and digital TV.

Mr Clarke added that the free online time ISP initiative would continue for the time being until an unmetered product could be offered next year in conjunction with ic24's current supplier, Cable & Wireless Communications. The service currently has around 500,000 active users.

Speaking for the first time about the delays in launching the IC websites, Mr Clarke blamed a number of "technical issues". He explained that TMDM had initially picked the wrong content platform, Zip2, last year, which meant having to backtrack and build a whole new platform from scratch in-house.

Mr Clarke said that now the new platform was built, it was easy to add on other functionality for new platforms.

IcShowbiz, the first 'central portal', has been delayed by a month but should launch in mid-November, followed by icBirmingham and icCoventry at the end of November. December is expected to seen the launch of icSport and a further 13 regional portals. The final 'central portal', icChoice, a lifestyle advice website, is expected to launch in January next year.

The new websites are part of Trinity Mirror's £150m three-year investment in new media revealed in April this year.

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 26.
fields.trailText: SME e-tail sites could face huge bills due to customers abusing the new EU Direct Selling Directive that comes into force next Tuesday.
fields.body:
SME e-tail sites could face huge bills due to customers abusing the new EU Direct Selling Directive that comes into force next Tuesday.

Netbenefit is threatening legal action against domain name registrar Easily.co.uk - because the latter has registered wwwnetbenfit.com (without the dot).

Breathe is to launch a mobile payment system with a one-stop billing facility for subscribers.

The online finance industry is set for a shake-up, with a report published next month expected to force the removal of an anomaly in the Mortgage Code allowing financial aggregators to avoid regulation.

New women's portal therumour is targeting 18 to 25-year-olds.

Online Jewish community site TotallyJewish is to make staff cuts following its reverse takeover of London Jewish News and Sojewish.co.uk.

Keith Chegwin and Kathy Lloyd are among the celebrities promoting streetnames.com .

Website of the week is Peoplenews.co.uk, which scores 85/100.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 27.
fields.trailText: October 27: Mirror editor Piers Morgan has been brought in Marina Hyde to give evidence in an internal appeal against her sacking.
fields.body:
Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan has been brought in by Marina Hyde, former UK Confidential columnist at the Sun, to give evidence in a nine-hour internal appeal against her sacking, Press Gazette claims. It is thought that if her appeal is turned down Ms Hyde will take News International to an industrial tribunal. She was sacked two months ago when it was discovered she had been sending emails to Mr Morgan.

Red editor Sally Brampton has quit amid reports that Emap was unhappy with her recent diet of "heavy political features", including interviews with Mo Mowlam and Tony Blair.

BBC World Service staff are to take part in a strike ballot over increased hours and night working.

While last week delivering the Hugh Cudlipp Memorial Lecture, Bob Edwards, the former Daily Express editor, suggested Michael Heseltine as a suitable new owner for the Express titles. Mr Heseltine told Press Gazette he had no plans to put in a bid.

The Sunday Times has finally backed down over a complaint made by Prince Charles to the Press Complaints Commission over a story that he was exploring the possibility of marrying Camilla Parker Bowles in Scotland.

webTitle: QXL.com needs a lifeline if it is to stay afloat

fields.headline: QXL.com needs a lifeline if it is to stay afloat
fields.trailText: It all looked so bright for QXL.com earlier in the year. The online auctioneer's shares touched 800p, chief executive Jim Rose and his team were using their highly rated shares to snap up continental rivals and there was a growing feeling in the City that the UK upstart might actually beat the US firm eBay to European domination.
fields.body:
It all looked so bright for QXL.com earlier in the year. The online auctioneer's shares touched 800p, chief executive Jim Rose and his team were using their highly rated shares to snap up continental rivals and there was a growing feeling in the City that the UK upstart might actually beat the US firm eBay to European domination.

Analyst Thomas Bock at SG Cowen in the United States even came out and said it was only a matter of time before the shares hit £44.

Seven months later QXL shares are trading at just 31p - a 96% fall from their high and less than half the 69p issue price. The paper-led acquisition strategy is in tatters and Mr Bock is keeping an extremely low profile. Analysts say the company needs to refinance in the next six months and a takeover by a European portal is likely.

So how did the wheels come off a company so dramatically that its market valuation fell from £2.6bn in March to less than £100m by October?

Analysts blame the fickleness of the market and the sell-off of hi-tech shares. Dealers say sentiment towards loss-making business-to-consumer companies is so negative at the moment that nothing appears to be underpinning the share price.

Confidence is unlikely to return quickly enough for QXL to raise money through a share issue. A strategic partner seems inevitable. Ironically, it was the acquisition that was supposed to have turned QXL into a serious rival to eBay that has been one of the most important factors in its undoing.

The £668m takeover of Germany's Ricardo.de has been beset with difficulties and the price was renegotiated when it emerged that Ricardo's revenues were not as strong as hoped.

The subsequent slump in QXL's share price has put an end to any further all-share takeovers for the foreseeable future. Investment bank analysts are less likely to follow the shares while the company's value is so low.

Mr Rose now faces having to complete the thorny task of integrating different management teams, cultures, and concepts, while keeping staff morale high as the value of their share options falls.

Even Mr Rose is likely to concede that a partner is now needed. At the end of June QXL had around £56m in the bank and was burning £15m each quarter. It needs to refinance within the next twelve months and find the cash that will take it through to 2004 when profitability is forecast. The longer it leaves it, the worse the terms of any deal become for shareholders.

eBay has long been touted as a possible suitor but the two firms have talked and eBay has said it is not likely to bid. One analyst said: "eBay is doing very well in Europe. It dominates Germany, is doing very well in the UK and is about to launch in France. It doesn't need QXL."

Lycos Europe has consistently been linked with a bid that analysts believe would increase stickiness on its own site. Lycos' £8bn merger with Terra Networks of Spain is due to be completed on Monday. Investment bank CSFB acts for both Lycos and QXL could then be tempted to engineer a merger of the two parties sometime over the next few months.

People close to QXL suggest Lycos may not be the most likely partner. Others include T-Online and Yahoo!

Third-quarter results are due towards the end of next month and QXL will be under pressure to give firm pledges on financing.

webTitle: Can Anthea ever pick up the pieces?

fields.headline: Can Anthea ever pick up the pieces?
fields.standfirst: She was once TV's golden girl, but her allegations that she was beaten by former lover Bruno Brookes have failed to convince a sceptical press and public. Claire Cozens asks the PR experts if Anthea Turner can ever regain her former glory.
fields.trailText: She was once TV's golden girl, but in the last week Anthea Turner's fortunes seemed to have hit rock bottom. Claire Cozens asks the experts whether she can ever win back her former glory.
fields.body:
Any other woman would have won the sympathy of the nation, but Anthea Turner's revelations about beatings appear to have had the opposite effect.

Britain's top celebrity PRs said it would be virtually impossible for Ms Turner to regain public credibility after she claimed that Bruno Brookes had repeatedly beaten her up when they were lovers.

One slammed her decision to go public about alleged beatings as the "desperate measures of a desperate woman".

The strategy, which seemed designed to win back public sympathy after a series of PR disasters, spectacularly backfired yesterday when the tabloid newspapers turned against her.

Influential Daily Mail columnist Lynda Lee-Potter accused Ms Turner of using the allegations to revive her flagging career, while The Mirror featured a former battered wife expressing suspicion about the TV presenter's claims. Even the Sun, which had carried the original story on Tuesday, was yesterday concentrating on Mr Brookes' categoric denials.

Today, The Mirror urges Anthea to "shut up" branding her "a spectacular pain in the neck".

PR supremo Max Clifford described the fiasco as a perfect illustration of the myth that all publicity is good publicity.

"She has gone from being popular and successful to being very unpopular with nothing happening in her career," he said. "By seeking greater exposure she has only done herself more damage. She has shown she has no real grasp of how the public thinks and feels and now the public knows what she's like she's going to find it very hard to come back from this."

Her decision to go public comes despite advice from friends to keep out of the media. Ms Turner's husband Grant Bovey was last week advised by a top PR agency that the couple should keep their heads down rather than seeking further publicity, advice the industry appears to agree with.

Mark Borkowski of Borkowski PR said: "Some people can never get enough. The celebrity highway is littered with the bleached bones of those who've been completely stiffed in the media. Anthea could take lessons from people like Kate Winslet and Emma Thompson, who do not court the attention, but recognise they are subject to media attention and are honest."

But Sandra Horley, chief executive of the charity Refuge, believes Ms Turner's actions will encourage other victims of domestic violence to speak out. "The story was going to run anyway so it was better for her to cooperate," she said. "Newspapers like the Daily Mail and the Mirror are only helping Bruno Brookes to carry on abusing her. Our phones have been flooded with calls from women expressing their admiration for her courage in coming forward."

The revelations about the one-time couple first emerged when Sue Evison, the Sun's chief feature writer, confronted Ms Turner during an interview about her autobiography. Ms Turner apparently broke down and told the Sun about the alleged beatings and subsequently approached the Guardian offering an interview.

She did not consult a specialist PR agency but instead took advice from her agent, James Grant Management, and her lawyer, Mark Stephens.

webTitle: C&W in global branding talks with London agencies

fields.headline: C&W in global branding talks with London agencies
fields.trailText: 8am: Cable & Wireless is talking to London ad agencies with a view to launching its most significant global branding campaign yet. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless has begun talks with several London ad agencies with a view to launching its most significant global branding campaign yet.

The company spends in excess of £10m on advertising in the UK alone.

The move is likely to come as a significant blow to McCann Erickson, which was appointed by C&W in March and has been working with the company on its global strategy.

The telecoms giant is said to have sought the advice of ISBA's director of membership, Debbie Morrison, although the organisation refused to comment on its relationship with C&W.

The managing director at one of the agencies approached confirmed that he had met with C&W recently to discuss the potential benefits to the company of having a single global agency.

The managing director, who asked not to be named, said: "C&W works with about 40 agencies worldwide across some of its key markets including Asia, Hong Kong and the Caribbean

"They are in the process of trying to build a more global network and are investigating whether it makes sense to use one communications group globally to handle all its communications needs. They have had meetings with several big network agencies."

A separate source added that C&W was asking agencies for a complete reassessment of its brand and advice on how it should tackle its global communications.

McCann's created a pan-European, business-to-business print campaign for C&W ealier this year.

fields.headline: Former Our Price boss joins interactive TV outfit
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Interactive TV company Tventures has hired former Our Price Music chairman David Clipsham as a consultant and non-executive director, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Interactive TV company Tventures has drafted in the former chairman of Our Price Music, David Clipsham, to act as a consultant and non-executive director.

Tventures, which plans to launch a number of interactive TV channels on Sky Digital early next year, is believed to be close to securing a £6m round of funding.

The investment will enable the company to launch an interactive retail-focused music TV channel, the first TV channel in the UK that will have been developed as an integrated interactive channel from scratch, in the first quarter of 2001.

The service, tentatively called Mint, will be a 24-hour video channel that will encourage viewers to buy CDs while watching the videos. A website is being developed to support the planned user interaction.

The company is also planning a number of other enhanced TV channels in areas such as gardening, parenting, and niche sports.

Mr Clipsham, who has held senior roles at Mercury Records (Polygram), Paperchase and Waterstones, will work with Tventures on a two-day-a-week consultancy basis.

Tventures's management team already includes Alex Wright, former head of interactive at the Virgin Group and head of interactive TV at Agency.com, and Bill Fathers, former managing director of Reuters Connect Services.

fields.headline: Pokemon catches top brand award
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Pokemon has been named character of the year at the Brand Licensing Awards, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Pokemon, the craze that has been sweeping the nation's schools, was last night named character of the year at the Brand Licensing Awards.

The Japanese brand, which has spawned a TV cartoon series, a computer game and two movies as well as its trademark collectible cards, also picked up an award for product of the year.

The award for retailer of the year went to Tesco, which beat Woolworths, Marks & Spencer, Toys R Us and Argos to win the prize.

Brand of the year went to Santoro Graphics for its Bang on the Door range of accessories aimed at young girls. The company beat Barbie, Coca-Cola, the Royal Ascot Collection and Liverpool Football Club.

Licensing - the creation, production and sale of branded products - is a rapidly-growing industry in the UK. It is worth an estimated £5bn.

fields.headline: ONdigital mulls video-on-demand service
fields.trailText: 8am: Digital terrestrial television platform ONdigital is considering launching a video-on-demand service, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Digital terrestrial television platform ONdigital is considering launching a video-on-demand service.

Chief executive Stuart Prebble said that the company would launch a video-on-demand service "as and when ADSL becomes a serious consumer proposition".

The broadcaster has been in talks with video-on-demand providers including Yes Television, which are being sounded out as possible technology partners for the service.

An spokeswoman for ONdigital said: "We are looking at a range of services, including video-on-demand. Any self-respecting broadcaster would be."

Yes Television refused to comment publicly on any talks. But an insider admitted: "We're in regular contact with a number of companies."

ONdigital and Yes TV are believed to see synergies between the two companies. Ondigital's newly-launched Onnet service allows internet access through a set-top box, compared with Sky's Open... service, which provides its own proprietary "walled garden" service.

webTitle: Fuel: Protesters face action over attacks

fields.headline: Protesters face action over attacks
fields.standfirst:
Tougher response promised to prevent repeat of September's disruption
Special report on the fuel crisis on the Guardian network at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/ petrol
fields.trailText: Fuel protesters can expect to be prosecuted as a result of evidence of intimidation and attacks on tanker drivers during last month's blockades, a police spokesman said yesterday.
fields.body:
Fuel protesters can expect to be prosecuted as a result of evidence of intimidation and attacks on tanker drivers during last month's blockades, a police spokesman said yesterday.

Protest leaders dismissed the catalogue of incidents supplied by the oil companies and transport union to the government's fuel taskforce as "spin" and "rubbish". But, referring to 180 cases of driver intimidation reported by the oil companies and 30 detailed by the Transport and General Workers' Union (TGWU), Peter Shipley, spokesman for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said yesterday: "We accept those incidents did take place".

"The protesters were careful to avoid acts of intimidation in front of the TV and police, which is the explanation for our and the media's perception that it wasn't widespread," Mr Shipley said.

"It is necessary to say that next time policing of all aspects of the protest will be much more vigorous," he added, singling out motorway or trunk road go-slows, which had been "very widespread and disruptive" during the September blockades.

The list of incidents drawn up by TotalFinaElf on behalf of the six main oil companies - obtained by the Guardian - includes bricks, stones and other objects thrown through cab windscreens, tankers cut up or forced off the road, physical attacks and threats to drivers and their families.

But although police investigations into some incidents are still being pursued, the TGWU has complained of foot-dragging. Meanwhile, the oil firms' record shows that police were well aware of some incidents but opted for a low-key approach.

At Stanlow refinery in Cheshire, for example, where the protests began, the log records: "Carlton Fuels vehicle had traffic cone thrown through windscreen and air lines disconnected ... following above incident, police advised they could not guarantee driver vehicle safety. All vehicle movements halted".

The failure of police to provide tanker escorts - not only as they left terminals, but at their most vulnerable, when delivering fuel to petrol stations - was a recurrent complaint by drivers during last month's blockades.

The TGWU-brokered agreement to allow two drivers per cab and to provide police protection at both pick-up and drop-off points was the key to getting fuel moving out of BP's Grangemouth refinery in central Scotland on September 13, the decisive break in the national blockade.

According to a ministerial source, police refused to escort tankers over county lines during last month's protests. But arrangements are now in place to ensure escorts, including police in the cab, will go the whole way if blockades reappear next month.

Union officials acknowledge that some tanker drivers felt sympathy for the protests and discontent at the deterioration in drivers' terms and conditions at the hands of the oil companies and their contractors. The employers were also paying the drivers and putting no pressure on them to work.

webTitle: Fuel protests: Demo leaders divided over tactics to force tax cut

fields.headline: Demo leaders divided over tactics to force tax cut
fields.standfirst:
Supermarket depots, ports and main roads face disruption
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Leaders of the fuel tax protests have split into warring camps, accusing each other of hijacking the movement, while promoting rival direct action plans - including blockading supermarket food distribution centres - if Gordon Brown fails to meet their demands next month.
fields.body:
Leaders of the fuel tax protests have split into warring camps, accusing each other of hijacking the movement, while promoting rival direct action plans - including blockading supermarket food distribution centres - if Gordon Brown fails to meet their demands next month.

At the centre of the infighting are two of the most prominent leaders of last month's fuel blockades, Brynle Williams, the 51-year-old Welsh smallholder, who kicked off the protests at Stanlow refinery in Cheshire, and David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, who has made the running since the blockades were called off.

Mr Williams yesterday accused Mr Handley of "running round the country setting up splinter groups."

"He's creating an element of fear among the public," said Mr Williams. "I don't know what his real agenda is." He added there was a risk that "everything that has been gained up to now will be lost".

Mr Handley, 48, who was last week bailed by police after being held overnight following alleged damage to a meat processing plant in Merthyr Tydfil, said of Mr Williams: "Who does he represent? I'm waiting for the man to come out and say who he represents."

The row is partly a battle over leadership and organisation and partly an argument over tactics in the run-up to the 60-day deadline - set by Mr Williams as he called off the blockade at the Stanlow refinery in Cheshire - and the chancellor prepares to reveal his response.

The farmers' and hauliers' groups are unlikely to be satisfied by whatever concessions he makes. But they also know that, given the preparations of government and police, they will not achieve the impact on fuel supplies they had last month by blockading oil refineries.

Among the alternatives being suggested by protest organisers are blockades of supermarket food distribution depots.

The country's five main supermarket chains - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Waitrose - operate around 50 giant warehouses, which are the hub of daily fresh food deliveries. Protesters have blocked individual depots briefly in the past and are convinced they are an easy target. But some protesters fear such a move would alienate public support.

Robert Burns, a leader of last month's Grangemouth blockade, insists: "Unless the government meets our demand and reduces the duty on fuel within the 60 days, all hell will break loose. It will be like Armageddon. People can live without fuel but they can't live without food."

Protest organisers are also considering blockades of ports and feeder terminals, like the St Fergus oil and gas terminal near Aberdeen, which pipes oil from the North Sea and elsewhere down to Grangemouth, Scotland's only refinery. Protesters reckon St Fergus, which needs regular fuel supplies to keep the pumps going, would be easier to shut down than the high-profile Grangemouth.

Orchestrated national grid power surges and main road lorry go-slows could form a third line of attack for protesters. Some groups believe that while police will be able to crack down on motorway blockades - one idea floated publicly this week has nevertheless been to block the M25 - it will be more difficult to stop go-slows on A roads.

But so far the only definite plan is for a national demonstration in London, called for November 14 by Mr Handley's group. "Unless Mr Brown slashes fuel tax," Mr Handley said yesterday, "we intend to bring the country to London and have the fishermen come up the Thames."

But other protest organisers are having none of it, accusing Mr Handley, a Conservative supporter who is also a leader of the direct action group Farmers for Action, of being a failing farmer intent on carving a new career out of his new role.

"North Wales will not be on Handley's march," Clive Swann, one of last month's protest organisers, said yesterday. "Has he been got at, trying to get us all down to London, while the rest of the country's safe? There's no need to form an organisation to make a protest - it leaves you wide open to infiltration by political factions like the National Front."

Richard Haddock, who was spokesman for the blockades in Plymouth, is also critical of the People's Fuel Lobby, set up in Stafford after last month's protest, complaining that "the south-west has never been invited to go to a meeting". He is also a Conservative supporter, but warns other groups against "holding a gun to the head of the government".

Mr Handley rejects the criticism and insists his only agenda is to win a fuel tax cut of 26 pence for the British people. But as the November 13 deadline approaches, Brynle Williams, the original leader of the protests, is angry that any campaigning is currently taking place at all.

"I'm fed up - I said nothing should happen for 60 days," he said yesterday. "One minute I'm the man everyone's supposed to look to and next they're creating splinter groups. What I'm terrified of with these meetings they're holding is that a group of people will kick off somewhere, close a refinery, a supermarket, a petrol station and everything we gained up to now will be lost."

Mr Handley, 48, who was last week bailed by police after being held overnight following alleged damage to a meat processing plant in Merthyr Tydfil, said of Mr Williams: "Who does he represent? I'm waiting for the man to come out and say who he represents." The row is partly a battle over leadership and organisation and partly an argument over tactics in the run-up to the 60-day deadline - set by Mr Williams as he called off the blockade at the Stanlow refinery in Cheshire - and the chancellor prepares to reveal his response. The farmers' and hauliers' groups are unlikely to be satisfied by whatever concessions he makes. But they also know that, given the preparations of government and police, they will not achieve the impact on fuel supplies they had last month by blockading oil refineries. Among the alternatives being suggested by protest organisers are blockades of supermarket food distribution depots. The country's five main supermarket chains - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Waitrose - operate around 50 giant warehouses, which are the hub of daily fresh food deliveries. Protesters have blocked individual depots briefly in the past and are convinced they are an easy target. But some protesters fear such a move would alienate public support. Robert Burns, a leader of last month's Grangemouth blockade, insists: "Unless the government meets our demand and reduces the duty on fuel within the 60 days, all hell will break loose. It will be like Armageddon. People can live without fuel but they can't live without food." Protest organisers are also considering blockades of ports and feeder terminals, like the St Fergus oil and gas terminal near Aberdeen, which pipes oil from the North Sea and elsewhere down to Grangemouth, Scotland's only refinery. Protesters reckon St Fergus, which needs regular fuel supplies to keep the pumps going, would be easier to shut down than the high-profile Grangemouth. Orchestrated national grid power surges and main road lorry go-slows could form a third line of attack for protesters. Some groups believe that while police will be able to crack down on motorway blockades - one idea floated publicly this week has nevertheless been to block the M25 - it will be more difficult to stop go-slows on A roads. But so far the only definite plan is for a national demonstration in London, called for November 14 by Mr Handley's group. "Unless Mr Brown slashes fuel tax," Mr Handley said yesterday, "we intend to bring the country to London and have the fishermen come up the Thames." But other protest organisers are having none of it, accusing Mr Handley, a Conservative supporter who is also a leader of the direct action group Farmers for Action, of being a failing farmer intent on carving a new career out of his new role. "North Wales will not be on Handley's march," Clive Swann, one of last month's protest organisers, said yesterday. "Has he been got at, trying to get us all down to London, while the rest of the country's safe? There's no need to form an organisation to make a protest - it leaves you wide open to infiltration by political factions like the National Front." Richard Haddock, who was spokesman for the blockades in Plymouth, is also critical of the People's Fuel Lobby, set up in Stafford after last month's protest, complaining that "the south-west has never been invited to go to a meeting". He is also a Conservative supporter, but warns other groups against "holding a gun to the head of the government". Mr Handley rejects the criticism and insists his only agenda is to win a fuel tax cut of 26 pence for the British people. But as the November 13 deadline approaches, Brynle Williams, the original leader of the protests, is angry that any campaigning is currently taking place at all. "I'm fed up - I said nothing should happen for 60 days," he said yesterday. "One minute I'm the man everyone's supposed to look to and next they're creating splinter groups. What I'm terrified of with these meetings they're holding is that a group of people will kick off somewhere, close a refinery, a supermarket, a petrol station and everything we gained up to now will be lost."

webTitle: Fuel protests: Intimidation at the blockades

fields.headline: Intimidation at the blockades
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Some of the 183 reported incidents of intimidation:
fields.body:
Some of the 183 reported incidents of intimidation:

Verbal abuse/ offensive gestures

September 12

Birmingham Driver abused by neighbour. Driver's child verbally abused in playground

Grangemouth Drivers called scabs at the terminal and en route

Nottingham Drivers subject to abuse and hand gestures while not under police escort

Manchester Drivers abused when leaving the terminal and called scabs

Poole Drivers are subjected to abusive language and threats

Bristol Drivers are taunted: "We know where you live"

Hamble area Trucks "buzzed" by motorists while on their way to delivery point

 September 13

Stanlow Reports of verbal abuse to distribution vehicle drivers while they are delivering unescorted

Purfleet A car is stopped and surrounded as it leaves the terminal. Protesters subject its occupant to verbal abuse and banged on roof of car

Grangemouth A tanker breaks down on the way to a delivery and its driver is abused and threatened by members of the public

Sunderland Drivers told "We will kill you"

 September 14

Jarrow Drivers harassed by motorists and other truckers

Glasgow A haulage vehicle swerves in an attempt to force the BP tanker off the road

Kingsbury Drivers report verbal abuse from the public

Purfleet Drivers are called scabs and warned not to try to work. Verbal, near-physical abuse at service stations

Missile attacks

 September 8

Stanlow Missiles are thrown at departing tankers

 September 12

Cardiff Objects are thrown from a motorway bridge

September 13

Shell Haven Missiles are thrown at drivers while they attempt to move vehicles out of a company compound

Cardiff Police report that protesters on an M4 motorway bridge are throwing stones _ trucks are diverted

Personal threats and intimidation

 September 8

Stanlow Protesters shout that they will throw bricks at trucks and that drivers' photographs will be posted on the internet

 September 10

Immingham Five tankers are blockaded at a BP Truckstop and forced to return to the terminal

Stanlow Protesters threaten drivers

 September 12

Birmingham Protesters tell a driver that if he leaves the gate with a payload they will seek out his home address.

Bristol A terminal manager is warned that his journey home could be hazardous

Sunderland The police escort is called to an emergency while a tanker en route. The vehicle is then surrounded by protesters and held for over an hour

North Wales Local farmers surround a tanker while it is leaving a delivery point. The driver is forced to lock himself in the cab

 September 13

Jarrow Drivers who are well-known are threatened with reprisals A protest leader from Farmers In Action is arrested at the terminal gates

Sunderland Staff are escorted from terminal by police and warned not to return as the police feel it is unsafe

14 September

Derby Two tankers are blockaded at a delivery point by youths in vans

Physical intimidation

 September 10

Hythe National Front supporters block a gate with bales of hay and threaten they will set them alight.

Purfleet A concerted effort is made by third party to force a tanker off the road even while police are escorting it

 September 11

North-west A white van, travelling in the opposite direction, crosses into the path of a tanker. The driver is unable to evade the truck without endangering other motorists. The white van veers away at the last moment

Dalston A shift supervisor is manhandled near a fuel terminal while attempting to cross the road to discharge a train

Grangemouth The intensity of abuse from protesters is at such a level such that Hoyer/ Esso drivers refuse to work

 September 12

Earlsgate service station A driver and a manager are surrounded by eight angry protesters who were trying to stop them from delivering fuel

Birmingham, Grangemouth, Manchester, Purfleet, Nottingham Photographs are taken of drivers who are hauling terminal on emergency loads

 September 13

Nottingham, Manchester Protesters warn drivers that their photographs will be taken and published on the internet

Liverpool A brick is thrown through a cab window  September 13

Kingsbury Protesters are openly video recording drivers

 September 15

Edinburgh A BP driver is unable to make a fuel delivery at Napier filling station in Edinburgh because of a group of people shouting threats at him and calling him a scab

Phone calls to drivers' homes

 September 11

Dorrington Threatening call is made to a sales office

 September 13-14 Independent collectors receive threatening phone calls to their offices in which they are told to stop collecting fuel, or else
