fields.headline: F is for Flatley - or is it?
fields.standfirst: Judith Mackrell  rues the day she started work on a dictionary of dance
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell rues the day she started work on a dictionary of dance
fields.body:
The new Oxford Dictionary of Dance must rank as one of the year's most authoritative-looking volumes. Its dust jacket is coloured in sober greys and blues, while its contents are laid out in uncluttered, readable type. The facts seem to march confidently from one column to the next, almost as if they had written themselves. But as one of its authors, I know how slippery and quarrelsome those facts really are.

I was commissioned to write the dictionary five years ago, together with another dance critic, Debra Craine of the Times. Both of us, I think, had a notion that we would be dealing with some fixed body of knowledge that would just be waiting for us to sort it into shape. Neither of us had any idea how much detective work and difficult choices would be involved.

Our book had a predecessor - Horst Koegler's impressive Dictionary of Ballet, last updated by the Oxford University Press in 1987 - but our brief was to start again from scratch. Our editors wanted a more reader-friendly book that would encompass the volatile energy of today's dance scene. While retaining all the major historical information, we also needed to open the book up to more populist aspects of dance, such as the Riverdance phenomenon, salsa and hip-hop. But the inclusion of so many new entries meant that we had to delete a lot of those listed in the previous dictionary, and selecting our victims was often difficult - though it did produce the occasional, illicit, iconoclastic thrill.

We intended to include many dancers and choreographers who had emerged in the last 20 years or so, as well as predicting the future prospects of younger artists. Having finally settled on our list, we started the long haul of researching and writing. But the wider we cast our net for source material, the more inconsistencies we encountered. The most trustworthy-seeming tomes started to feel unnervingly inconsistent and it began to dawn on us that there was no such thing as a 100% reliable reference book. Errors by proofreaders and typesetters had leaked into some texts. Worse, we had to navigate sprawling grey areas of interpretation. However objective writers seemed to be, opinion and taste inevitably influenced their descriptions of an artist's career or a company's history. We knew, too, that what we would eventually produce was going to be "the world of dance as seen by Craine and Mackrell".

There were other practical difficulties. We had a hard time winkling out the birth dates of several artists. Dance is a youth-obsessed profession, and many of the men and women we approached were reluctant to disclose their ages.

Dancers' geography can also be hard to pin down, though while I was working on some of the early 19th-century entries I was reminded what a nomadic profession it has always been. There were ballet masters who routinely commuted between Paris and St Petersburg during this period, while in 1840 the ballerina Fanny Elssler embarked on a tour of the Americas with a schedule that would be exhausting even today, with modern methods of transport.

Had we realised what teeth-grindingly frustrating work writing this dictionary would be, I'm not sure we would have embarked on it. But the discipline of reading around the entire subject of dance did throw up some compensatory gems. We had decided early on to incorporate some extra essays and generic entries - partly as background for non-specialist readers, partly as a bit of light relief.

I had serious fun writing our brief entry on socialist realism, sifting through the wackier Soviet examples. (Belsky's Coast of Hope, for instance, contrasted the lifestyles of two fishing villages: a shiny, happy communist village and a grimly exploitative capitalist one.) Researching entries that I thought had only a 20th-century dimension - such as sport or feminism - also threw up ballets of which I'd known nothing. One was Sports of England, choreographed in 1887 by Katti Lanner, a fascinating figure who virtually ran the London ballet scene at a time when directors and choreographers were almost exclusively male. Another was the work La Révolte au Sérail (1833), which portrayed the inmates of a harem banding together with local working women to overthrow the tyranny of men. It was choreographed by a man, Filippo Taglioni.

Spare as most of the entries had to be, some did contain germs of wonderful stories from which we had to drag ourselves away. Before I wrote this dictionary, I had no idea that the dancer and ballet master Leon Espinosa was apparently captured by Indians in 1850 during a tour of north America, nor that the egocentric dancer Louis Duport so incensed the Parisian authorities with his demands that he allegedly escaped their wrath by slipping out of the city disguised as a woman in the company of a former mistress of Napoleon. But these tales will have to wait for another book

 The Oxford Dictionary of Dance is published today, price £25.

fields.headline: Any answers?
fields.trailText: Where did the name for a "Knickerbocker Glory" (ice-cream, syrup, jelly, cream, etc, in a tall glass with a cherry on the top) come from?
fields.body:
Where did the name for a "Knickerbocker Glory" (ice-cream, syrup, jelly, cream, etc, in a tall glass with a cherry on the top) come from?

Tony Carr, Dundas, Ontario.

Is there anyone in Britain under the age of 50 who uses the first-name Reginald?

Reginald Walker (born 1946), Norwich.

Why is the ozone hole principally over the south pole? Vastly more fluorocarbons, from aerosols and refrigerators, must have been released in the industrialised northern hemisphere, so shouldn't they have collected over the north pole?

Lee Simpson, Amersham, Bucks.

Why are all medium- and long-wave radio frequencies divisible by the number nine (for example, Radio 5, 693/ 909; TalkSport, 1053/1089; Radio 4 long-wave, 198)?

John Glackin, Great Linford, Bucks.

A correspondent to my local newspaper recently claimed that the UK has the third lowest tax in the world. Is this true (I don't think tax havens count)? And would this include all tax, or just income tax?

Ian Bee, West Lavington, Wilts.

fields.headline: Chief backs lottery four
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The four regulators held partly responsible for the recent national lottery fiasco are to remain in their posts in an attempt to push through a decision on who should run the game, the lottery commission chairman said yesterday.
fields.body:
The four regulators held partly responsible for the recent national lottery fiasco are to remain in their posts in an attempt to push through a decision on who should run the game, the lottery commission chairman said yesterday.

Despite the debacle - in which a high court judge ruled the commissioners acted illegally in deciding to deal exclusively with Sir Richard Branson's consortium, the People's Lottery, and not the present operators Camelot - the four will continue in the hope that a decision on the rival bids can be reached by mid-November.

Should both groups meet the criteria of being a "fit and proper company" to run the scheme for the next seven years, a decision on which would give the most money to good causes should be reached by mid-December.

Commission chairman Lord Burns, whose predecessor Dame Helena Shovelton resigned following the court defeat, said he had rejected the regulators' offer to resign as their experience was invaluable. "The commission has accepted it made a mistake and the important thing now is to ensure no other mistakes occur."

But he admitted the lottery's reputation could be more severely damaged by a further delay to the decision and said using the present commissioners would avoid this. "If we had to go through a long period of getting new commissioners then it would delay the process by several months. The risks regarding that are much greater than the risks in carrying on."

fields.headline: Air traffic sell-off doomed
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government's controversial plans to sell off Britain's air traffic control service were close to collapse last night amid pressure from the House of Lords and the mounting chaos on the privatised railways.
fields.body:
The government's controversial plans to sell off Britain's air traffic control service were close to collapse last night amid pressure from the House of Lords and the mounting chaos on the privatised railways.

Ministers were preparing for a defeat at the hands of an alliance between the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives, who hope to set up a public trust to run the service, when the delayed transport bill is debated in the Lords today.

The government's official view is that it will not back down from the £500m partial privatisation of the service and that it is ready to send the issue back to the Lords until it gets its way.

But this tactic could delay other legislation. Concerns are already being expressed that the government's plans to tighten up control of the railways and the introduction of congestion charging would be jeopardised by political posturing on air traffic control.

The Department of Transport has prepared contingency plans to drop the air traffic sell-off from the Transport bill.

In a further development yesterday, the department confirmed that the four bidders for the air traffic control privatisation hold possible conflicts of interest. It said that each bidder would have to show how they intended to meet this concern. They are all being closely examined by the government.

There are also fears that the creation of a public-private partnership could lead to a further sale of air traffic control to individual airport operators.

The proposed sell-off has been plagued with difficulties. Political pressure to drop the plans has been dramatically heightened by the collapse of the rail industry in the past week and an admission by Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, that privatisation has led to fragmentation and a less safe railway.

Leaders of the air traffic controllers' union (IPMS), said yesterday the government's plans to sell off the service could repeat some of the faults of previous privatisations.

Paul Noon, the controllers' leader, said: "After all we have learnt in the recent days, it is nothing short of incredible that the government should choose this moment to privatise air traffic control.

"The service provided by Nats [National Air Traffic Services] is the safest and most successful of any form of transport in the country. It is a model for the railways and we should thank God for its existence. But it could be wrecked by this dangerous experiment."

Mr Noon said the government claimed the sell-off would enable Nats to invest in equipment, but that could not be guaranteed. "Experience of Railtrack has shown that you can lead a horse to water but you cannot make it drink."

Political pressure to drop the plans has been dramatically heightened by the collapse of the rail industry in the past week and an admission by Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, that privatisation has led to fragmentation and a less safe railway. Leaders of the air traffic controllers' union (IPMS), said yesterday the government's plans to sell off the service could repeat some of the faults of previous privatisations. Paul Noon, the controllers' leader, said: "After all we have learnt in the recent days, it is nothing short of incredible that the government should choose this moment to privatise air traffic control. "The service provided by Nats [National Air Traffic Services] is the safest and most successful of any form of transport in the country. It is a model for the railways and we should thank God for its existence. But it could be wrecked by this dangerous experiment." Mr Noon said the government claimed the sell-off would enable Nats to invest in equipment, but that could not be guaranteed. "Experience of Railtrack has shown that you can lead a horse to water but you cannot make it drink."

webTitle: Inland Revenue writes off millions to solve backlog

fields.headline: Inland Revenue writes off millions to solve backlog
fields.trailText: The government is to let the Inland Revenue close 1m unresolved tax records in an effort to cope with a mounting backlog.
fields.body:
The government is to let the Inland Revenue close 1m unresolved tax records in an effort to cope with a mounting backlog.

The decision means that the revenue may never know whether under, over, or non-payments have been made on affected records for the 12 months ending 1998.

As a result, taxpayers may be entitled to claim compensation for mistakes and the Treasury could lose vast amounts of cash.

The files are to be closed to allow revenue staff to concentrate on the black hole in records which has opened up in the wake of problems involving its computerised database for taxpayers.

The move follows a leaked memo which revealed that the 1998/99 records on 5.2m taxpayers - almost 20% of the British workforce - could not be found anywhere on the computer system. There are now thought to be at least 8m unresolved records held by the taxman - compared with just 2.5m in 1998.

In a letter to Computer Weekly, which broke the story, the source of the leak said that the jump in unresolved cases could lead to "large-scale losses to the revenue".

The latest measure, approved by the paymaster general, Dawn Primarolo, will go some way to easing the vicious circle that is engulfing the revenue. At present, unresolved files are holding up the completion of subsequent records, which, in turn, add to the burden.

In the latest leaked memo, seen by the Guardian, the revenue said: "The large number of missing pay and tax items for 1998/9... means that we have again to consider the possibility of automatically Z-ing cases without pay and tax."

"Z-ing" is a last resort measure that closes a taxpayer's computer file for the year even if the information needed to do so has not been found.

John Gwyer, the director of taxation investigations at the chartered accountants Pannell Kerr Forster, said that the revenue's move was " unacceptable".

"In an age in which the Inland Revenue claims to be user-friendly, how are those who have over-paid tax, and do not realise it, going to find out about it?" he said. "It is unacceptable to simply say it's all down to a computer error."

A spokeswoman for the revenue defended the decision, adding that records could still be re-opened and completed if relevant information comes to light.

"It is a business decision - taken every year - and the judgment was made that it wasn't worth following up on these files," she said.

Last night the Inland Revenue advised anyone who thinks they may be due a repayment of tax to contact their tax office.

At the centre of the crisis are two computer systems which are managed by different private sector firms. Many files appear to have gone missing somewhere between the two.

The interface, which is called COP/CORR, is meant to link information on the the National Insurance Recording System (Nirs2) to COP, the revenue's system.

Nirs2 is managed by Andersen Consulting under a seven-year outsourcing agreement, while the COP system is run by the information technology firm EDS.

fields.headline: Have you no shame?
fields.standfirst: Scandals: they're not what they used to be. As EastEnders' 15-year-old Sonia Jackson heads for the maternity ward,  Rupert Smith  looks at how soaps' attitudes to teenage pregnancies have mellowed over the years
fields.trailText: Scandals: they're not what they used to be. As EastEnders' 15-year-old Sonia Jackson heads for the maternity ward, Rupert Smith looks at how soaps' attitudes to teenage pregnancies have mellowed over the years
fields.body:
Tonight, while preparing a tasty meal for her tasty boyfriend, Sonia Jackson, aged 15, will go into labour. If this can happen to the most sensible character in EastEnders, then teenage pregnancy must really be getting out of hand. She had it coming, of course - ever since she got lucky with Jamie Mitchell, Fate has been waiting to even the balance - but, generally speaking, Sonia is not the sort of girl to whom these things happen.

Sonia Jackson is one of a new breed of young soap mothers. She's intelligent, hard-working, conscientious, and most emphatically not the Town Bike. She allowed Martin Fowler to get a bit carried away earlier in the year, but that's no reflection on her - Martin would probably get carried away with Mo Harris if the lighting was low. Sonia did all the right things - she realised what had happened, confided in an older friend, got a pregnancy test (negative) and then chalked it up to experience. When Jackson Junior arrives tonight, nobody is more surprised than Sonia (although her recent weight gain might have given her a clue).

Rewind 13 years to the grim and gritty early years of EastEnders, when soap's most memorable single mother, "Punk" Mary Smith, prowled the Square with haystack hair and Siouxsie eye make-up. Mary was old-school: an anti-social runaway who supported baby Annie by stripping and prostitution. Not only was she a single mother, Mary was a bad mother, leaving little Annie home alone while she went out to hustle a few bucks for baby food. The cot blanket caught fire and Albert Square was very nearly one baby down. Mary struggled ineffectually to straighten herself out, but it was no good: she had to go.

Less sensational, but equally loaded, was the case of Michelle Fowler. Ostensibly one of soap's sensible girls, Michelle suffered bouts of dementia, during one of which she became pregnant by Den Watts, her best friend's father, and then named the baby Victoria after the pub he ran. Nobody twigged, and Michelle staunchly protected the identity of her mystery baby. She decided to go it alone, an icon of independent young womanhood (apart from the odd furtive session with Dirty Den, who slipped her wads of hush money). This was bold stuff for soaps in the 80s, when single/teenage motherhood was still a semi-shameful subject; Michelle's courage and integrity helped, perhaps, to blow away the last shreds of stigma.

"There's always a balance between a strong storyline and public respon sibility," says John Yorke, EastEnders' executive producer. "Because we have such a massive audience, we know we're contributing to awareness on certain issues, but we try not to be tied down by that. People will soon get fed up if they think they're being preached to, so I'd say we never take a moralistic stance. In the case of Sonia, we wanted to do a storyline about sexual naivety. Sonia was the perfect character for it: she's bright and educated, but ironically she's ignorant about her own body. The shift, I'd say, is that 10 or 15 years ago teenage pregnancy was presented as something that happened to promiscuous girls who went out 'looking for it'. Now it's seen more as a consequence of ignorance. It's harder for anyone to disapprove of that."

And EastEnders is by no means the first to explore this territory. A few months ago and several miles north, Coronation Street's Sarah-Louise Platt (13) gave birth to baby Bethany, went back to school to complete her education and faced nothing more than a bit of gentle playground teasing. Meanwhile her grandmother Audrey reflected bitterly on her own experience of teenage motherhood, forced by parental pressure to give up her son for adoption. Attitudes have changed even in conservative Weatherfield. The last time Corrie had a single mother - Andrea Clayton, who fell pregnant at 18 after an encounter with Terry Duckworth - her folks were so ashamed that they upped sticks and left the series. Sarah-Louise, however, remains firmly in the warm bosom of the family.

Trust Brookside to put an absurd spin on the issue. Lindsay Corkhill turned herself into a Merseyside Mildred Pierce to support baby Kylie, now eight. She grafted, she schemed, she ran a nightclub and dreamed of a better life for her daughter until gangsters blew the place sky high. Now Lindsay's learned her lesson and is settling down to respectable single parenthood, ably assisted by Jimmy and Jackie. She has been punished enough.

Brookside aside, soaps are happier, fluffier places than they used to be. Sonia's accidental motherhood won't be easy for her, but she won't face crushing social opprobrium every time she wheels the buggy through the Square. In part, this is an accurate reflection of relaxing social attitudes to a whole range of issues - illegitimacy, underage sex, homosexuality, and so on - that were once the cause of tragedy and shame both in real life and in soap. To some extent, soaps have led the way out of the darkness. But without tragedy, shame and melodrama, will we still be gripped as we were in the darker days of the 80s?

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Natural: Mythic story of a baseball hero that charmingly preserves the magical universe of Bernard Malamud's novel.
fields.body:
The Natural

(Barry Levinson, 1984)

6pm, FilmFour

Mythic story of a baseball hero that charmingly preserves the magical universe of Bernard Malamud's novel. Robert Redford plays superhuman hitter Roy Hobbs who, with his bat Wonderboy - fashioned from the wood of a lightning blasted tree, is on the verge of a great career until fate turns against him. Then, years on, he's offered a second chance. Like Phil Alden Robinson's Field Of Dreams, an affecting teaming of sport and the supernatural. Cast includes Robert Duvall, Glenn Close and Kim Basinger.

The Rainmaker

(Francis Ford Coppola, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Assured adaptation of a John Grisham novel, with Matt Damon (pictured) as the novice lawyer working for Mickey Rourke's dodgy ambulance chaser, but taking up the worthy cause of a leukaemia sufferer against a giant insurance corporation. With Coppola at the helm, Michael Douglas producing, and a top-notch cast - Jon Voight, Danny De Vito, Claire Danes, Danny Glover - it's a well-nigh flawless Hollywood drama, with welcome shafts of humour.

Tin Men

(Barry Levinson, 1987)

8.20pm, FilmFour

Levinson again, with a richly comic tale of the titanic clash between two aluminium siding salesmen. Danny De Vito and Richard Dreyfuss are the "tin men", whose cars crunch heavily into each other's lives, with De Vito's wife Barbara Hershey becoming a pawn in their feud. A vividly realised early 60s milieu, and finely acted.

The Siege

(Edward Zwick, 1998)

10.15pm, Sky Premier

Muslim terrorists are bombing New York, and the forces of law and order are trying to catch them. The goodies are Denzel Washington's FBI man, Annette Bening's cunning National Security operative and Bruce Willis's army general. It may sound like crass action-movie guff, but confrontations over issues of civil liberty and the limits of security measures are as gripping as the explosive stuff.

fields.headline: Manners maketh man
fields.trailText: Richard II was the first Englishman to blow his nose. Not many people know that, but Simon Shama does. In A History Of Britain (BBC2), he said "Richard was built the usual Plantagenet way, six foot tall with long, flowing, blonde hair.
fields.body:
The plague full swift goes by

I am sick, I must die.

Lord have mercy on us!

- Thomas Nashe

Richard II was the first Englishman to blow his nose. Not many people know that, but Simon Shama does. In A History Of Britain (BBC2), he said "Richard was built the usual Plantagenet way, six foot tall with long, flowing, blonde hair. But real Plantagenets tore at their meat and slurped the drippings. Richard insisted on using a spoon. Real Plantagenets brought you blood-soaked victories over the ancestral enemies in France and Scotland. Richard brought England the pocket handkerchief."

The historian Arthur Bryant wrote that the sleeves of Richard's doublet were "hung with 15 silver cockles and 30 mussels and whelks in silver gilt." Indistinguishable, then, from Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen? Several promising professions leap to mind for Richard, but king is not one of them.

He came to the throne when he was 10 years old. In one of those thumbnail sketches which bring the past touchingly to life, Schama told how the sleeping child was carried from his own coronation, his oversized shoe slipping from his swinging foot. He also called him Little Richard, which rather threw you, suggesting, as it did, that he was hot stuff on the old harpsichord.

This was the programme about the plague which killed half the population. It didn't, however, kill Richard. You just knew he would be punctilious about personal cleanliness. Who would have suspected anything as insignificant as a flea? The ravenous progress of the plague was recorded by a Kilkenny priest, who speaks to me across the centuries. The man was a good journalist. Waiting for death, he wrote: "I am committed to writing what I truly have heard and examined and I leave parchment for continuing this work if, perchance, any man survive to carry on the work I have begun."

Another hand has written underneath: "Here, it seems, the author died."

There was a line in this week's Scarlet Pimpernel (BBC1), "Knowing where you have been is as important as knowing where you are going", which explains the whole why and wherefore of A History Of Britain.

Sir Percy's cry of "Gunpowder, treason and plot!" and a lavish firework display made this Pimpernel an unusually topical frolic.

The leg-pulling, educated script by Alan Whiting - in which William Turner had a small part and Isaac Newton a friendly mention - turned on the invention of a hand-grenade by the heroine. By happy chance, she was the world's greatest living scientist, and pretty chippy about it too. "Surely you are not suggesting that that a woman doesn't have the mental capacity to grasp the subject of chemistry?" Sir Percy, who had been playing with his balls all evening and had developed a useful yorker, bowled her bomb over Robespierre's railings. The heroine had urged him to try an unorthodox overarm delivery. Being French, she did not know that in the 18th century, underarm bowling was de rigueur .

The bomb not only demolished the guillotine ("Well bowled, sir!") but blew off Robespierre's wig. Robespierre seems to be a proxy Sheriff of Nottingham in these stories, regularly getting it in the neck in the last reel. That both the Sheriff of Nottingham and Robespierre are French gives the whole thing a cheerier frisson.

The Pimpernel's immediate adversary, in this episode, was General La Forge, a trying visitor who always knocks the door down with a battering ram. You could tell them apart because the Pimpernel (Richard E Grant) wore his hat east and west, and La Forge (Jim Cartwright) wore his north and south. Very like the Duke of Wellington and Napoleon, only vice versa, if you follow me. Half the secret of costume drama is the ability to wear silly hats with insouciance.

Why do I keep talking French? It's not catching, is it?

Meanwhile, half Coronation Street (ITV) is gallivanting in France as well. Paris being the aphrodisiac it is, Audrey Roberts is zeroing in on Fred Elliot like a heat-seeking missile on a big bonfire. Fred is unusually big and, as they say up north, a very warm man.

webTitle: AT&T revamp plan wins few fans

fields.headline: AT&T revamp plan wins few fans
fields.standfirst: Divergent lines
fields.trailText: AT&T, America's largest telecommunications company, yesterday announced a radical restructuring plan designed to improve its flagging share price and allow it to compete more effectively in fast-growing markets.
fields.body:
AT&T, America's largest telecommunications company, yesterday announced a radical restructuring plan designed to improve its flagging share price and allow it to compete more effectively in fast-growing markets.

The most significant restructuring of the former monopoly since the US government forced it to break itself up in 1984 did not manage to impress shareholders. Shares in the group fell 13% after the announcement that it would be split into four divisions - wireless, broadband, business and long-distance consumers services.

Several analysts issued downgrades prompted by fears that revenues would continue to fall as the reorganisation, expected to take at least two years, caused turmoil.

In a note to investors explaining his decision to downgrade the company yesterday, Adam Quinton, analyst at Merrill Lynch, wrote: "In our view, the market will be troubled by the revenue trends at AT&T."

The company reported worse-than-expected third-quarter earnings yesterday and warned that the current quarter would also disappoint because of the performance of AT&T's consumer and business divisions. The business services division increased sales by only 2.5 % in the quarter.

Michael Armstrong, chairman and chief executive of the business, insisted yesterday that the proposals would be good for shareholders. "Underpinning these changes is ... the foundation for shareholder value."

Shares in the company were trading just $2 above a year's low of $21.25 yesterday morning after falling more than two-thirds since April. Shareholders have criticised the company for failing to address the problem of the increasingly competitive market for long-distance residential calls in America.

At the same time, questions have been raised about whether Mr Armstrong's plan to create a telecommunications powerhouse would prevent the wireless and broadband divisions from growing as fast as they could.

AT&T has spent more than $100bn buying between 20 and 30 companies in the cable and broadband sectors since Mr Armstrong took control of the business in 1997.

Yesterday he denied that the four-way split represented a strategic about-turn after publicly resisting pressure to split for several months. "Our strategy has been consistent since we started this journey in 1998," he said.

In 1997, AT&T's growth businesses, such as wireless, accounted for only about 20% of group revenues, compared to 50% this year, Mr Armstrong said.

AT&T announced its acquisition of cable group Media One almost two years ago, a deal which made it the largest cable provider in the US and boosted its ability to supply broadband internet access to consumers and business customers. In spite of these acquisitions, however, its results have been dragged down by limited growth in its more traditional operations.

Mr Armstrong denied that the demerger plans had been instigated by John Malone, the head of Liberty Media who sits on AT&T's board.

Mr Armstrong, 62, said he intended remain as head of AT&T in order to oversee the demerger - a complicated series of transactions which are expected to take between 12 and 24 months. "This is quite a task to implement successfully," he said. "I intend to be chairman and chief executive to get this thing done."

Shares in the group fell 13% after the announcement that it would be split into four divisions - wireless, broadband, business and long-distance consumers services. The business services division increased sales by only 2.5 % in the quarter. "Underpinning these changes is ... the foundation for shareholder value." webTitle: Secretary 'sacked for going to ill son'

fields.headline: Secretary 'sacked for going to ill son'
fields.standfirst: Mother's claim for unfair dismissal tests law giving parents the right to time off
fields.trailText: A single mother who was sacked after telling her boss she needed to leave work to collect her sick son from school is suing her employers for unfair dismissal.
fields.body:
A single mother who was sacked after telling her boss she needed to leave work to collect her sick son from school is suing her employers for unfair dismissal.

Julie Percy claims she was fired from her job as a secretary in March because she asked for time off to look after her son Thomas, then aged seven. If she is successful it will be the first case to be won under the Maternity and Parental Leave Act 1999, which states that employees have a right to take time off work to care for dependants.

Ms Percy, 35, was working for chartered surveyors Metcalfe and Co, in Moss Nook, near Manchester, for five weeks when she was sacked.

She had received a call from her son's school, saying that he had a temperature and a discharge from his ear. She told Michael Oates, the company principal, that she needed to collect him and make alternative childcare arrangements.

But by the time she had got her coat and gone downstairs, another colleague told her she was to be sacked. Ms Percy told an employment tribunal in Manchester yesterday that she was told this was because she was "unreliable".

"I take the view that I have been dismissed as a result of my request to take time off to look after my son," she said.

But Mr Oates denied that he had sacked Ms Percy because of her request for time off, claiming instead that she was "rude and aggressive" and "entirely antisocial".

He said that she flung documents and files on his desk "without a please or thank you", and if asked to type an amendment to a letter would "snatch the documents and storm out".

He had decided to fire her in February because of her attitude, he said, and had drafted a letter of dismissal but later ripped it up, deciding to give her another chance.

But John Cook, representing Ms Percy, said Mr Oates drafted the letter in response to an earlier occasion when Ms Percy was late for work because her son was ill. He said neither Mr Oates nor any other member of staff had raised Ms Percy's alleged "attitude problem" with her while she worked at the company.

In summing up, David Berkley QC, representing Metcalfe and Co, said: "This woman did not fit into this office because of her attitude, because of her impertinence and because of the way she was rankling the most senior member of staff, Mr Oates."

But Mr Cook said: "In my submission there is no getting away from the fact that she was sacked five minutes after making the request [to go to collect her son]."

The tribunal reserved its decision.

webTitle: Nylon suit offers bottom line on builders' cleavage

fields.headline: Nylon suit offers bottom line on builders' cleavage
fields.trailText: Britain may soon be spared the builders' trademark of two buttocks fighting their way out of a pair of sagging jeans.
fields.body:
Britain may soon be spared the builders' trademark of two buttocks fighting their way out of a pair of sagging jeans.

Peter Bowry, 34, a roofer from Manchester, has designed a nylon two-piece suit for builders after 18 years of working on sites in jeans that slipped to show his backside.

Mr Bowry started making the water resistant suits in December last year with his sister who is a machinist. The trousers are made of breathable nylon with a high waist and straps to keep them in position.

With support from a government new business scheme, Mr Bowry produced seven prototypes which he has tested on a joiner, a mechanic and a road cableman. The workers found they were hard-wearing and easy to move in. Mr Bowry hopes to sell the jackets and trousers for £50 each, through retailers.

"It is not builders' faults that they reveal their bottoms. Jeans come down because they are made of cotton and go saggy after a day's wear," he said.

Mr Bowry said builders' bottom was not just ugly, an exposed lower back in winter was bad for the kidneys and spine.

A spokesman for the Transport and General Workers Union said: "There is such a lack of safety culture in construction that anything that gives the industry a kick up the bum should be welcomed."

webTitle: Teacher in slapping case cleared to go back to work

fields.headline: Teacher in slapping case cleared to go back to work
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was cleared of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, was last night given the all clear to return to work.
fields.body:
Headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was cleared of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, was last night given the all clear to return to work.

The board of governors at St Mary's primary school, in Caldicot, Gwent, held a special meeting which lasted nearly four hours.

The suspension was placed on Mrs Evans last September after she was charged with slapping a 10-year-old special needs pupil.

She was convicted of the assault in July but cleared on appeal last month. But the suspension remained in place because police were investigating further claims of pupil mistreatment.

The Crown Prosecution Service announced on Monday that no further action would be taken against Mrs Evans.

The CPS examined 33 witness statements and records of interviews concerning the 10 allegations of cruelty against 11 children at St Mary's. Police were told there was no realistic prospect of conviction.

Mrs Evans said: "I'm delighted and relieved that this nightmare now seems to be drawing to a close. From the outset I have maintained my innocence and am glad that justice has finally been done."

She added: "The past 13 months have been a terribly stressful ordeal for my family and me. I am now looking forward to returning as headteacher to St Mary's following the agreed period of absence and consideration."

At last month's appeal hearing at Cardiff crown court, Mr Justice McKinnon, quashing Mrs Evans's conviction after a trial before Abergavenny magistrates in July, said evidence against her was "conflicting" and "unsatisfactory".

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "I am delighted that this lengthy period of torment is now over for Marjorie Evans.

"She has suffered a great deal during the time she has been suspended. I trust the school will be able to return to normal and Marjorie to her post within the not too distant future."
Press Association

fields.headline: Cell killing accused's 'history of violence'
fields.trailText: A racist prisoner charged with murdering an Asian inmate was allowed to share a cell with his alleged victim despite a record of violent assaults on fellow prisoners in the years leading up to the attack, Kingston crown court in south west London heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A racist prisoner charged with murdering an Asian inmate was allowed to share a cell with his alleged victim despite a record of violent assaults on fellow prisoners in the years leading up to the attack, Kingston crown court in south west London heard yesterday.

Zahid Mubarak, 19, from Walthamstow, east London, was beaten to death with a table leg on the last night of a 90 day sentence for dishonesty at Feltham young offenders' institution in March. He was sharing a cell with Robert Stewart, 20, who denies his murder. Stewart was on remand having just completed a custodial sentence.

The jury heard that in a 12 month period Stewart stabbed a fellow prisoner under the eye, was found with knife blades in his possession and threatened to take a cookery teacher hostage "and carve him up".

A senior prison officer, writing on Stewart's file, which was read to the court by Anthony Evans QC, defending, said: "He may come across as a weakling but he is an extremely dangerous individual."

Stewart's prison file contained a litany of incidents including burning his cell, throwing everything including his mattress out of the window, flooding his cell, attempting to dismantle it in order to escape, suicide attempts and setting himself on fire.

The court also heard prison officers state that the weapon with which Mr Mubarak was attacked could have gone undetected for more than two months. The table leg had been snapped off and then replaced to prop up the table, but would not necessarily have been found during routine searches.

Another weapon, a wooden "gagger" fashioned from a broken piece of the table, was found under Stewart's pillow.

The court was told that on the night of the murder, Graham Davis, the senior officer, ordered that Stewart be taken to an unfurnished cell to await the police. Instead he was taken to a cell with a hand basin where he was able to wash blood from his hands and destroy potential evidence.

Press Association

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: The hedges are all shades of red, fuchsia still in flower, rose hips, hawthorn laden with berries. Never have I seen such a harvest of berries- the spikiness of the whitethorn is quite hidden. Time to tackle my autumn walk by Mullaghmore.
fields.body:
The hedges are all shades of red, fuchsia still in flower, rose hips, hawthorn laden with berries. Never have I seen such a harvest of berries- the spikiness of the whitethorn is quite hidden. Time to tackle my autumn walk by Mullaghmore.

Grey skies darkened the afternoon, bringing out the contrasting orange, pale yellow and green of the hazel's ribbed leaves. I came into the open, and lovely Mullaghmore mountain rose before me; its terraced steeps, by a quirk of shadow, seemed weightless, fragile, almost ready to take off. The turlough, Lock Gealain (disappearing lake) was full to the brim. I walked on by Teampall Phadraig (Patrick's Temple), by Loch Da Ean (Lake of Two Birds), wondering at the beautiful yellow of the blackthorn leaves. Starlings streamed above.

On my return to Mullaghmore I noticed a water garden, bordered by low blackthorn bushes, shrubby cinquefoil, hazel and one spindle-tree, its pink berries dangling, mirrored in clear water, fed by a spring rising gently among moss-covered stones. I have never visited Mullaghmore without coming upon some wonder that fills the heart with gladness. But I came home to anxiety.

I looked out at the sea, at the land-spit, the Rine, that tapers out into the Bay. Jo and Sheila Burns' cattle were isolated at the end, the rising tide cutting them off. I phoned an alert but, as the light faded and sea rose, we had to watch the water reach the cattle's knees and then their stomachs. The creatures huddled together, unpanicked; but got safely home at midnight and have been well pampered since.

webTitle: Leader: The Commons needs radical change

fields.headline: Sweep out the stables
fields.standfirst:
The Commons needs radical change

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: After just three short months of holiday, the good folk of the Westminster village knew they had better return with a bang. So they laid on a couple of treats. On Monday we had the seven-hour marathon election for a new Speaker, culminating in the elevation of Michael Martin. And yesterday we had the first session of prime minister's questions since July.
fields.body:
After just three short months of holiday, the good folk of the Westminster village knew they had better return with a bang. So they laid on a couple of treats. On Monday we had the seven-hour marathon election for a new Speaker, culminating in the elevation of Michael Martin. And yesterday we had the first session of prime minister's questions since July. Surely these delights would remind voters what we had been missing all this time, restoring parliament once more to its rightful place at the centre of Britain's national life.

Did they heck. Both events have served the reverse purpose, providing a full-colour illustration of why Westminster has become such a sideshow to our democracy that a consummate parliamentarian like Tony Benn can joke, with good reason, that he is quitting the house - to devote more time to politics.

We have already noted that the method of the Speaker's election was farcical, an arcane procedure wholly removed from common sense and contemporary democracy. Yesterday Mr Martin sought to bring a breath of modernity to his ancient office by holding a first-ever press conference in the Speaker's apartments. Oddly, his action confirmed the very assumption he and his predecessor, Betty Boothroyd, so vehemently oppose: that the way to communicate with the nation these days is not via the floor of the House of Commons, but through the media.

His comments do not augur well. He said reform of the chamber and its creaking practices was not a matter for him, but rather for MPs. The best he could offer was a promise not to be a "block" on change. This is a wretched shame since, as we argued all summer through the non-campaign campaign, what Westminster needs above all is a reforming Speaker.

Proof of that came yesterday with the return of prime minister's questions. Once again, 20 minutes of rehearsed ding-dong between a clear-voiced and practised William Hague and an efficient, if less fluent Tony Blair. Once again, it was Mr Blair banging on about the five tests for British entry into the euro and Mr Hague offering some well-honed gags. Once again, the benches lit up only when a member stumbled or became tongue-tied, marking the Commons out as a particularly cruel kind of public school. Enlightenment, or even genuine engagement, came there none.

For all Mr Martin's nonchalance, the Commons is crying out for change. It is fast sinking into irrelevance, visible in the empty green benches or the fact that a national debate, like the one during the fuel crisis, could comfortably take place without it. Yet this is our elected chamber. If it slides into oblivion, then so does our democracy. We need it to work.

There is no shortage of ideas. The secretary of the Hansard Society has argued on these pages for fewer, shorter sessions in the full chamber, freeing MPs to pursue the tough work of scrutiny in committee - with the plenary reserved for set-piece interrogations of ministers and major debates. He wants daytime sitting, so that Westminster deliberations can fall within broadcast and print media deadlines, so winning more public attention. Others speak of electronic voting to speed efficiency or a professionalisation of research.

The problem is not a lack of ideas, but the absence of political will to drive them through. If the Speaker refuses to be an engine for change, then reform-minded MPs must take on the task themselves - backed by all who want to see our democracy flourish. Mr Martin says he will not stand in the way. Let us hold him to that.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Julian Pettifer (pictured) looks at a potentially explosive political issue that's attracted little general attention. In Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) he talks to Basques living on the northern side of the Pyrenees.
fields.body:
Julian Pettifer (pictured) looks at a potentially explosive political issue that's attracted little general attention. In Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) he talks to Basques living on the northern side of the Pyrenees.

Unlike their fellows in Spain, who have their own parliament, police force and educational system, French Basques remain unrecognised by the government. They want a separate Basque département and official recognition of their language. They're also becoming exasperated by the lack of response from Paris.

In the second programme about wartime internment of innocent people by democratic governments, Behind The Wire (8.0pm, Radio 4) rightly recalls America's long history of racist legislation against Japanese immigrants.It should have come as no surprise that the constitution offered little protection to Japanese-Americans after Tokyo's attack on Pearl Harbor. But, unlike Britain, Washington eventually acknowledged the injustice of what happened and paid compensation.

fields.headline: Dignified Speaker sees off gang of Tory snipers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: The new Speaker
fields.trailText: Many Scottish people have written and emailed to complain about my comments on the new Speaker's Glaswegian accent.
fields.body:
Many Scottish people have written and emailed to complain about my comments on the new Speaker's Glaswegian accent. The Scottish press has also been deeply upset, but then the Scottish press thinks that everything in the London papers is anti-Scots, including the lottery numbers.

However, I have clearly caused much offence to our countrymen in the north, who feel that their culture has been unfairly traduced for the sake of a cheap joke. Therefore I am happy to say that, on reflection, it is time to redouble my efforts.

For example, yesterday the new Speaker, Michael Martin, held a press conference in the Speaker's house, which is a sort of impossibly grand maisonette built into the Palace of Westminster. He revealed that his wife did not feel comfortable there, and would rather stay in their flat in Pimlico.

This is a refreshing change from the lord chancellor, who also has a house built into the palace.

He caused much controversy by having hundreds of thousands spent to make the place look even more magnificent.

Perhaps Mr Martin will now spend a similar sum to do the opposite. He could have the ceilings lowered, the hot water pipes ripped out and a communal washing area with a stone sink put between his place and Derry Irvine's.

The Tories would go wild. "How can the government justify the spending of £8.79 on a new outside privy for the Speaker's house? Not since the grotesque waste of money on the dome..."

But yesterday Mr Martin faced a test worse than any offered by the hacks. The Tory awkward squad ganged up on him. They don't like him, they feel he won the election on a rigged vote, they think he ought to be a Tory, and they reckon he's an easy target. On yesterday's showing they may well be wrong.

Eric Forth, who must have been a Flashman figure in his day, toasting new bugs at the fire, produced a pompous rigmarole about how Betty Boothroyd had tried to prevent ministers from making public statements before they came to the Commons. "Yet today you gave a press conference outside the house before you'd been able to share your thoughts with members of the house."

Given that the normal mode of address to the Speaker is oleaginous toadying, this was astoundingly rude.

Mr Martin met the attack with dignity. He had done it to protect his family, he said; they had been inundated by journalists, and he hoped this would call them off. "I will never stop you from speaking to whoever you want to speak to, and you will not stop me."

As for Betty Boothroyd, "I have the highest respect for her, but she is gone... Betty is no longer with us," he said, making that sprightly lady sound like an much loved old family pet who'd had to be put down.

David Winnick accused the Tories of "sniping and spite" at the new Speaker.

He refused the bait. "I have heard no sniping and spite. Everybody likes the Speaker." This remark, which translates as "you all try to suck up to the Speaker", was the first recorded Martin joke.

John Bercow tried to fool him with a long, convoluted question about John Prescott's absence from the debate on the fuel crisis. Mr Martin stopped him dead with a trick answer: "No".

It's too early to be sure, but after two days it looks as if the new man might just be settling in.

A final thought. The new Speaker is a Scot. So are the chancellor of the exchequer and the foreign secretary, plus - let us give him his full title - the lord chancellor of England.

The prime minister was educated in Scotland. So why do so many Scots regard themselves as an unjustly oppressed minority?

fields.headline: Opposition acts to impeach Mugabe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The mood was electric in Zimbabwe's packed parliament when the opposition began impeachment proceedings yesterday against President Robert Mugabe, further eroding his political authority.
fields.body:
The mood was electric in Zimbabwe's packed parliament when the opposition began impeachment proceedings yesterday against President Robert Mugabe, further eroding his political authority.

The articles of impeachment were delivered by Gibson Sibanda, vice-president of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), to the Speaker, Emmerson Mnangagwa. More than a third of the MPs had signed them.

The 57 MDC members cried "Yes, yes, today is the day!" and the 92 members of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF shouted "Shame! This is nonsense. A waste of time!"

The impeachment has scant chance of gaining the necessary two-thirds majority, but it will focus attention on Mr Mugabe's record, including his disastrous management of the economy and his incitement of political violence.

It is the first time impeachment has been used in Africa against a head of state.

"It shows that the MDC is doing everything it can in parliament and using the law to bring an end to the rule of a dictator," one of the party's MPs, Job Sikhala, said.

The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, said: "The MDC has been watching too much television and think they can act like the US Congress did against Bill Clinton. It is pure fantasy to think the president can be impeached. These people are just dreaming of Rhodesia. President Mugabe will not pay any attention to such frivolity."

A Gallup poll yesterday showed that Mr Mugabe's popularity has plummeted in recent months: 74% of Zimbabweans wanted him to leave office and 51% said he should be put on trial.

It showed a collapse of support in the rural areas which were his stronghold until a few months ago.

His economic mismanagement, land seizures, violence against the opposition, involvement in the Congo war and rhetoric against whites were rejected by more than 70% of those interviewed in both urban and rural areas.

Mr Mugabe responded by hardening his attack on whites, saying he would revoke the policy of racial reconciliation and put the former Rhodesian leader Ian Smith on trial for crimes against humanity during the 1970s war for majority rule.

He addressed a band of about 400 supporters, who then marched through Harare and surrounded the House of Assembly, carrying printed placards which declared: "Impeach the Chief Justice, not our President", and "Dissolve Parliament".

They were able to get to the front door of the parliamentary chamber without police hindrance, although similar gatherings of MDC supporters are quickly tear-gassed, beaten and arrested.

The impeachment document charges Mr Mugabe with "willful violation of the constitution" and "gross misconduct".

Many MDC supporters want mass action against Mr Mugabe but the party leaders fear that would lead to massacres.

webTitle: The best sandwich scene: This is Spinal Tap

fields.headline: The best sandwich scene: This is Spinal Tap
fields.trailText: Backstage, guitarist Nigel Tufnell (Christopher Guest) sits disconsolately beside a tray of sandwiches as manager Ian Faith (Tony Hendra) walks in.
fields.body:
Backstage, guitarist Nigel Tufnell (Christopher Guest) sits disconsolately beside a tray of sandwiches as manager Ian Faith (Tony Hendra) walks in.

"Ian, can I have a word with you a minute?"

"Yes, of course."

"There's, uh... a couple of problems with the..."

"What?"

"... uh, arrangements backstage. There's some problems here. I don't even know where to start..."

"What? What's wrong?"

"This."

Nigel picks up a sandwich.

"Look... this, this miniature bread. It's like... I've been working with this now for about half an hour. I can't figure it out. Let's say I want a bite, right, you've got this..."

He holds up the sandwich for Ian's inspection.

"You'd like bigger bread?"

"Exactly! I don't understand how..."

"You could fold it though."

"Well, no, then it's half the size..."

"Not the bread. You could fold the meat."

Nigel tears the sandwich in half.

"Yeah, but then it, then it...breaks apart like this."

Ian tries to demonstrate his method.

"No, you put it on the bread like this..."

"But then, if you keep folding it, it keeps breaking..."

"Why do you keep folding it?"

Nigel stares down at the crumbled remnants of the sandwich, then tries folding it again.

"And then you... everything has to be folded, and then it's..."

He keeps folding.

" This. And I don't want this ."

Disgusted, he hurls the sandwich to the floor.

"I want large bread !"

See also: Smithereens, Psycho, Five Easy Pieces

Don't see also: Smokey And The Bandit

Pointless trivia: Tony Hendra has regularly worked as a wine columnist for various magazines.

fields.headline: Let there be light
fields.standfirst:
Justice is better done in the open

Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: A week from now, the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, is due in court for a preliminary hearing of the case brought against him under the Official Secrets Act. Eighteen days later, Lieutenant-Colonel Nigel Wylde faces prosecution under the same act.
fields.body:
A week from now, the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, is due in court for a preliminary hearing of the case brought against him under the Official Secrets Act. Eighteen days later, Lieutenant-Colonel Nigel Wylde faces prosecution under the same act. Yesterday, the Crown Prosecution Service applied for all or part of the case against Mr Shayler to be taken behind closed doors. Earlier this week, the Guardian reported that lawyers for the Ministry of Defence were seeking a ruling for the case against Lt-Col Wylde to be held in private. In each instance, the application is being made on grounds of national security.

While security services are sent out to work for us, there will always be cases where information might come out in court which could genuinely threaten security. Judges know that and use their discretion, as in the Ponting case. Blanket applications deserve to be treated with a scepticism bordering on suspicion. The history of these clashes demonstrates the way that the label of national security can be stuck on a case to mask the real cause of anguish: the fear of official embarrassment.

The rule should be that as much is done in the open as possibly can be. In the Wylde case, that is all the more necessary in the light of the odd manoeuvres preceding the prosecution. He is charged with passing information on army surveillance in Northern Ireland to the writer Tony Geraghty. Initially, Mr Geraghty too faced prosecution, but the charges against him were dropped. Perhaps the prosecution of journalists was judged that much more inconvenient and potentially embarrassing than the prosecution of past serving officers.

Mr Geraghty's book has been published. As we reported on Monday, the MoD's own damage assessment concluded that it did not endanger lives or military operations. The difficulty in seeing why Lt Col Wylde has been hauled into court at all makes it all the more urgent to keep the doors open.

webTitle: Inquiry urged over betting on Martin

fields.headline: Inquiry urged over betting on Martin
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the new Speaker
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Opposition MPs yesterday protested that Labour colleagues who both bet on and voted for Michael Martin to become the new Speaker of the Commons were guilty of improper conduct which should be investigated by the parliamentary watchdog.
fields.body:
Opposition MPs yesterday protested that Labour colleagues who both bet on and voted for Michael Martin to become the new Speaker of the Commons were guilty of improper conduct which should be investigated by the parliamentary watchdog.

As rumours swept both Glasgow and Westminster that sums as high as £200,000 had been won by MPs getting pro-Martin odds as good as 20-1 when the contest was announced in July, other members insisted that the winnings should - at the very least - be declared in the register of MPs interests.

Frank Roy, MP for Motherwell and Wishaw, admitted obtaining those odds, but denied placing as much as £400 with William Hill in Wishaw.

"I am certainly not looking for anything like £7,000 back," he told the Daily Record.

One of Glasgow's most colourful backbenchers was rumoured by the Daily Mail to have made £200,000 on the basis of a £10,000 bet placed with money from a libel settlement with the paper. He denied it.

In similar circumstances footballers are not allowed to bet on their own games and some MPs - including the Lib Dem chief whip, Paul Tyler - took the same view of Monday's election.

"If these bets in any way coloured MPs' judgment of the respective qualities of different candidates for the chair, that is obviously a very serious matter," said Mr Tyler, who promised to write to Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards.

webTitle: The sleepwalking voters care more about the ball game

fields.headline: The sleepwalking voters care more about the ball game
fields.standfirst:
The next American president will be the most likeable chap
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In baseball, unlike politics, Americans know where they stand. The baseball World Series, which this year reduces "world" to the city of New York, engages every New Yorker with an intensity Al Gore and George W Bush can never match.
fields.body:
In baseball, unlike politics, Americans know where they stand. The baseball World Series, which this year reduces "world" to the city of New York, engages every New Yorker with an intensity Al Gore and George W Bush can never match. Ideally the climactic contest would be between west and east coasts, Seattle Mariners v New York Mets. But the Mets v the Yankees is good enough. Baseball is war by other means even at one o'clock in the morning, when I watched the first game stretch into the 12th inning with 55,000 fans at Yankee Stadium screaming and roaring as though morning would never come.

Baseball is also the only team game ever invented that has no time limit. There can never be a tie. It goes on until there's a zero-sum result - unlike the election, which must end on November 7 and could produce any one of eight results. Gore could be president, with an all-Republican Congress, an all-Democrat Congress, a Congress split between Democratic House and Republican Senate, or just possibly vice versa. Bush faces the same permutations. Though some outcomes are more likely than others, none can be ruled out. Entering its own final stretch, the contest is too close to call. It's also, however, as unlike war as politics can ever be. Whole armies have not engaged. To the combatants it is everything. But many voters confess to the bewildered paralysis of people who think it doesn't matter.

It began as a battle that did matter. Gore's convention speech promised a stark left-right election. There are still traces of that, in some clear differences over social security spending and tax cuts. While one man denounces big government, the other promises active government. But the blurring is intense. Bush, after all, would have to come to Washington and abandon his puerile pretence that the infamous city can be written out of the script. Gore is now insisting he wouldn't appoint a single extra federal employee. The centre beckons, and the politics of maximum inoffensiveness in search of elusive voters who can't yet persuade themselves the journey to the polling-booth is worth making.

Trivia, therefore, reigns. This is less a political battle than a beauty contest. Who has the cuter smile? Which looks you more warmly in the eye? Which is the more likeable ? Never mind the competence, let alone the healthcare details - who would you rather have at the barbecue cook-out? Because from likeability comes trust , does it not? And from trust, the reassurance that this guy will do the right thing, whatever that might be. The verdict on the three Gore-Bush debates was that because Gore was superior in every sense, he had lost them, and maybe the election too.

Why have things come to this? Three groups collude to produce it. First, the electorate, and its crisis of contentment. For many tens of millions of Americans, including the majority of the 50% likely to vote, there are no agonising existential choices. They think they don't have to confront anything serious that public men can do much about. They are having a good time. Smiles and body-language are attractions they can therefore indulge. Why not give the other side a chance? There can't be much to lose.

Second, the candidates themselves, two dynastic dilutees. The juice is running out of the line. Gore is the son of a father who was a political hero of his time, a Tennessee senator of convictions, about Vietnam especially, which he would not surrender. Bush is the son of a president who was schooled for the highest office as well as any man who held it. Both current incumbents of the names are, by comparison, cyphers: calculating, unheroic, uninspired and, in Bush's case, the empty vessel into which Big Oil and the National Rifle Association have poured enough to guarantee they hold the public interest to ransom if they get the right result.

Third, there are people like me, the commentators in thrall to the reality they see, amplifiers of this trivia, submitters to a zeitgeist they can't escape, compulsive expounders of the thesis that smiles matter, hauteur is deplorable, earnestness an anachronism, policy competence a burden. They may not like this. They compare it with better days, like Nixon/Kennedy or even Carter/Reagan. But they become part of the static that legitimises it. Because every poll says that likeable matters most, every writer has to say that George W Bush is proving an extraordinarily strong candidate for president and commander-in-chief of the US.

The big loser from this tendency is, of course, Al Gore. He doesn't meet the new tests of showbiz politics, yet has so far failed to wrest the election back to the agendas that once counted for everything. This will mark an astounding historic record, if Gore loses. There will never have been a failure like it.

Having been party to creating the contentment, Gore is unable to own it. The economic triumphs of Bill Clinton become an albatross round his neck. The test that used to be decisive - are most Americans better off after eight years of the incumbent party? - no longer figures. It is not only the times that have imposed this degeneration. It is the candidate, who has not imposed the terms of political trade he inherited, and has thus fortified the delusion that the result matters less than the outcome of the World Series.

Whichever of the eight results happens in two weeks' time, it will matter hugely. If Bush becomes president, however close the call, America will have voted for change. That's how it will be seen. A new era will begin to get its name. After Clinton, Bush. It may come down to only a couple of precincts in Chicago, the ones they always said Kennedy stole to beat Nixon, but the name on the trophy will be definitive.

It will bring a lot of consequences. Not just a style and a name and a fearsome collection of interest-groups awaiting their reward for the costliest campaign in history, but, actually, an ideology which, at the edge, favours the rich over the poor, the gunmen over the unarmed, the law of the jungle over the laws of men, and a supreme court that will make such biases come to pass. In foreign affairs, as I wrote on Tuesday, the change of trajectory is set to be much sharper.

Can America, sleepwalking agreeably towards this, be made to care? In a tight race, for the remains of an apolitical electorate, much can still happen to change a few minds. In the land of trivia, the most trivial error could swing it. Bush is more capable than Gore of saying something stupid that makes fickle minds think again about the guy around the barbecue. Nothing, though, will match the ball game, to which I will tonight repair for a glimpse of the old testosterone.

Both current incumbents of the names are, by comparison, cyphers: calculating, unheroic, uninspired and, in Bush's case, the empty vessel into which Big Oil and the National Rifle Association have poured enough to guarantee they hold the public interest to ransom if they get the right result. Third, there are people like me, the commentators in thrall to the reality they see, amplifiers of this trivia, submitters to a zeitgeist they can't escape, compulsive expounders of the thesis that smiles matter, hauteur is deplorable, earnestness an anachronism, policy competence a burden. They may not like this. They compare it with better days, like Nixon/Kennedy or even Carter/Reagan. But they become part of the static that legitimises it. Because every poll says that likeable matters most, every writer has to say that George W Bush is proving an extraordinarily strong candidate for president and commander-in-chief of the US. The big loser from this tendency is, of course, Al Gore. He doesn't meet the new tests of showbiz politics, yet has so far failed to wrest the election back to the agendas that once counted for everything. This will mark an astounding historic record, if Gore loses. There will never have been a failure like it. Having been party to creating the contentment, Gore is unable to own it. The economic triumphs of Bill Clinton become an albatross round his neck. The test that used to be decisive - are most Americans better off after eight years of the incumbent party? - no longer figures. It is not only the times that have imposed this degeneration. It is the candidate, who has not imposed the terms of political trade he inherited, and has thus fortified the delusion that the result matters less than the outcome of the World Series. Whichever of the eight results happens in two weeks' time, it will matter hugely. If Bush becomes president, however close the call, America will have voted for change. That's how it will be seen. A new era will begin to get its name. After Clinton, Bush. It may come down to only a couple of precincts in Chicago, the ones they always said Kennedy stole to beat Nixon, but the name on the trophy will be definitive. It will bring a lot of consequences. Not just a style and a name and a fearsome collection of interest-groups awaiting their reward for the costliest campaign in history, but, actually, an ideology which, at the edge, favours the rich over the poor, the gunmen over the unarmed, the law of the jungle over the laws of men, and a supreme court that will make such biases come to pass. In foreign affairs, as I wrote on Tuesday, the change of trajectory is set to be much sharper. Can America, sleepwalking agreeably towards this, be made to care? In a tight race, for the remains of an apolitical electorate, much can still happen to change a few minds. In the land of trivia, the most trivial error could swing it. Bush is more capable than Gore of saying something stupid that makes fickle minds think again about the guy around the barbecue. Nothing, though, will match the ball game, to which I will tonight repair for a glimpse of the old testosterone. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Leader: Transport privatisations should be reconsidered

fields.headline: Many a mile to go yet
fields.standfirst:
Time to put further privatisations on hold

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack's sudden imposition of track closures and speed limits across the country conjures up the doomsday image of vital parts of the nation's infrastructure crumbling away after decades of underinvestment. Passengers are understandably irate when they receive only a couple of hours notice of track closures because of possible risks which must have been known to Railtrack for some considerable time.
fields.body:
Railtrack's sudden imposition of track closures and speed limits across the country conjures up the doomsday image of vital parts of the nation's infrastructure crumbling away after decades of underinvestment. Passengers are understandably irate when they receive only a couple of hours notice of track closures because of possible risks which must have been known to Railtrack for some considerable time.

If there is a risk to passenger safety, then Railtrack is, of course, justified in declaring force majeure. But this does not explain why the track was allowed to get into such a state in the first place, during a period when the company was making enough profits to see its share price surge on the stock market. It would be absurd to blame privatisation for the lack of a modern network of tracks, because successive governments denied the railways the continuous investment needed to modernise. Even if the railways were still in public ownership, lack of investment would almost certainly still be a problem.

But privatisation is now almost five years old and, instead of getting better, the railways are patently getting worse - as commuters are rudely reminded every day. Railtrack and the operating companies frequently remind us of their grandiose plans for the future, usually extended over 10 or even 20 years to make them sound even grander. But nothing is seen to happen on the ground.

What is on trial now is privatisation itself, as applied to a public service for which people rightly demand much higher standards of safety than they do when they make individual decisions to drive their own cars on roads. Railtrack may be suffering from a systemic design fault - maybe it is not possible for it to generate the profits (and dividends) necessary to keep shareholders happy while at the same time spending the vast sums which are needed to make the railways ultra-safe.

Until this problem is resolved, the government would be extremely unwise to push ahead with the privatisation of air traffic control (due to be debated in the Lords today) or privatisation of London Transport in its present form. This is not an issue of dogma or party politics. It is a question of finding the right structure to deliver an efficient, safe and well-funded railway system of the kind that other countries take for granted. We are even further away from that goal than we were before privatisation.

fields.headline: BT denies Concert disharmony
fields.trailText: AT&T and British Telecom insisted yesterday they are still trying to work together to improve joint services to corporate clients.
fields.body:
AT&T and British Telecom insisted yesterday they are still trying to work together to improve joint services to corporate clients.

The announcement that AT&T intends to spin off its business services division has clouded the future of Concert, the joint venture between the British and US telecoms groups targeted at multinational corporations.

US executives have voiced their disappointment at the performance of what should be a lucrative business. To improve the situation both sides are understood to have entered negotiations about merging their business service operations. These talks were understood to have broken down without agreement, however, as AT&T prepared its restructuring efforts.

But Michael Armstrong, head of AT&T, refused to rule anything out yesterday when he said the company was still considering "a lot of options" to improve its services. Discussions with BT had been held for "a short period of time" and were therefore not over.

At a press conference to discuss the demerger, he said: "We think there are better ways to strengthen the construct that we currently have called Concert."

Analysts have suggested that the uncertainty could end in a split rather than a merger.

BT also yesterday insisted, however, that the AT&T announcement did not mark the end of discussions.

Analysts and shareholders said that AT&T's announcement turned the spotlight on BT to clarify its strategy as well as its international relationships.

Adam Quinton, telecoms analyst at Merrill Lynch, described AT&T's plan as "strategically, a nightmare for BT" because of its possible impact on the joint venture and deeper questions it raises.

"A lot of people are going to be saying: the company that looks most like you in the world has just done this, what are you going to do?"

Shares in BT have fallen sharply in recent months as shareholders have grown disillusioned with the company's direction. The group announced an internal review which un derstood to be looking at reorganisation which is expected to be completed by the end of December.

BT has already restructured its main operations into five new divisions and is planning to float Yell, its yellow pages directory subsidiary, by the end of the year.

BT Cellnet, the group's mobile phone unit, is said to be a prime candidate for any fund-raising operation, although BT is thought to prefer a flotation, where it retains control, rather than outright disposal.

The group is also considering the sale of some minority interests, largely in mobile or fixed-line licences. Its scope for converting them into majority holdings is restricted by its borrowing levels and low share price.
