webTitle: Reform is up to you, MPs are told

fields.headline: Reform is up to you, MPs are told
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: the new Speaker
fields.trailText: Michael Martin, newly elected Speaker of the Commons, yesterday promised MPs that he wants to be a "facilitator" who will not obstruct widespread pressure for reform of archaic procedures at Westminster.
fields.body:
Michael Martin, newly elected Speaker of the Commons, yesterday promised MPs that he wants to be a "facilitator" who will not obstruct widespread pressure for reform of archaic procedures at Westminster.

But it is up to them - not him - to bring ministers to heel, Mr Martin repeatedly emphasised, as well as to set the pace and shape of the reforms they want to see introduced.

In effect, he set himself up as the Commons's referee, not its chief executive, while indicating in thinly veiled terms that he will be more sympathetic than Betty Boothroyd has been since 1992 to calls for shorter, more family friendly hours and a more responsive daily agenda. He praised his predecessor, but was keen to stress that his own style will be different. "That was Speaker Boothroyd, I'm Speaker Martin," he said. But he repeatedly challenged MPs to assert their own rights and prerogatives against ministers and the party whips.

"It's up to the house to hold the executive to account. I am not the executive's man, I am the house's man and I will not allow the rules of the house to be broken," Mr Martin told reporters in what amounted to an even-handed warning to MPs, ministers and Whitehall spin doctors. Faced with a flurry of requests for interviews after Monday night's election Mr Martin had taken the unprecedented step of summoning a press conference at the ornate Speaker's house underneath Big Ben into which he and his wife, Mary, will eventually move.

The decision to talk to the Westminster press corps caused controversy as Tory MPs, resentful of Labour's imposition of a second Labour successive speaker, protested in the Commons that Mr Martin should have addressed them first. Even Tam Dalyell, a Labour fellow Scot who may emerge as father of the house after Sir Edward Heath's retirement, professed himself "horrified" by the move.

Mr Martin said yesterday he had no intention of being "a temporary Speaker" because he had been elected by the same procedures as his predecessors, with the added test that every rival candidate had his claim put to a vote during the seven hour contest.

The Commons procedure committee will meet next week to discuss reform of the procedure. Mr Martin backs an inquiry but warned yesterday that change must be considered carefully since many options exist.

Faced with some personal questions he joked that "I don't have an accent, it's just other people who have an accent". Questioned about the "over representation of Scots" in senior posts he said such talk was to "go down a dangerous path".

webTitle: Work of a private investigator more mundane than murky, says boss

fields.headline: Work of a private investigator more mundane than murky, says boss
fields.trailText: The shadowy world of British private investigators are a far cry from the Champagne-filled lifestyle of TV detective Magnum PI.
fields.body:
The shadowy world of British private investigators are a far cry from the Champagne-filled lifestyle of TV detective Magnum PI.

Instead, British private eyes are far more likely to be monitoring an errant husband through the telephoto lens of a camera to provide a suspicious wife with proof that her husband is having an affair.

The bulk of assignments involve corporate surveillance, such as monitoring an employee who is claiming long-term sick leave. Pre-employment screening is another popular area, where a little delving can reveal the truth about that glowing reference.

Timothy Jones, managing director of UK Private Investigators, said the perception of the unshaven, private detective in a dirty mac is a cliche.

"The men and women who work in this industry are highly skilled, often with a background in the police, armed forces or intelligence services," he said. "They have to be able to blend in with any surroundings, whether it is a top class hotel or a rundown housing estate."

Overseas work is also commonplace, with the bulk of assignments coming from companies wanting staff monitored for unsavoury extracurricular activities, said Mr Jones.

"We had one large company in Dubai that was appointing one of its employees to a senior position," he said. "They were worried about the fact that he made so many trips to Thailand and asked us to follow him to see that he wasn't indulging in anything that might being the company into disrepute."

One country he is adamant they would not visit on assignment is Cuba, on the grounds that it is too dangerous. He said: "I doubt whether you would find many British private investigators' firms that would be keen. It's way too risky, given the political set-up and trade sanctions.

"While it is not unusual to send a team of six private detectives on a case, it is unusual - even amateurish - for investigators to be offered£1,000 up front with more, depending on results."

John Stalker, the former deputy chief constable of Greater Manchester, and now a security consultant agrees. He said: "It really sounds like Carry on Spying. I've been to Cuba and how a bunch of chancers from London thought they could possibly blend in there amazes me."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Paedophile protest charges
fields.body:
Paedophile protest charges

Thirty-five people, including 22 children, appeared before Portsmouth magistrates on a range of criminal charges following anti- paedophile protests on the city's Paulsgrove estate in August. Most cases were adjourned until next month.

Craft closes in on asteroid

The spacecraft Shoemaker today closes to within three miles of the asteroid Eros 433. It will collect data and photographs of boulders as small as 2ft across.

'Victory' in 1952 murder appeal

The Northern Ireland appeal court appeared to indicate that Iain Hay Gordon had won his appeal against conviction for the murder of a judge's daughter in 1952, although judgment was reserved.

Submarines in dock for months

Britain will be without its hunter-killer submarines for at least five months, defence officials admitted. All 12 are being taken out of service after the discovery of a "generic" fault in the reactor cooling system of HMS Tireless.

Seven charged over cocaine

Seven people appeared at Portsmouth magistrates court charged with importing drugs after the seizure of 300kg of cocaine on the Isle of Wight. The case was adjourned until November 1.

Cornwall lays claim to pasties

Cornwall's trading standards department is preparing a case to the European Union that cornish pasties can be sold as such only if made in the county.

fields.headline: Closed books and stilled lives
fields.standfirst: Review: Whiteread's concrete tribute to victims of nazism
fields.trailText: The soft white parachute silk covering Austria's first memorial to its 65,000 Jews killed in the Holocaust rippled gently in the wind. "This monument shouldn't be beautiful," Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal warned a crowd of around 400 gathered in Judenplatz - Jews' Square - for its unveiling. "It must hurt," he insisted, his faint voice shaking with age and emotion.
fields.body:
The soft white parachute silk covering Austria's first memorial to its 65,000 Jews killed in the Holocaust rippled gently in the wind. "This monument shouldn't be beautiful," Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal warned a crowd of around 400 gathered in Judenplatz - Jews' Square - for its unveiling. "It must hurt," he insisted, his faint voice shaking with age and emotion.

As the ropes were pulled back, the silk slid with a swish over the bunker-like form and the chief rabbi's recitation of the Kaddish filled the small square. Holocaust Memorial by British sculptor Rachel Whiteread was finally revealed - a brutally stark inverted library set in concrete, a lifeless form with no sympathetic lines, and doors with no handles or hinges.

"It's harrowing," remarked Hilde Fein, 70, who had taken a pew on a window sill outside a beer cellar on the baroque square. The daughter of Austrian Jews, she lost her grandparents in the Holocaust after they were deported to Lodz, Poland. "It offers no consolation, and rightly so," she added, shaking her head. Her biggest regret was that she had to wait so long.

The Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, called Ms Whiteread's "nameless library" - a hermetically-sealed room of books to symbolise the large numbers of victims and the untold stories of their lives - an attempt to "describe the indescribable".

Acknowledgment

Mayor of Vienna, Michael Haupl, said it was "necessary for Austria", and was meant to "send a message to the world", from a country which for years has painted itself as a victim of Hitler, rather than a perpetrator of nazi crimes.

The unveiling comes at a sensitive time for the alpine republic as it desperately tries to repair its tarnished reputation following the entry into a coalition government of Jorg Haider's far right Freedom party (FPO) almost nine months ago.

Sanctions imposed by the European Union in response were only lifted last month, leaving Austria humiliated.

Jewish visitors from around the world were invited to view the unveiling along with representatives from government and the Catholic Church, but the FPO was noticeable by its absence. Asked if she had any contact with the party, Ms Whiteread, 37, replied: "I've never met Haider and I hope that I never do."

She said she was "very relieved and happy" finally to see her work which almost failed to see the light of day.

The 1994 Turner prize winner received the commission to create the monument in January 1996. Nameless Library was originally to be unveiled on November 9 of the same year, the 58th anniversary of the Kristallnacht anti-Jewish attacks. But heated debates cut across Vienna's political and religious landscape and split the Jewish community, delaying its completion.

Construction of the monument ground to a halt when excavation work on the square unearthed the ruins of a synagogue destroyed in 1421. A campaign of violent persecution by the Catholic Church had led dozens of Jews to commit suicide inside the synagogue, rather than renounce their faith. The building was torched on March 12, the same day that Nazi troops would enter Vienna 517 years later.

Large numbers of Vienna's 10,000 Jewish community argued that the medieval synagogue was a far more fitting tribute to the Shoah and that it would be insulting to place Ms Whiteread's work on top of it. Meanwhile resident of Judenplatz complained that the construction would reduce parking space and affect business. City officials suggested moving Ms Whiteread's sculpture elsewhere.

But the artist stood her ground, threatening to sue the council. "I designed the memorial for Judenplatz and if it is to be moved elsewhere a new competition has to be launched," she said.

After lengthy negotiations the archeological findings and the monument were allowed to co-exist on the square and the project was completed earlier this year.

Judenplatz has been pedestrianised to provide an atmosphere of relative calm and its chronicle of the persecution of Austria's Jews now includes access to the remains of the synagogue and a Judaic centre for the ultra-orthodox Misrachis.

In his speech President Klestil stressed the "ambivalence of our history", pointing out that at times the Jews had prayed peacefully in Judenplatz, and in house No 244, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart composed Cosi Fan Tutti in 1783. He also stressed his country's recent attempts to right the wrongs of its past after Monday's signing of an agreement to set up a 6bn schilling (£260m) fund to compensate the survivors of Nazi forced labour. But he admitted such measures should have happened years ago.

Roots

A Latin inscription on a plaque from 1497 at the far end of the square stating that the Jews deserved the fate that befell them, recalled the anti-Semitism in which the Holocaust had its roots.

It was not until 1500 that Jews were allowed to settle in Vienna on payment of a poll tax. But they were repeatedly expelled until the 18th century.

The president of the Jewish community, Ariel Muzicant, said the monument marked hundreds of years of anti-Semitism in Vienna, but the main concern should be: "What happened after 1945? Why didn't anyone call the Jews back? Why after 1945 were no measures taken to give their stolen goods back? And why is there is so much anti-Semitism even today?"

The memorial, said Ms Whiteread, aimed to "invert people's perception of the world and to reveal the unexpected." She says her 1994 work House - the cast of the whole interior of an East London house - marked a logical step towards Holocaust Memorial.

City officials have agreed not to put anti-graffiti solution on the monument. "If someone sprays a swastika on it we can try to scrub it off," Ms Whiteread said, "but a few daubed swastikas would really make people think about what's happening in their society."

Construction of the monument ground to a halt when excavation work on the square unearthed the ruins of a synagogue destroyed in 1421. A campaign of violent persecution by the Catholic Church had led dozens of Jews to commit suicide inside the synagogue, rather than renounce their faith. The building was torched on March 12, the same day that Nazi troops would enter Vienna 517 years later. Large numbers of Vienna's 10,000 Jewish community argued that the medieval synagogue was a far more fitting tribute to the Shoah and that it would be insulting to place Ms Whiteread's work on top of it. Meanwhile resident of Judenplatz complained that the construction would reduce parking space and affect business. City officials suggested moving Ms Whiteread's sculpture elsewhere. But the artist stood her ground, threatening to sue the council. "I designed the memorial for Judenplatz and if it is to be moved elsewhere a new competition has to be launched," she said. After lengthy negotiations the archeological findings and the monument were allowed to co-exist on the square and the project was completed earlier this year. Judenplatz has been pedestrianised to provide an atmosphere of relative calm and its chronicle of the persecution of Austria's Jews now includes access to the remains of the synagogue and a Judaic centre for the ultra-orthodox Misrachis. In his speech President Klestil stressed the "ambivalence of our history", pointing out that at times the Jews had prayed peacefully in Judenplatz, and in house No 244, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart composed Cosi Fan Tutti in 1783. He also stressed his country's recent attempts to right the wrongs of its past after Monday's signing of an agreement to set up a 6bn schilling (£260m) fund to compensate the survivors of Nazi forced labour. But he admitted such measures should have happened years ago. Roots A Latin inscription on a plaque from 1497 at the far end of the square stating that the Jews deserved the fate that befell them, recalled the anti-Semitism in which the Holocaust had its roots. It was not until 1500 that Jews were allowed to settle in Vienna on payment of a poll tax. But they were repeatedly expelled until the 18th century. The president of the Jewish community, Ariel Muzicant, said the monument marked hundreds of years of anti-Semitism in Vienna, but the main concern should be: "What happened after 1945? Why didn't anyone call the Jews back? Why after 1945 were no measures taken to give their stolen goods back? And why is there is so much anti-Semitism even today?" The memorial, said Ms Whiteread, aimed to "invert people's perception of the world and to reveal the unexpected." She says her 1994 work House - the cast of the whole interior of an East London house - marked a logical step towards Holocaust Memorial. City officials have agreed not to put anti-graffiti solution on the monument. "If someone sprays a swastika on it we can try to scrub it off," Ms Whiteread said, "but a few daubed swastikas would really make people think about what's happening in their society."

fields.headline: Kursk gives up its dead
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The corpses of three sailors were removed from the ravaged hull of the Kursk last night, after a Russian deep-sea diver penetrated the dark and icy waters inside the sunken nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
The corpses of three sailors were removed from the ravaged hull of the Kursk last night, after a Russian deep-sea diver penetrated the dark and icy waters inside the sunken nuclear submarine.

The military diver, Sergei Shmygin, began the dangerous operation yesterday afternoon to remove the bodies of some of the 118 men who had died when it sank on August 12, after a team of Norwegian and Russian divers completed the first of seven man-sized holes in the side of the vessel.

Sack-like coffins were taken down to the wreck, and the bodies were packed into them; later the bags were loaded into a metal container which was raised to the surface.

During a five-hour mission, Mr Shmygin searched the eighth and the ninth sections of the submarine's nine compartments. His progress was hampered by his bulky diving suit, which prevented him from going down narrow passageways. His oxygen lead was too short to allow him to proceed very far in the other direction. The three corpses were discovered on the top layer of the compartments.

fields.headline: 75 feared dead in Georgian crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Russian military was struck by a fresh disaster last night when a ministry of defence plane carrying 75 people, some of them children, crashed into a Georgian mountain while trying to land in dense fog. No one was thought to have survived.
fields.body:
The Russian military was struck by a fresh disaster last night when a ministry of defence plane carrying 75 people, some of them children, crashed into a Georgian mountain while trying to land in dense fog. No one was thought to have survived.

Residents in villages outside the Black Sea port of Batumi - the capital of the Georgian breakaway region of Abkhazia - heard a huge explosion as the four-engined Ilyushin 18 veered off course and fell rapidly into nearby mountains.

Neither the cause of the crash nor the fate of the 64 passengers - thought to be both civilians and military - and the 11 crew were known last night. The alarm was raised by local foresters.

Abkhazian rescue teams, who made their way through difficult mountainous terrain to the scene of the accident, said they believed everyone must have died.

Only fragments of the aircraft were found, scattered over a charred expanse of land.

"After such a powerful explosion, it is unlikely that any of the passengers could have survived. But the rescue operation is nevertheless continuing," a spokesman for the local emergency services said.

Marina Ryklina, a spokeswoman for Russia's emergency situations ministry, said the plane crashed about 15 miles east of the capital. A Georgian politician, Georgy Targamadze, put the site of the accident near the small town of Kabuleti, at the foot of the Mkirala mountain.

The plane was flying from Chkalovskoye, a town outside Moscow which hosts a military airfield, to Batumi, also home to a Russian military base.

Georgia gained independence with the break up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but Russia still maintains some troops in the region. The military is in the process of removing its soldiers and equipment from two bases in Georgia, and is negotiating withdrawal from two more. Equipment from the bases is being shipped out through Batumi.

fields.headline: UN chiefs get Ruud awakening
fields.trailText: Diplomats from across the world reacted with surprise yesterday to the nomination of former Dutch prime minister Ruud Lubbers as the next head of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).
fields.body:
Diplomats from across the world reacted with surprise yesterday to the nomination of former Dutch prime minister Ruud Lubbers as the next head of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

"Ruud who?," asked one European Union diplomat. "Man from nowhere gets the top UN job."

Mr Lubbers also seemed puzzled at his selection by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan. "I do not know how come Kofi Annan thought of me. This is a complete surprise," Swiss newspapers quoted him as saying. "I'm packing my bags and leaving for New York."

The rubber-stamping of Mr Annan's selection by the UN general assembly is seen as a mere formality. Mr Lubbers was not mentioned as a candidate and his name surprised even those back home, where the prime minister, Wim Kok, had been lobbying for the official Dutch candidate, the Environment Minister, Jan Pronk.

Sceptics claimed the choice smacked of backroom dealing with rumours in Geneva's diplomatic corridors claiming that the job had been promised to the Dutch but due to objections to Mr Pronk's candidacy another prominent Dutchman had to be found at short notice.

Reuters, Geneva

webTitle: MPs' £230m offices hit by new glitch

fields.headline: MPs' £230m offices hit by new glitch
fields.trailText: For once, it was a case of not enough spin. An engineer called in to check a mechanical glitch at Portcullis House, the controversial new £230m office for MPs, found himself trapped for two hours by its revolving doors.
fields.body:
For once, it was a case of not enough spin. An engineer called in to check a mechanical glitch at Portcullis House, the controversial new £230m office for MPs, found himself trapped for two hours by its revolving doors.

An eyewitness said of the engineer, who shielded his face when our photographer caught him: "He looked very embarrassed, particularly since people were laughing at him."

Such humour was lost on Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, who said he would be asking questions about the cost of the doors, why it took so long for the man to be released, and whether the incident could happen again.

Last night a spokesman for Portcullis House - where other problems have included a gap around the main entrance which posed a security risk and flooding last month - said: "New circle lock and security door systems take a while to settle down. But we don't know how long."

Meanwhile 35 MPs signed an early day motion protesting at not being allowed to transfer their four-drawer filing cabinets to Portcullis House. MPs are instead only permitted two-drawer, light oak cabinets. Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, said: "It isn't helpful if the Commons authorities unnecessarily interfere with such petty rules."

fields.headline: Ex-finance minister to stand trial
fields.trailText: France's former finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn was ordered to stand trial yesterday on charges of false accounting at his private law practice.
fields.body:
France's former finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn was ordered to stand trial yesterday on charges of false accounting at his private law practice.

Mr Strauss-Kahn, part of the original "Dream Team" cabinet appointed in 1997 by the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, resigned a year ago to fight the allegations.

Investigating magistrates say he falsified documents to account for a £60,000 payment from the student health insurance group, MNEF.

Mr Strauss-Kahn, a close friend of Mr Jospin's and much admired on the international finance scene, admits "technical irregularities" in the invoicing, but he says the money was payment for legal work carried out for the insurance group between 1994 and 1996.

The trial is a further blow to Mr Strauss-Kahn, who was at one stage tipped as the next Socialist candidate for mayor of Paris. He is also under formal investigation in another scandal surrounding the former state-run oil giant Elf Aquitaine, now part of TotalFinaElf, and has also come under suspicion in a vast kickback scam allegedly run by the conservative RPR party.

webTitle: Gore has to battle for the home ground

fields.headline: Gore has to battle for the home ground
fields.standfirst:
The South
Even core Democrat states need to be coaxed to the polls
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As the legendary crooner Tony Bennett eased into The Best is Yet to Come at a Democratic fundraising rally in Nashville, the look on Al Gore's face said it all.
fields.body:
As the legendary crooner Tony Bennett eased into The Best is Yet to Come at a Democratic fundraising rally in Nashville, the look on Al Gore's face said it all.

If a single expression can convey fear, hope, determination and uncertainty all in one rapid spasm, then the inner turmoils of the political moment etched themselves briefly across the Democratic presidential candidate's normally studied features.

The song may yet prove right for Mr Gore. But he should not have to be campaigning in his home state, Tennessee. In fact, he should not be campaigning in most of the mainly middle-ranking states he is visiting this week, all of which voted for the Clinton-Gore ticket in 1992 and 1996 and several of which even voted for the defeated Michael Dukakis in 1988.

But his schedule this week is another mark of how things are simply different in this year's nip-and-tuck White House race. Since the national polls still indicate a photo-finish with George W Bush on November 7, every state counts even more than usual, and states which would normally be safely wrapped up for one man or the other by this stage remain volatile right down to the wire.

Nowhere is this truer than in the South. This week Mr Gore has been campaigning in states that were cornerstones of the Clinton-Gore victories in the 1990s: Mr Clinton's native Arkansas, his own Tennessee and, today, the normally safely Democratic West Virginia. The itinerary tells you everything that the campaign staff will never admit.

The latest published polls from Arkansas show Mr Bush in a narrow 45% to 43% lead, but both sides say the gap has widened. In Tennessee, where last month Mr Gore led easily, Mr Bush is now 3 points ahead. It is not impossible that Mr Gore may be the first candidate in modern times to win the presidency while losing his own backyard.

"This election is the closest election since 1960, when John Kennedy won by the equivalent of a single vote in each precinct," Mr Gore told supporters during a brief stop in Shreveport, Louisiana, another state where he is battling to stay in contention. The polls, which political observers are now following with more than usual obsessiveness, show that he is right. On polling day every vote in almost every state may make the difference.

At the end of last week it looked as if everything was beginning to unravel for Mr Gore. The more Americans saw of him in the presidential debates, the better they liked Mr Bush. His September poll lead had vanished and Mr Bush seemed to be pulling ahead in the final stretch.

Now it has changed again. In the latest national tracking polls he has recovered a wafer thin lead: 46% to 45% in Gallup, 45% to 42% in the Zogby, and dead level on 46% in the Washington Post. All are within the statistical margin of error.

"I think we have the momentum right now," Mr Gore's spokesman Chris Lehane said yesterday. "I think that's a function of the fact that Gore's in the right place on the issues and the policies. People are beginning to focus on that more and more."

Momentum or not, the campaign is very hard pounding for Mr Gore. There is a new urgency in his manner as he approaches the day for which he has been preparing for most of his adult life.

He has brought his wife Tipper back to his side at many campaign events, hoping that her more relaxed public style may rub off on his own. And in Nashville last night he was with his running-mate Joe Lieberman again, trying to regain some of the energy which marked their campaign back in August.

He has stripped down his message to a few key essentials - the economy, women's rights, his Vietnam service - which his team believes spotlight the differences between him and Mr Bush. In doing so he hopes to move the core Democrat supporters to turn out on November 7 while reaching the undecided, who the strategists believe are not yet focused on the election.

The economy is at the heart of his campaign. "Prosperity itself is on the ballot," he said in Little Rock on Tuesday. "The Bush agenda really amounts to a big tax giveaway, big deficits, big debt and blank cheques to all the special interests."

Yet despite being the virtual incumbent at a time of enormous economic and social contentment, Mr Gore is having terrible difficulty persuading Americans to rally behind his call. In consequence, many Democrats have been urging him to bring Mr Clinton into the campaign. But he is determined to do it his way, win or lose. Mr Clinton will campaign for the black vote in some southern states, but there are no plans for them to campaign together. The unspoken fear is that Mr Clinton would simply overshadow him.

He used his Little Rock speech to try to rebut one of Mr Bush's seemingly most successful accusations: that he is at heart an old-style big-government Democrat.

"I know my opponent would like to run against a mythical big-spending, big-government candidate - a cartoon image from campaigns past," he said. "[But] I am the one who believes in limited government, and I believed in it long before it was fashionable in the Democratic party to do so."

As he continued his battle to regain the initiative, his press spokesman did his best to maintain a studied cool. "I'm staying nonchalant, and I'm full of equanimity," Mr Lehane said. "Our assumption has always been that this will go right to the very end, to the last minute of the last day of this campaign."

webTitle: Patients in right to life test case allowed to die peacefully

fields.headline: Patients in right to life test case allowed to die peacefully
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The two severely brain-damaged patients who were at the centre of a high court "right to life" test case three weeks ago have died peacefully, lawyers for the hospitals which treated them said yesterday.
fields.body:
The two severely brain-damaged patients who were at the centre of a high court "right to life" test case three weeks ago have died peacefully, lawyers for the hospitals which treated them said yesterday.

The announcement came 19 days after Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, gave doctors the go-ahead to withdraw tube feeding after hearing that both women were suffering the "living death" of a permanent vegetative state.

The case went before England's top family judge to test the effect of the new Human Rights Act on the right of doctors to withdraw artificial feeding in such cases. In 1993, the House of Lords ruled in the case of the Hillsborough survivor, Tony Bland, that doctors could stop feeding PVS patients.

That ruling had to be reconsidered in the light of the act, which incorporates the European convention on human rights, with its guarantee of the right to life.

On October 8, Dame Elizabeth ruled that feeding could be withdrawn from the two patients, named only as Mrs M and Mrs H.

Giving her reasons yesterday, she concluded that the Lords' ruling in the Bland case did not conflict with the European convention.

Article 2 of the convention, the right to life, obliges the state to refrain from taking life intentionally and also imposes a positive obligation on the state to safeguard life.

Dame Elizabeth said: "Although the intention in withdrawing artificial nutrition and hydration in PVS cases is to hasten death, in my judgment the phrase 'deprivation of life' must import a deliberate act, as opposed to an omission, by someone acting on behalf of the state, which results in death."

She said a "responsible decision" by a medical team not to provide treatment at the initial stage could not amount to intentional deprivation of life. Mrs H, aged 36, was visiting the US last year when she suffered an attack of pancreatitis caused by medication for epilepsy.

She returned to England but had a heart attack, depriving her brain of oxygen, when she was in hospital undergoing treatment in January this year.

Mrs M, 49, was brain-damaged in 1997 as a result of an anaesthetic accident during gynaecological surgery.

She returned to England but had a heart attack, depriving her brain of oxygen, when she was in hospital undergoing treatment in January this year. Mrs M, 49, was brain-damaged in 1997 as a result of an anaesthetic accident during gynaecological surgery.

webTitle: Mob kills 24 in detention camp attack

fields.headline: Mob kills 24 in detention camp attack
fields.trailText: A mob rampaged through a detention camp housing Tamil rebels and child soldiers in central Sri Lanka early yesterday, killing at least 24 inmates and wounding dozens more.
fields.body:
A mob rampaged through a detention camp housing Tamil rebels and child soldiers in central Sri Lanka early yesterday, killing at least 24 inmates and wounding dozens more.

Local residents said the Bindunuwewa camp near Bandarawela, 140 miles east of Colombo, was completely devastated, adding that hundreds of machete and knife-wielding men, mostly from nearby villages, torched buildings in the compound after massacring the inmates

A radio station quoted one attacker as saying the inmates had connected power lines to the perimeter barbed-wire fence and hurled rocks to defend themselves. The camp housed up to 80 Tamil rebels who had surrendered or been captured.

Reuters, Colombo

fields.headline: A question of style
fields.standfirst: These five women have been voted the most stylish in the world. But what do they have in common, asks  Polly Vernon  , and what exactly  is style anyway?
fields.trailText: These five women have been voted the most stylish in the world. But what do they have in common, asks  Polly Vernon  , and what exactly  is style anyway?
fields.body:
There is something about that raddled old tart of a quality, style, that gives it perpetual currency for women. That makes it a constantly covetable notion. It is, apart from anything else, a characteristic women applaud in other women. While overt sexiness has a subtext of confusing politics (empowering or exploiting? dangerous or endangering? subversive or compliant?), style is widely considered legit. To be stylish is to play by the rules. It is an all-round good thing. Therefore to have style is to be a superior woman.

But what exactly is style? In the name of making things a bit easier for us, last spring Vogue commissioned a style poll. Its results, the magazine hoped, would deconstruct the essence of modern style. But, as tends to be the case with these things, the Vogue Style Survey 2001 ended up saying more about its respondents than it did about the status of style in contemporary times.

The results, which seeped into the public domain yesterday, revealed that the 2,000-plus respondents considered model-turned-actress Isabella Rossellini to be the definitive style icon of the moment, followed closely by Joanna Lumley. Some may interpret this as a clear indication that style is the unique preserve of the "experienced" woman. Indeed, a speed-read of the Vogue report reveals that 87% of the respondents consider the confidence acquired with time to be the major contributing factor of style, while 1% believe it to be a youth thing.

In my experience, women aspire towards celebrity super beings who somehow resemble their non-famous selves in the smallest way. Our fantasy alter egos must always be anchored, however minimally, in a sense of the achievable. We need to be able to think: "If I had her money and wardrobe and access to a personal trainer, and if I squinted a bit when I looked in the mirror, then just maybe . . . "

Thus brunette normal beings will not waste their time wishing they could be Cameron Diaz and, equally, those surveyed by Vogue were presumably not about to start holding up Britney Spears as a style icon, in the knowledge that they passed their sell-by date on that look some time before. The fact that they (somewhat confusingly) then voted overwhelmingly for Jennifer Aniston as Personal Style Icon (as opposed to Most Stylish) speaks volumes about precisely that: Aniston's look, though admittedly developed from sound basic material, is nonetheless a testament to the possibilities of an everyday aesthetic improved by serious grooming.

Quite apart from that, Vogue's top 10 stylish women list is a strange combination of fairly random names. Catherine Zeta Jones is at three, with a style ethic (buxom Welsh strumpet?) that seems essentially to rely on a never-ending supply of diamond-encrusted premiere dresses and some studied hair flickery. Jennifer Aniston crashes in at four, with her take on Hollywood smart casual (faded denim, glitzy tops, slut heels and ironed flat hair) and Elizabeth Hurley makes it to five, thanks to her neat line in gratuitous glitzy slapper chic, which, when juxtaposed with her faux aristo public persona, creates a heady sexiness - but does it really qualify as style incarnate?

More confusing yet, precisely what style qualities does Aniston share with Gwyneth Paltrow, who makes it in at number seven (jointly with Nicole Kidman) and whose particular breed of pared-down Calvin Klein minimalism and power grooming bears out the belief, shared by 45% of poll respondents, that Audrey Hepburnesque simplicity defines style. Yet Madonna, who sashays in at number six, has done nothing but be extremely un-simple and inconsistent in her aesthetic reinventions, from geisha girl to retro boho trollop and back again in the past two years.

It's all terribly confusing, really. Particularly when you consider that, given the current ubiquitousness of the celebrity stylist, famous women are arguably the outward expression of someone else's style. And how often are celebrity women PR-spun stylish public personas? Do we really think Joanna Lumley is stylish, or are we just buying the English cut-glass hauteur associated with her fame?

According to hackneyed cliché, style is a nebulous quality - "more than just about clothes", in the words of Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman. But surely there must be some logic behind the possessing of it. By considering the enduring, archetypally stylish women of the last century - Audrey Hepburn, Rita Hayworth, Lauren Bacall - then extracting the common denominators, it is possible to bash out a prototype of sorts.

Cheekbones are good, but too-full lips will count against you. If you happen to be blonde, your skin must be perma-pale - neither tans nor blushes will do. And if you're brunette, do as power New Yorkers Plum Sykes and her cronies do, and depilate. Exhaustively. A louche demeanour, poised walk and sleek finish are essential, and lack of cleavage is an advantage - as we've already seen, blatant sexuality and innate stylishness rarely coexist.

The stylish are people of few words. They can generally express themselves sufficiently merely by manipulating one fiercely shaped eyebrow. Emotional outbursts do not become them. Sudden movements of any kind, in fact, do not work for the stylish. Unless, perhaps, we are talking about performing a perfectly executed tango.

To be truly stylish, you must also be thin. Thinness is always good. It mutters about formidable self-control and the kind of austere personality that wears style best. The stylish often smoke, which is a double whammy of a stylish trait because beyond looking cool (which it does), smoking can help with the thinness.

Style, I am widely informed, is about having "class" - which in theory has little to do with social class but in practice often does because the kind of affluence that allows you to bunk off the day job and get groomed will certainly help, if not actually guarantee you stylish status. Lady Helen Taylor, who is currently gracing the front of Hello!, alongside the coverline, "A Perfect Ambassador For Style", would probably tell you as much.

webTitle: City in line for health check

fields.headline: City in line for health check
fields.standfirst: World Bank and IMF to test Square Mile stability
fields.trailText: The City has been volunteered by the chancellor for a health check by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to see if it poses a risk to global financial stability.
fields.body:
The City has been volunteered by the chancellor for a health check by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to see if it poses a risk to global financial stability.

Mr Brown announced the move yesterday in an attempt to spur other countries into taking part in the so-called financial sector assessment programme (FSAP), which is designed to prevent a repeat of the Asian crisis.

Weaknesses in the financial systems of countries such as South Korea and Thailand have been widely blamed for contributing to the panic which spread through the global financial system after the devaluation of the Thai bhat in August 1997.

"I am confident that UK financial regulation is amongst the best in the world," said Mr Brown, attending a meeting of G20 finance ministers in Montreal.

"Nevertheless, the UK financial sector is also amongst the most important in the global financial system. We will therefore welcome the opportunity of participation in the programme."

Launched in 1999, the FSAP tests the vulnerability of a country's financial system to macro-economic shocks, assesses its compliance with international standards and evaluates the legal and institutional infrastructure. It is meant to complement the IMF's well-established procedure for inspecting member countries' economies.

So far FSAP examinations have been limited to countries which are not leading players in the global financial system, such as South Africa and India. By offering up London, Mr Brown is hoping to persuade other world financial centres to take the plunge.

The Treasury said it would be ready for the FSAP by the end of next year, by which time the legislation establishing the authority of the Financial Services Authority to act as a single City regulator was due to be completed.

FSAP reports contain sensitive information and are confidential but, subject to these constraints, Mr Brown pledged to make public any recommendations for reform.

fields.headline: Pass Notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1749 James Palumbo
fields.trailText: No: 1749 James Palumbo
fields.body:
Naked Chef meets cigar-smoking detective ? I think you might be getting confused with the popular mac-wearing 70s TV cop, Columbo.

Easy mistake to make. So who is this Palumbo fellow? He owns a nightclub.

Like Peter Stringfellow? Mmm, yes, only without the mullet and the frolicking ladies.

No mullets? No ladies? What kind of a nightclub is this? It's called the Ministry of Sound and is one of the nation's premier dance venues.

Of course it is. And not satisfied with its legendary club nights, plus a lucrative trade in spin-off merchandise, MoS is now organising the farewell party for the Dome.

Going out on a high? Actually, the MoS has a strict anti-drugs policy. But yes, they'll be putting on a special New Year's Eve shindig, charging 16,000 young bucks £35 a pop for 12 glorious hours of 37 DJs "pumping out mind-blowing quality tunes" in the buildings that surround the Dome.

But why not in the Dome itself? Don't even go there. Just rest assured that the Dome will make its apologies and leave early on December 31.

So what else do we know about this Palumbo character? He's 36, was educated at Eton and Oxford, did a short stint in the City and is a close friend of Peter Mandelson.

We all have our crosses to bear. Yes, but a friend in need is a friend indeed. In 1997, Palumbo lent Mandelson a chauffeured car. Now the MoS is getting the Dome strangely free of charge.

That's one helluva coincidence. That's just the sort of cynicism that damaged the Dome .

What will the critics say? They are being unusually supportive. Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth has said: "If there is to be a party, I would rather it was organised by the Ministry of Sound than the Ministry of Culture."

That's a bit tough on Chris "havin' it large" Smith: You clearly didn't spend last New Year's Eve in the waiting room at Stratford station.

Do say: "At last a party worth voting for."

Don't say: "Any chance of booking the Corrs again?"

fields.headline: A view to a cull
fields.standfirst: On sense v sentimentality in the country * The truth about the Speaker * A virtual workout
fields.trailText: Last week, I was bombing along the C-class road that lies between my dripping cottage and New Greenham Business Park (formerly Women's Peace Camp: Say No to Cruise) when I came across what was obviously a very minor road accident.
fields.body:
Last week, I was bombing along the C-class road that lies between my dripping cottage and New Greenham Business Park (formerly Women's Peace Camp: Say No to Cruise) when I came across what was obviously a very minor road accident.

Two cars pulled up on the verge, two young women standing about looking tense, one shouting on a mobile. I was racing for the London train, but we neighbourly country folk do not pass by on the other side. "Are you OK?" I enquired. "Anybody hurt? Need any help?" The one without the mobile said: "Er, er, I think we'll be all right. Thanks for stopping. She's called the emergency services, they're coming, they'll be here soon." Snatches of the mobile conversation blew towards me ("A glancing blow to the side of the head - no, no - alive - no, not too much blood") and I said, "Oh, my God!" and leapt out of the car.

"Who is hurt?" I asked, in a soothing but urgent voice. They turned stricken little faces towards me and said: "It's a squirrel." A squirrel? For a squirrel she called the emergency services? In the depths of the country? Who'd turn out for asquirrel? Vets Sans Frontieres? Here, at the bucolic foot of Watership Down, we have ways to deal with the hundreds of small animals that routinely fling themselves under our wheels each week. We despatch them, quickly and unsentimentally, by a) wringing their necks or b) hitting them with something heavy. You may not fancy the idea down Upper Street, Islington, but that's the great British divide, isn't it? Town v country. Sense v sentimentality.

Well, that's how it used to be. Not any more. I opened my mouth to utter something normal, sane and helpful (such as "Shall I knock it on the head with my car-jack") but I shut up sharp at the sight of their white, set faces.

These young women clearly did not want their squirrel despatched in the time-honoured country manner. They wanted it rescued, and preferably by a telegenic RSPCA officer in reassuring navy-blue. They wanted it carried lovingly off to Animal Hospital, splinted and stitched up by a popular Swedish vet, and serenaded afterwards by Rolf bloody Harris.

Villages like mine used to be full of red-blooded, unsentimental country people: mole-stranglers, pheasant-pluckers, pigeon-shooters, rabbit-hunters. They knew that milk isn't crushed from vegetables and that your best Christmas turkey is the one that is killed for you personally by the farmer up the back lanes. Now every hill and hedge-bottom is crawling with milk-fed suburbanites who think animals have souls and that noisy cockerels can be turned off at dawn, like car-alarms. Is it too much tarmac or too much television that's turning the countryside into one vast seamless suburb? Maybe it's too much Tony Banks. He was roaring and bawling on Any Questions? last week about toffs and viciousness and medieval barbarism (fox hunting) and being cheered to the rafters by a Bristol audience. Only 10 years ago, he would have been cheered and booed on a 50-50 basis. Now it's 80-20. Any day now, it will only be me and Clarissa Dickson Wright supporting the idea that half-dead squirrels should be knocked on the head.

When I finally got to London, my friend Julia Reed nearly choked on her martini when I told her why I was late. "What's happening to you people?" she said. She's from Mississippi. She once drove me along the levee at Greenville with a huntin' and shootin' neighbour, Warren. He told me how to shoot deer ("It's hard - they have a very acute olfactory sense and they kin smell you") and wild pig, and brought me up short with the words: "Y'all ever see an armadillo explode?" Er, no. He said they have a $20 bounty on them, because they burrow under the levee. "So most everybody in Greenville has a .22 pistol which they keep for armadillos." Julia just could not get her head round the squirrel thing. She said her friend Jessica ran over a raccoon last summer ("Raccoons are pests. Like squirrels") and took it straight back home to her maid, "who skinned it in a minute flat, and threw it in the pot for stew. It's a southern delicacy, coon stew". How very thrifty, I said. "More than that. She gave the skin back to Jessica, whose little boy is aged around eight, and she had somebody cure it and make him a genuine coonskin cap, which he has never taken off. He loves that thing. In Mississippi," she said, "we know how to deal with roadkill."

Lang may Michael Martin's lum reek

Poor Michael Martin, the new Speaker, is suffering a heavy barrage of frankly racist abuse after his heady rise to high office. It's true that his primordial Glasgow burr is barely comprehensible to the English ear (he goes home every single weekend, to refresh it), but at least he sounds like who he is.

You'd rather have him than Tony Blair's studied forays into matey estuarial, wouldn't you? I certainly would. I imagined that the Scottish press would be chuffed to bits about yer man from Springburn and tossing him bouquets. But they're giving him a hard time, too: the Scotsman and the Glasgow Herald both chundering away about "Papish conspiracies" and "the Catholic vote" that is supposed to have swung his election. (Poor ducks. Scots have no idea about how unconcerned and ungodly the English are.)

I'm rather pleased that he won. I was rooting for Gwyneth Dunwoody on the unarguable grounds that she's a woman and therefore not a Freemason. Papish plots I can disdain, but the whole creepy conspiracy of masonry makes me gnash my teeth with feminist rage. Betty Boothroyd was the first Speaker for centuries not to be a high-ranking Freemason; I believe Martin will be the second. We'll know for certain next January. The palace of Westminster has its own masonic lodge, which enjoys much junketing. All the masons tog up for a big Burns Supper every year, where they toast: "Here's tae us and wha's like us." Martin, who is, perhaps uniquely, a Glaswegian Catholic trade-unionist teetotaller, will not be raising his glass next year with the other befuddled tomnoddies. So lang may his lum reek, I say, and I hope he isn't toppled by a snap election before Burns Night.

The Latvian finance minister and me

I 'm thrilled to learn that Gundars Berzins, the Latvian minister of finance, has tooled up his office with a webcam, so that Latvians can tune in while he fiddles with the state finances. I'm not thrilled for the Latvians particularly, though it's pleasant to know that they actually have finance in Latvia now, and it won't only be done but seen to be done.

I'm pleased because I'm getting my own office tooled up with a webcam. Well, I say "office", but it's the top back bedroom under the eaves that doubles as a spare bedroom. It has one plug (at floor level) and one phone jack, and these people from Utah keep ringing me up to ask about cabling and ISDN lines. I have to get wired up with a mini-cam, plug into my PC screen and e-train down the wire with a personal e-trainer for three weeks on a treadmill, and then write a piece about how fit I've become. I said, I haven't got a treadmill! I haven't got a webcam! I haven't even got a PC! They said: "We'll ship it all over." From Utah? "From Utah." They've been ringing since February and now they're actually coming over in a fortnight. I've been fretting for weeks with technophobia, but I feel calmer now. If Latvians can wire up their finance minister, I'm sure Salt Lake City can cope with me.

She once drove me along the levee at Greenville with a huntin' and shootin' neighbour, Warren. He told me how to shoot deer ("It's hard - they have a very acute olfactory sense and they kin smell you") and wild pig, and brought me up short with the words: "Y'all ever see an armadillo explode?" Er, no. He said they have a $20 bounty on them, because they burrow under the levee. "So most everybody in Greenville has a .22 pistol which they keep for armadillos." Julia just could not get her head round the squirrel thing. She said her friend Jessica ran over a raccoon last summer ("Raccoons are pests. Like squirrels") and took it straight back home to her maid, "who skinned it in a minute flat, and threw it in the pot for stew. It's a southern delicacy, coon stew". How very thrifty, I said. "More than that. She gave the skin back to Jessica, whose little boy is aged around eight, and she had somebody cure it and make him a genuine coonskin cap, which he has never taken off. He loves that thing. In Mississippi," she said, "we know how to deal with roadkill." Lang may Michael Martin's lum reek Poor Michael Martin, the new Speaker, is suffering a heavy barrage of frankly racist abuse after his heady rise to high office. It's true that his primordial Glasgow burr is barely comprehensible to the English ear (he goes home every single weekend, to refresh it), but at least he sounds like who he is. You'd rather have him than Tony Blair's studied forays into matey estuarial, wouldn't you? I certainly would. I imagined that the Scottish press would be chuffed to bits about yer man from Springburn and tossing him bouquets. But they're giving him a hard time, too: the Scotsman and the Glasgow Herald both chundering away about "Papish conspiracies" and "the Catholic vote" that is supposed to have swung his election. (Poor ducks. Scots have no idea about how unconcerned and ungodly the English are.) I'm rather pleased that he won. I was rooting for Gwyneth Dunwoody on the unarguable grounds that she's a woman and therefore not a Freemason. Papish plots I can disdain, but the whole creepy conspiracy of masonry makes me gnash my teeth with feminist rage. Betty Boothroyd was the first Speaker for centuries not to be a high-ranking Freemason; I believe Martin will be the second. We'll know for certain next January. The palace of Westminster has its own masonic lodge, which enjoys much junketing. All the masons tog up for a big Burns Supper every year, where they toast: "Here's tae us and wha's like us." Martin, who is, perhaps uniquely, a Glaswegian Catholic trade-unionist teetotaller, will not be raising his glass next year with the other befuddled tomnoddies. So lang may his lum reek, I say, and I hope he isn't toppled by a snap election before Burns Night. The Latvian finance minister and me I 'm thrilled to learn that Gundars Berzins, the Latvian minister of finance, has tooled up his office with a webcam, so that Latvians can tune in while he fiddles with the state finances. I'm not thrilled for the Latvians particularly, though it's pleasant to know that they actually have finance in Latvia now, and it won't only be done but seen to be done. I'm pleased because I'm getting my own office tooled up with a webcam. Well, I say "office", but it's the top back bedroom under the eaves that doubles as a spare bedroom. It has one plug (at floor level) and one phone jack, and these people from Utah keep ringing me up to ask about cabling and ISDN lines. I have to get wired up with a mini-cam, plug into my PC screen and e-train down the wire with a personal e-trainer for three weeks on a treadmill, and then write a piece about how fit I've become. I said, I haven't got a treadmill! I haven't got a webcam! I haven't even got a PC! They said: "We'll ship it all over." From Utah? "From Utah." They've been ringing since February and now they're actually coming over in a fortnight. I've been fretting for weeks with technophobia, but I feel calmer now. If Latvians can wire up their finance minister, I'm sure Salt Lake City can cope with me.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Aer Lingus cancels flights|Amato defends UMTS auction|London Bridge buys Phoenix|No decision yet on Barings|ABB engineers tech transition
fields.body:
Aer Lingus cancels flights

Ireland's state-owned airline Aer Lingus said yesterday it would cancel a number of flights tomorrow when many of its 1,400 clerical workers are due to hold a four-hour strike.

Aer Lingus, which last week had to ground its fleet for one day due to a cabin crew strike, said the action would hit around 20% of scheduled flights tomorrow.

It was making contingency plans to try to minimise disruption, including rescheduling. Flights leaving Irish airports before 0900 GMT and after 1400 GMT were expected to operate normally.

The airline is fighting a series of industrial disputes over pay and conditions which threaten to delay its plans for privatisation, scheduled for 2001.

Amato defends UMTS auction

Italy's prime minister, Giuliano Amato, said his government set the right rules for the country's UMTS (advanced mobile phone) licence auction, and the opposition's charge of incompetence was unjustified. The rules were the same as those used in the UK, he said.

Commenting on the withdrawal of BT-backed consortium Blu from the contest, Mr Amato said the auction did not arrive at the result it should have and the Italian state had received less money than it could have.

The government plans to retain Blu's deposit because it claims the group breached rules on confidentiality.

London Bridge buys Phoenix

London Bridge Software Holdings said it agreed to fully acquire Phoenix International for up to $45.5m (£31.4m) cash.

LBSH said the £51.9m raised in its cash placing earlier this month will fund the purchase and provide working capital to restore Phoenix to financial stability and profitability.

Additionally, LBSH signed a loan agreement to provide Phoenix with up to $10m to cover potential funding requirements.

No decision yet on Barings

ING Group has not yet taken a decision on whether or not to scrap the Barings brand name, according to spokeswoman Roelina Bolding.

ING chairman Ewald Kist has said the firm "is keeping all options open in the case of ING Barings." Scrapping the Barings name was just one of the possible options in the company's process of "reassessing" brand strategy.

ABB engineers tech transition

Switzerland's ABB said the appointment of Jorgen Centerman as chief executive officer sealed its transition from manufacturing to technology.

But ABB shares fell 7.4% after it reported mixed nine-month results and postponed a New York listing - planned for this quarter to raise its profile with US funds - until 2001 because of volatile tech stock markets.

webTitle: Portraits of the century go on show

fields.headline: Biting image
fields.standfirst: Portraits of the century go on show
fields.trailText: A bitterly satirical portrait of former prime minister Margaret Thatcher is back in Britain for the first time since it provoked uproar in an exhibtion at the Tate by lampooning art collector Charles Saatchi and his close connection with the gallery.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A bitterly satirical portrait of former prime minister Margaret Thatcher is back in Britain for the first time since it provoked uproar in an exhibtion at the Tate by lampooning art collector Charles Saatchi and his close connection with the gallery.

Mr Saatchi, famous for buying the complete contents of studios of artists he likes, chose not to add this one to his collection. Since 1984 it has been in a private collection in the United States, and has come back on temporary loan to the Painting the Century exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, which opens today.

The painting by the German artist Hans Haacke was the star exhibit in his one man show in the Tate in 1984, and poured petrol on an already blazing arts row.

Charles and his twin brother Maurice are portrayed in the cracked plates on the top shelf of the book case. The painting pillories the Iron Lady's assault on cultural institutions, and the Saatchi and Saatchi advertising campaigns credited with winning her elections in 1979 and 1983 - the books on the shelves carry the names of Saatchi and Saatchi accounts.

But it also specifically refers to a furious row over the Tate's closeness to Charles. He was a member of its patrons of new art committee, and it emerged that he owned almost all the paintings in two exhibitions the committee organised. The paintings were by Jennifer Bartlett, who had been commissioned to design Saatchi's dining room, and New York artist Julian Schnabel. The exhibitions were seen as boosting sale prices. The paper on the table refers to sales from the Saatchi collection.

As a result of the row, the Saatchis broke their connection with the Tate and opened their own gallery of contemporary art in 1985.

Yesterday Robin Gibson, curator of the National Portrait Gallery exhibition, said: "The irony is that 16 years later Charles Saatchi is acknowledged to be one of the strongest forces in the contemporary art market in Britain, and the painting looks increasingly like one of the most memorable images of Margaret Thatcher ever produced."

Mr Gibson has chosen one painting to represent each year from 1900 to 2000, beginning with a monumentally glum Queen Victoria.

The portraits include many of the most celebrated images of the century, including Andy Warhol's double portrait of a gun toting Elvis Presley.

webTitle: Labour party: Rules Chairman is caught out

fields.headline: Rules chairman is caught out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Conservatives scored a hit on Labour on the running tit-for-tat battle over parliamentary sleaze yesterday when, Robert Sheldon, the veteran Labour chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, fell foul of the disclosure rules.
fields.body:
The Conservatives scored a hit on Labour on the running tit-for-tat battle over parliamentary sleaze yesterday when, Robert Sheldon, the veteran Labour chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, fell foul of the disclosure rules.

As Mr Sheldon was criticised for not declaring a financial interest in four textile firms during debates on the small business sector, Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, simultaneously found in favour of Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor.

Similar complaints had been laid against Mr Portillo for failing to register correctly fees paid for speeches outside parliament. After a two month inquiry he was cleared - but not former treasury minister, Mr Sheldon.

Mr Sheldon was cleared on seven complaints made by Tory MP, Ian Bruce, but caught out on two, with both sides point scoring over ever tighter disclosure rules in the post-Nolan era. Mr Portillo had been accused by Labour's Chris Leslie. In her report on Mr Sheldon, MP for Ashton under Lyne since 1964, Mrs Filkin said: "Given the nature of (his) business interests, it would have been advisable for him to make a declaration in all of the 12 debates. This conclusion is not affected by the fact that in none of his interventions was (he) seeking assistance specifically for the textile industry."

On Tuesday the committee, chaired by Labour's Alan Williams after Mr Sheldon withdrew, upheld the report but decided against further action on a "marginal" case where the MP had declared his interests in writing, but not in debates he thought "too broad and diffuse" to be relevant.

In Mr Portillo's case the MP had, after some delay, registered speaking fees after seeking guidance from Mrs Filkin, but Mr Leslie claimed he had an unregistered "employment contract" with a speakers bureau.

Mr Sheldon's case was complex and spread over many years. Mrs Filkin, a stickler for the rules, concluded it would have been "advisable" for him to explain his ties during economic debates.

webTitle: New call for wider EU data access

fields.headline: New call for wider EU data access
fields.trailText: European Union states are being asked to approve new freedom of information plans granting their citizens the right to see documents from any institution in Brussels.
fields.body:
European Union states are being asked to approve new freedom of information plans granting their citizens the right to see documents from any institution in Brussels.

The challenge, which follows a vote on Tuesday, comes from the European Parliament's citizens' rights committee and, if successful, would grant unprecedented access to all but the most sensitive defence and foreign policy paper.

Michael Cashman, the committee's rapporteur, said yesterday that he hoped governments would respond positively.

"We are seeking a change of culture," said Mr Cashman, Labour MEP for the West Midlands. "This is about accessing information that matters to citizens and that will make European institutions more accessible and accountable. "

The proposals - which call for a public register of documents, a tight list of exemptions and access to papers held by all EU institutions - are being tabled in accord with the 1997 treaty of Amsterdam, itself a response to years of concern about a lack of transparency in the EU.

But Tony Bunyan of the civil liberties group Statewatch, disputed whether the plan would enhance access or fulfill treaty requirements.

webTitle: Letters: Green movement and the fuel crisis

fields.headline: Green gripe
fields.trailText: The idea that the Green movement "vanished" during the fuel crisis (Letters, October 25) is becoming an urban myth. Throughout the crisis, Green politicians were involved in a constant round of media interviews, strongly opposing any cut in fuel duty. That we did not have a higher profile is largely due to the media's desire to focus on images of militant hauliers and a crisis-hit government. Still, given Tony Blair's new-found environmentalism, he'll be putting arguments for fuel tax himself next time, rather than leaving it to the Greens. Won't he?

fields.headline: On your bike, Connex
fields.trailText: As a long-suffering passenger on the Hastings-Charing Cross Line, how come Connex has been allowed to keep its south-east franchise?
fields.body:
As a long-suffering passenger on the Hastings-Charing Cross Line, how come Connex has been allowed to keep its south-east franchise? The rolling stock is so filthy it is best not described here in detail lest readers have not yet had their breakfast. I must be one of thousands who have written to complain about blocked lavatories, litter-strewn floors and disgusting seating - to no avail.
Ann Kramer
Hastings, E Sussex

We may be the only passengers disappointed by the demise of the Connex South Central rail franchise. At present there are around 30 regular cyclists who commute from London to Brighton, taking bikes on the train. The government's integrated transport white paper requires rail operators to provide "sufficient" onboard storage for cycles, but none of the other franchisees running services into London (from anywhere) permit carriage of cycles during the rush hour, including GoVia's Thameslink and Thames Trains. We are now faced with an uphill battle to maintain an existing standard of service which is practical, environmentally responsible and in line with government policy.
Richard Lindley
Cyclists on Connex

fields.headline: Money for the Dome, but not for Hackney
fields.trailText: The financial crisis in Hackney (Nurseries close as council faces £40m cash gap, October 24) is threatening a virtual meltdown in essential services. This is thanks to years of underfunding by central government and incompetence and kow-towing to big business by local councillors. What I want to know is why those of us who live in Hackney are being made to pay for a crisis not of our making?
fields.body:
The financial crisis in Hackney (Nurseries close as council faces £40m cash gap, October 24) is threatening a virtual meltdown in essential services. This is thanks to years of underfunding by central government and incompetence and kow-towing to big business by local councillors. What I want to know is why those of us who live in Hackney are being made to pay for a crisis not of our making?

The government says it can't bail out incompetent councils that overspend. Yet it has no problem bailing out the incompetently run privatised rail companies and the ridiculous Millennium Dome with billions of pounds. Why is it punishing Hackney for being poor? The government says it is pledged to massively expanding pre-school childcare. Yet it has ordered Hackney to slash services, including nursery provision. People in Hackney are fed up with the way all three main parties treat us. The low turnout of 18% in the Hackney Wick by-election earlier this month, in which I stood as the London Socialist Alliance candidate, reflects this disillusionment.

It is becoming increasingly clear that direct action is the only way to make this government and our councils listen to us. Since last Friday I have been in occupation at my son's nursery, one of two nurseries in Hackney that parents have occupied since the council ordered them to close. We are standing together to make sure the government puts its money where its mouth is.
Diana Swingler
Hackney, London

 It is tempting to explain Hackney's chaos by reference to complex social problems that simply overwhelm services. But why does neighbouring Newham, which has at least equal difficulties, manage so much better? It is generally agreed that "one-party state" councils are likely to be slovenly and even corrupt, whilst balanced ones are lean and sharp. But Newham has had less than 10 non-Labour members in 20 years and Hackney is hung.

These contrasting experiences present a rare opportunity for a serious study. It seems likely, however, we will see a witch-hunt leading to less democracy, rather than some quiet contemplation to aid its strengthening.
David Helliwell
Halifax

fields.headline: Flood plans
fields.trailText: The Environment Agency takes an extremely strong stance against any proposed new development which would put life and property at risk from flooding (Letters, October 16). Each year, the agency considers thousands of planning applications and we make our objections clear . But we still find that planning authorities consent to around 20% of the 1,000 or so applications to which we object on flood risk grounds. Ministers made encouraging sounds recently about strengthening planning guidance. We would welcome a clear presumption in the guidance against building in the flood plain, if the planning system is to deliver responsible decisions that will reduce, rather than increase, the risk to future generations.

In the same paper you report that Lord Cullen, chair of the Dunblane inquiry, ordered that a police report into Thomas Hamilton's firearm history be kept secret for 100 years (Public demands answers). Hamilton murdered 13 children. What is being hidden?
Bruce Robinson
Dorstone, Herefordshire

Re the dangers lurking on long-haul flights (Letters, October 25): as a regular over-70 transatlantic economy passenger, I wear a pair of surgical support stockings which has proved a simple, cheap and - so far at least - effective means of maintaining good circulation in my legs.
Bill Youdale
Etchingham, E Sussex

Not only did you crop off the mystery man in Manet's picture (Letters, Monday 23), but also the bottle of Bass beer. Its red triangle is said to be the world's first registered trade mark. Did Manet receive any sponsorship, making it the first stealth advertisement?
Ted Gunby
Sheffield

You say the Spanish Foreign Legion marches at 120 paces a minute (Spain lured by romance of the Legion, October 24). That is the average for the Spanish army. The Foreign Legion marching step is 160 paces a minute.
Eduardo Barrachina
 Sheffield

The Dome's final event is to be a New Year's rave organised by the Ministry of Sound (Dome's not-so-amazing last day, October 24). I'm glad to see a government department taking an interest at last.
Toby Wood
Peterborough

Who is the Minister for Sound? My guess would be Dennis Skinner.
Paul Palmer
Ellesmere Port, Wirral

fields.headline: More digs at students
fields.trailText: As the organiser of the conference looking at the implications of growing numbers of students resident within the community, it was interesting to compare your article (Two square miles of housing hell, October 24), regurgitating the well-known views of Harold Best MP, with Anne Power's excellent article (City Limits, Society, October 25). The real issues in Headingley fit into the wider picture of inner-city urban depopulation. The only difference with other inner-city areas is that young people actually want to live there.
fields.body:
As the organiser of the conference looking at the implications of growing numbers of students resident within the community, it was interesting to compare your article (Two square miles of housing hell, October 24), regurgitating the well-known views of Harold Best MP, with Anne Power's excellent article (City Limits, Society, October 25). The real issues in Headingley fit into the wider picture of inner-city urban depopulation. The only difference with other inner-city areas is that young people actually want to live there. What is more, housing standards are not poor and investment, mainly by the private sector, has been substantial. Over 80% of owners in Headingley meet, voluntarily, a code of standards, which reflects their long-term commitment to the area.

Of course rapid social change needs managing. The universities in Leeds, the local authority, the charity sector and local community groups are all making efforts to tackle problems of crime and security, waste disposal and tolerance of different lifestyle issues. Tomorrow's conference is about sharing examples of best practice.

Those who are critical of young people living in the inner city represent the same policy-makers who have seen our urban core decline over the last 20 years and who have no alternative solutions.
Martin Blakey
Unipol Student Homes M.J.Blakey@unipol.leeds.ac.uk

 Both Leeds University and Leeds Metropolitan University were a benign influence in the past, converting large old houses, too big for modern families, to residences and maintaining swathes of open space as playing fields. Now landlordism is biting into established family areas and the results are the kind of squalor seen in your photograph. The idea that students are a "regenenerative" influence would strike most local residents as a sick joke - there is not one greengrocer now in Headingley, for instance, though take-aways, pubs and cheap cafes are thick on the ground.

The blame lies with the manic pursuit by government of ever-rising student numbers. A real campaign of regeneration would see new student housing developed in south and east Leeds. The universities have a responsibility to develop housing to contain the young people they impose on the city. Nottingham's new inner-city campus demonstrates how positive an influence universities can be in regenerating cities.
Kenneth Powell
London

 Your article struck a chord with those of us living in Dunkirk and Lenton, Nottingham. Next year Nottingham council has set itself a target of 220 houses in the whole of the city to be inspected and registered as "shared houses" and houses in multiple occupation (HMOs) - fewer than five a week and some indication of the low priority given to tackling a problem which threatens to destroy the inner-city community in which I live.

Before universities are allowed to expand further, they should be made to provide suitable student accommodation on their own land and local councils should be given the power to control the numbers of HMOs in any one street (say 25%). More importantly, local councils should require the same standards of provision, in terms of quality, management and fire safety, from private landlords as they expect of housing associations.

We want to live in a vibrant, multicultural community: the way Dunkirk and Lenton used to be. The prospect of this diminishes every day. I only hope it isn't too late for places like Headingley, Selly Oak, Dunkirk and Lenton.
Robert Howard
Dunkirk & Lenton Partnership Forum

fields.headline: Navan's golden future
fields.trailText: Bid speculation continues to surround Navan Mining, the resources company with interests in Spain and Bulgaria. According to latest reports, Managem, a subsidiary of a Moroccan company ONA, is poised to make an offer for it.
fields.body:
Bid speculation continues to surround Navan Mining, the resources company with interests in Spain and Bulgaria. According to latest reports, Managem, a subsidiary of a Moroccan company ONA, is poised to make an offer for it.

But investors might be heartened to hear there are good reasons for taking a look at the company. Navan's house broker, SG Securities, has just published a research note in which it labels the stock a "strong buy" and sets a 151p target price. Last night Navan shares stood at 84p.

SG's new price is based on the potential of its gold discovery at the Krumovgrad site in southern Bulgaria. SG reckons the site could be worth as much as $30m (£21m) if it yields 1m ounces of gold and is suitable for open cast mining.

Over the the next year, SG sees Navan's earnings pushing ahead as its mines cash in on demand for precious metals.
