fields.headline: Serbia-style rising fells African junta
fields.trailText: Directly inspired by the popular uprising that felled Serbia's strongman, street protests in the Ivory Coast swept out the west African state's first and only military dictator yesterday, after less than a year in power.
fields.body:
Directly inspired by the popular uprising that felled Serbia's strongman, street protests in the Ivory Coast swept out the west African state's first and only military dictator yesterday, after less than a year in power.

General Robert Guei is in hiding after trying - like Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade - to declare himself the winner of an election. The apparent victor of Sunday's poll was a civilian and socialist, Laurent Gbagbo.

When the general's aim became clear on Tuesday, Mr Gbagbo called for a Belgrade-style revolt against the ruling junta. His supporters defied an emergency curfew to take to the streets of the capital, Abidjan, and soldiers mutinied to join them. In the resulting clashes Tuesday night and yesterday, at least 13 died.

As the last bursts of gunfire rang out in Abidjan yesterday, Mr Gbagbo praised supporters of his Ivorian Popular Front for repelling Gen Guei's "electoral coup d'état".

"I thank you for responding massively to this appeal. You went out in the hundreds of thousands. I pay particular homage to those who died in the cause of this. We will give them a funeral befitting their courage," he said.

He also called for national conciliation - and he will need it if he is to stay in power. Two bigger parties, whose leaders were banned by the supreme court from contesting the election, are demanding a new poll in which all are free to run.

It was a power struggle between these two parties - the perennial party of government, the Parti Démocratique de Côte d'Ivoire, and its rival, the Rassemblement des Républicains - that gave Gen Guei his coup opening in December. But if this scenario is about to repeat itself and the army is tempted to step in again, the general's fate may act as a deterrent.

Abandoned by his soldiers and denounced by senior colleagues scrambling to distance themselves from the junta in which they took part, he was thought by some to have fled to nearby Benin, where his wife Rose and some of his children arrived on a small plane yesterday.

But the chief of Ivory Coast's defence staff, Diabakate Soumahila, told Radio France International that Gen Guei was still in Abidjan.

It was on Monday afternoon that the only independent tally of voting in the election was given by the election commission. It showed Mr Gbagbo with a slight edge over Gen Guei after a fraction of the votes had been counted.

On Tuesday, as tension grew over the lack of final results, the junta announced that the commission had been dissolved. An interior ministry official gave the final tally as 52.72% of the vote for Gen Guei, and 41.02% for Mr Gbagbo. Three lesser known candidates shared the rest.

But Mr Gbagbo said he believed he had got 59.58%, compared to 32.91% for Gen Guei.

Later Tuesday, the general went on state TV to thank the people of the Ivory Coast who, he said, "like one man, in a great wave of dignity and solidarity, have just taken me to the head of the country."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
United News & Media: Contrary to what we said in an article headed Give the Crusader a fighting chance, page 5, Media, October 23, the stock exchange did not "demand an explanation" from United News & Media concerning unsolicited approaches for Express Newspapers. United voluntarily issued a statement. Nor has Andrew Neil, managing editor of the Barclay brothers' press holdings, held talks with Bernard Gray, United's director of strategy. We apologise for those errors.

In a review of a performance by the reggae musician Lee Perry at The Forum, London, page 25, October 19, the writer of the piece, Maxine Kabuubi, made unacknowledged use of three distinctive passages from two articles published by the magazine, The Wire. Two passages were taken from an article by Ian Penman which appeared in The Wire in June this year. One was taken from an article by Simon Reynolds which appeared in The Wire in September this year. Ms Kabuubi apologises unreservedly to the writers of the original pieces and to the editor of The Wire.

Question Time is not to be moved from its place on BBC1 on Thursdays, contrary to what we said in a panel, The ratings war: the prime movers, page 7, Media, October 23.

In a leader headed House of ill repute, page 21, October 24, we described Edward Heath as leader of the house. He is not. He is father of the house.

The photograph accompanying a piece headed Evocative tastes of the orchard, page 9, Society, yesterday, was by James Ravilious (not Rivelius).

In our obituary of Eduard Goldstücker, page 24, yesterday, we said, "He passionately opposed the distortion of truth and the fortification of history." Falsification, that should have been. Our mistake.


It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible.
Please quote the date and page number.

fields.headline: Placebo effect hits Cantab
fields.trailText: To say that 2000 has been an annus horribilis for one of Britain's oldest biotechnology firms, Cantab Pharmaceuticals, would be something an understatement.
fields.body:
To say that 2000 has been an annus horribilis for one of Britain's oldest biotechnology firms, Cantab Pharmaceuticals, would be something an understatement.

The company's leading product, a vaccine for genital warts, has failed in clinical trials - it proved no more effective than a placebo. That news has prompted SmithKline Beecham, down 11p to 912p, to pull the plug on their partnership agreement.

On top of that merger talks with rival Peptide Therapeutics, unchanged at 97.5p, failed during the summer - Peptide decided to link up with north American firm Baxter instead - and Glaxo Wellcome, off 18p to £20.02, was forced to pull out of a partnership for a genital herpes vaccine because of its imminent merger with SmithKline Beecham.

All of which has left Cantab shareholders nursing some serious losses. From 700p in March, Cantab shares have fallen in an almost unbroken decline to yesterday's closing price of 78p.

However, this particular story could have a very happy ending. According to Cantab insiders a board meeting is taking place today, and gossips claim the chief topic of discussion will be the future of chief executive Jurek Sikorski.

Apparently Cantab's largest shareholders want Mr Sikorski out. It seems that the former Swindon Town football star has been reluctant to commit himself to corporate action despite the fact that various offers, including a full bid or joint venture, have been put on the table.

While there can be no doubting the scale of Cantab's problems it still has attractive assets. It has six vaccines in the pipeline and more than £20m in the bank - enough to cover losses for two years. But yesterday's share price valued the company at just £35m, a fact that will not have been lost on venture capital firm Apax, which has recently snapped up a 9.1% stake. Cantab refused to comment on the speculation.

In the wider market, leading shares closed lower for the first time in five sessions as technology stocks moved sharply lower in reaction to news of unexpectedly soft sales figures from telecoms kit maker Nortel Networks.

A weak performance from the heavyweight drug sector in the wake of a weak set of figures from AstraZenca, off 80p to £31.70p, also affected market sentiment.

The FTSE 100 ended 70.6 points weaker at 6,367.8, having dipped to 6,330 at one point. The FTSE 250 fell 19.7 points to 6,544.4 and the Techmark slipped 83.55 points to 3,457.7.

Optical chip maker Bookham Technology led the market lower. It shares fell 371p, or 13.27%, to £24.24 on the back of the Nortel figures - not a surprising reaction given that Nortel is Bookham's biggest customer, accounting for well over half its sales. Marconi, a rival to Nortel Networks, also suffered, losing 80p to finish at 870p. In the rest of technology sector things were no better. With the Nasdaq moving sharply lower from the outset, IT services group Logica surrendered 156p to £20.20, while competitor Misys fell 38p to 757p.

After Tuesday's strong gains telecoms stocks were hit by a flurry of profit-taking. BT was the worst affected, losing 34p to 754p with Energis, off 26p to 528p, and Vodafone, down 7p to 278p, also being hit.

On the up side, utilities retailers were in demand as investors looked for safe places to park their cash in the aftermath of the Nortel-related shake down. Saninsbury improved 12p to 371p, while National Grid put on 16p to 609p and Scottish & Southern, with benefit of a CSFB upgrade, added 18p to 587.

Lower in the market computer games retailer Gameplay rose 4.5p to 194.5p on talk that Goldman Sachs will soon start coverage of the firm with a positive recommendation.

Getmapping.com, best known for having attracted the Queen as an initial shareholder, rose 7p to 55p after two directors bought shares.

fields.headline: At this price?  Invensys
fields.trailText: Every man and his dog seems to be buying shares in the automation and controls group Invensys of late.
fields.body:
Every man and his dog seems to be buying shares in the automation and controls group Invensys of late.

Yesterday the stock shot up a further 9% in exceptionally heavy turnover amid chatter that bid is on the way. The market's favourite is the Swiss company ABB - based, it seems, on the fact that its new chief executive, Jorgen Centerman, used to head Invensys' automation unit.

While General Electric's $45bn bid for Honeywell has put consolidation back on the sector's agenda, there might be a more rational explanation for the movement.

The market overreacted to September's profit warning and the acquisition of Dutch software house Bann. The 50% slide in Invensys' stock price in the wake of the warning was almost unprecedented for a blue chip.

The company did its best to take the sting out of the news with an immediate restructuring and 3,000 jobs to be axed, but it did not stop £3bn being wiped off the value.

Based on the Honeywell take-out price, the slide left Invensys looking too cheap. Before its takeover, Honeywell was trading at an 80% premium to Invensys and GE offered 50% on top of that.

Admittedly, Invensys has said earnings will be affected by the weak euro, slowing US demand and rising raw material prices, but so have its US peers, and that did not stop bidders vying for Honeywell.

According to figures from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, Invensys' powers systems business will increase operating profits by around 40% this year. Dresdner reckons that the business is worth around 130p, which means that the rest of the firm is almost in for free.

Shareholders might not have liked the Bann acquisition but "e-manufacturing" offers radical boosts to total productivity and customer satisfaction.

So what is Invensys worth? Based on the share prices of its peers, Dresdner has a target price of 200p for Invensys, which seems about right. Buy.

Based on the Honeywell take-out price, the slide left Invensys looking too cheap. Before its takeover, Honeywell was trading at an 80% premium to Invensys and GE offered 50% on top of that. Admittedly, Invensys has said earnings will be affected by the weak euro, slowing US demand and rising raw material prices, but so have its US peers, and that did not stop bidders vying for Honeywell. According to figures from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, Invensys' powers systems business will increase operating profits by around 40% this year. Dresdner reckons that the business is worth around 130p, which means that the rest of the firm is almost in for free. Shareholders might not have liked the Bann acquisition but "e-manufacturing" offers radical boosts to total productivity and customer satisfaction. So what is Invensys worth? Based on the share prices of its peers, Dresdner has a target price of 200p for Invensys, which seems about right. Buy.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
When last we came across Mary Ellen Synon, she was receiving deposits at the Bank of England, on the office floor, from the deputy governor, Rupert Pennant-Rea. Today, the journalist is in Ireland, and works as the feisty rightwing woman columnist on Tony O'Reilly's Sunday Independent. But what form she has struck. Her last column concerned the Paralympics, which she described as "grotesque" and, indeed, "perverse". Questioning the need to applaud "the physical performance of the lame" as we do "the fit", she explained that competition "is not about finding someone who can wobble his way around a track in a wheelchair, or can swim from one end of a pool to the other by Braille". Oh dear. Following some pithy letters to the paper, ferocious criticism from across the board (including Bertie Ahern), yesterday's apology from editor Aengus Fanning was sensationally grovelling. Whether Ms Synon, who declines to comment, has done to her editor's career what she once did to Mr Pennant-Rea on Eddie George's office floor is unclear, but news of her own departure is expected soon.

Belated commiserations, for returning figures of 1-56 off seven overs against England last Friday, to Pakistani cricketer Yasir Arafat. We hope to see Yasir soon when his country next tours England, and will even sponsor him lavishly so long as, purely for the merriment, he agrees to fly here with El Al.

Recently, the Diary wondered whether Millbank might find a way to avoid debating any of the 11 motions calling for Ken Livingstone's reinstatement and seven more against part-privatisation of the Tube at the London Labour party conference on November 11. Well, would you believe it, the conference arrangement committee chaired by Blairite sycophant Jim Fitzpatrick has decided that none of these motions is sufficiently "contemporary" to debate. Instead, they will be discussed in workshops. At the arrangements committee meeting, one ironical member asked whether a motion about the Hatfield train crash might be considered contemporary. Certainly not, was the reply. Will they never learn?

With Jim about to depart, a new London Labour party leader is sought, the battle seemingly between two Unison men, garrulous leftie Geoff Martin and Blairite dullard Chris Robbins. More amusingly, Mr Robbins's would-be deputy is Catherine Smith, who established herself as a footnote in the compendium of political fiasco last year when, from her hospital bed, she orchestrated the South London Co-op's decision not to ballot members, thus delivering the Labour mayoral selection to Frank Dobson.

A bizarre letter, with a Bradford postmark, has been sent to Mori pollster Robert Worcester. "If Bob Worcester does not start issuing true opinion polls from next week," begins the anonymous note, "Labour will blow the story of why Maggie was kicked out - for using fake opinion polls." A little obscure. "When this story gets out, no one will believe Mori polls ever again." Prof Worcester, who says he has never had a threatening note before in all his decades of polling, is a little spooked. If anyone can shed light, get in touch.

More Carry On Up the Cabinet suggestions arrive, with Joan Sims mooted for Harriet Harman (I'd have gone for Una Stubbs myself). And John O'Keefe emails all the way from from Prague proposing Professor Stanley Unwin for John Prescott "as they both seem to possess the same verbal dexterity and clarity." John asks if it matters whether the professor ever appeared in a Carry On. Not really. Anyone from the world of entertainment can be cast, and the cartoon character Deputy Dawg is even now considering an offer to play his doppelgänger, Lord Irvine of Lairg.

webTitle: Big four under fire for poor service to small business

fields.headline: Big four under fire for poor service to small business
fields.trailText: The big four banks will next week face criticism that the services they provide to small businesses are indistinguishable in terms of service and charges.
fields.body:
The big four banks will next week face criticism that the services they provide to small businesses are indistinguishable in terms of service and charges.

Research by the Mid Yorkshire Chamber of Commerce, which will be released at a public hearing next week, is understood to have concluded that small businesses felt they were not being offered any real alternatives by the banks. While the researchers found no evidence of collusion over the charges and rates of interest set by banks, it was felt the prices showed a remarkable similarity.

The research will form the core of the case against the banks at next week's open meeting being held by the competition commission as part of its scrutiny of the level of competition in small business banking between Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Barclays and HSBC.

Between them, the big four provide banking services to 80% of small businesses and are being investigated on the recommendation of Don Cruickshank after his review of competition in the sector.

Facing their critics in public for the first time, the big four are expected to try to argue that while they have a dominant position in the small banking sector, they do not abuse it. They are likely to point to announcements by banks such as Halifax and Alliance & Leicester of new products for small business as evidence that there are no barriers deterring new banks setting up in the sector.

At the public meeting next Friday, presentations will be made by senior business bankers from Barclays, Lloyds TSB and HSBC. NatWest, now owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland, will attend the hearing.

A Barclays spokesman said: "We are in a competitive market which is becoming more competitive. Technology is changing the rules of the game. We have worked very hard to improve our relationship with small business and seen our market share grow. But, we are not complacent."

webTitle: Psychologist in affair with client can still practise

fields.headline: Psychologist in affair with client can still practise
fields.trailText: A psychologist who had an improper relationship with a vulnerable woman client was expelled from his professional body yesterday - but can continue to practise because of a legal loophole.
fields.body:
A psychologist who had an improper relationship with a vulnerable woman client was expelled from his professional body yesterday - but can continue to practise because of a legal loophole.

Timothy Naylor, 39, had unprotected sex with the woman and warned her that if she told anyone she would lose her job and her child, it was claimed.

The British Psychological Society heard Mr Naylor took on the client, who had "sexually related" problems, privately and worked with her unsupervised despite having "low level" qualifications.

Even though its three-man disciplinary committee, sitting in public for the first time, concluded unanimously that the pair had a sexual relationship, the BPS admitted that it could not stop him from practising.

The case highlights the lack of statutory powers to stop poorly qualified people from practising as psychologists.

Mr Naylor, who is married, met the woman, identified as Mrs X, in June 1997. The woman had suffered medical negligence. They met in a pub and he gave her his home telephone number. Later they met at his home in York.

Patricia Hitchcock, counsel for the BPS, said Mrs X claimed that she had unprotected sex with Mr Naylor in October 1997. The woman said Mr Naylor had told her he had "done this" many times before. Mr Naylor denies this. Mrs X made a complaint in June 1999. Harrogate Healthcare Trust, where Mr Naylor was working, sacked him. Ms Hitchcock said he admitted to his employers that the relationship was sexual though he has not done so to the BPS.

Mr Naylor did not appear in person but, in a written statement, said: "The client made it very clear that she wished the relationship to be much more than client and counsellor. Personal and professional relationships were becoming blurred. I lacked the training to deal with this ... I was aware of the danger of being drawn into personal relationships with patients but believed that patients who have been abused would not seek to establish any romantic relationship with their therapist."

Professor Bill Lindsay, a member of the BPS investigatory panel, said he would not have expected Mr Naylor to be qualified enough to counsel Mrs X. He said he should have known he was supposed to be supervised and take notes.

Mr Naylor graduated from Bristol University in 1982 with a degree in theology. Subsequently he completed a psychology diploma and a BPS exam. He became a graduate member of the BPS in 1996.

The committee found him guilty of entering into an inappropriate relationship with a client, practising psychology outside his field of competence and failing to seek supervision. He now works as a teacher but is also embarking on a psychology MSc and has expressed a desire to get back into psychology.

After the hearing, BPS chief executive, Barry Brooking, said that Mr Naylor could set himself up as a psychologist again. He said that most NHS authorities checked with the BPS before employing a psychologist. But he could work in private practice without fear of being prosecuted.

He said: "We are pressing for a system of statutory registration so that anyone practising psychology has undergone an approved course."

The Department of Health said that all NHS bodies were obliged to vet potential employers. But because the BPS is not a statutory body there is no procedure which obliges NHS bosses to consult with the BPS. The BPS was planning to send details of Mr Naylor to all health authorities. Governed by royal charter, the BPS has 34,000 members, including 9,000 chartered - "fully qualified" - psychologists.

fields.headline: Flying high
fields.standfirst: Airbus orders boom
fields.trailText: Booming orders for the Airbus range of aircraft should produce better than expected earnings at the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), the Franco-German-Spanish rival to BAE Systems said yesterday.
fields.body:
Booming orders for the Airbus range of aircraft should produce better than expected earnings at the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), the Franco-German-Spanish rival to BAE Systems said yesterday.

Announcing the first financial results since Eads was formed from the merger of France's Aerospatiale Matra, Germany's Dasa and Spain's Casa, Philippe Camus, co-chief executive, said business activity in commercial aircraft far exceeded the group's expectations of as recently as July's Farnborough air show.

Airbus, in which Eads holds an 80% stake, won 476 firm orders last year, giving it a 55% share of the global market it shares with Boeing, and industry sources said it was on track to secure around 490 orders this year.

In the first nine months of 2000 Airbus, in which BAE holds the remaining 20% stake, won 305 firm orders, taking its global total to just below 4,000, and delivered 218 aircraft.

Eads said the order intake would be worth €28bn-€29bn (£16.8bn-£17.4bn) this year, compared with €20.7bn in 1999, while Airbus said deliveries should be 307.

Mr Camus said in Paris that production of the smaller A320 family of aircraft was being stepped up to 30 a month, while output of the longer-range A330/340 family would rise from five a month to eight.

"We don't see any sign of a slowdown and Airbus is increasing production capacity of both short and long-range aircraft," he said, indicating that deliveries in 2002 would be 400 aircraft compared with the 350 initially expected.

Pre-tax earnings in the first half the year were €553m, largely due to the €516m booked by Airbus - including €440m secured through currency fluctuations.

fields.headline: US sales drop hits AstraZeneca
fields.standfirst: Competition intensifies as patent on leading ulcer drug runs out
fields.trailText: Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, yesterday warned that its sales were falling short of its own expectations because of a slowdown in US usage of the world's top selling prescription medicine, the ulcer treatment Losec.
fields.body:
Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, yesterday warned that its sales were falling short of its own expectations because of a slowdown in US usage of the world's top selling prescription medicine, the ulcer treatment Losec.

The group admitted that despite its earlier promise of double-digit growth in annual turnover, the actual increase is likely to be just 8%. The news sent the shares tumbling 6% at one point, although after a late rally, they closed down 80p at £31.70.

Finance director Jonathan Symonds said: "This is not something we've done lightly. We felt it was better to be clear to the market just what we're expecting, rather than allow it to come as a surprise."

Losec is gradually losing its patent protection around the world. Competitors are rapidly moving in ahead of the imminent end of its protection in the US.

Mr Symonds said AstraZeneca had underestimated the aggression with which its rivals would slash their prices: "We are seeing a much more competitive market out there. Two new products have been launched and there has been discounting to a much greater extent than anticipated."

AstraZeneca is reluctant to devote money to price cuts and promotions of its own. It wants to hold fire ahead of the US launch of Nexium, its follow-up to Losec, in the new year. Nexium went on sale in Britain four weeks ago and already, doctors have prescribed it 5,000 times.

The setback emerged as AstraZeneca announced a 15% rise in pre-tax profits to $3.4bn (£2.3bn) for the first nine months of the year. The company insisted that despite the shortfall in sales, its profits remain on track because of higher than expected savings from its merger last year and tight management of its research and development budget.

Analysts said the news was significant in terms of market sentiment. Alyson Coates of SG Securities, who has been negative on the shares all year, said: "Investors are beginning to take notice of the risks in the company's gastro-intestinal franchise."

The number of prescriptions of Losec increased 4.4% in the US during the third quarter but AstraZeneca's overall US sales fell 1% to $1.92bn, partly because of changes in stocking patterns by wholesalers.

The company stressed that its younger products were doing better, including schizophrenia drug Seroquel and cancer treatments Casodex and Arimidex.

The group has high hopes in the long term for a heart drug called ZD4522, which is still in clinical trials.

fields.headline: Carlton captures SMG airtime sales
fields.standfirst: 100 job losses to go at TSMS after latest ITV skirmish
fields.trailText: The consolidation and shake-up of ITV continued yesterday as Carlton Communications picked up the contract to handle Scottish Media Group's £120m-a-year television advertising sales.
fields.body:
The consolidation and shake-up of ITV continued yesterday as Carlton Communications picked up the contract to handle Scottish Media Group's £120m-a-year television advertising sales.

The company's subsidiary, Carlton Sales, will take over selling airtime for SMG's Scottish and Grampian ITV subsidiaries on January 1 as part of a five-year deal.

The agreement gives Carlton control of ITV's advertising revenue and means it will be responsible for almost £1bn of annual advertising income.

Carlton will take over from TSMS the sale of Scottish and Grampian airtime. TSMS is the former United News & Media sales house that is being merged with Granada Sales following the £1.75m sale of United's ITV businesses to Granada Media.

The merger and loss of the SMG contract will lead to 100 job losses at the combined TV sales house, Granada confirmed yesterday.

SMG was able to renegotiate its TV sales business under office of fair trading rules laid down before the alliance between Granada and United.

In order to get the merger cleared by regulators, Granada gave an undertaking that it would free the smaller ITV franchises from their existing TSMS airtime sales contracts.

TSMS had been handling the Scottish and Grampian accounts since 1994 and the existing deal was due to run until the end of 2002.

Donald Emslie, SMG's managing director, said that the company held "thorough and extensive discussions" with both Carlton Sales and Granada Sales before awarding the sales contract to the former.

"We went with Carlton because of the deal that they offered in commercial terms and the services they could provide," he added.

He continued: "This is good news for ITV and advertisers, creating a balance in the market place between two equally strong sales houses."

SMG's total TV advertising revenues in 1999, the last full year reported, were just under £120m, with Scottish and Grampian accounting for 6.1% of ITV's net advertising revenue in that year.

Carlton Sales managing director Steve Platt said: "Adding the Scottish stations to the Carlton stable gives us a stronger sell with a wider reach. HTV and the Scottish stations together bring an other 9m people into the Carlton sell."

The cuts in the combined Granada Media airtime sales arm will be made by January, with some staff being asked to reapply for their jobs.

Granada took over ownership of TSMS on October 4. Staff from TSMS will be moved from the company's west London base in Hanger Lane to Granada's headquarters in Grays Inn Road.

Lorna Tilbian, analyst at WestLB Panmure, said she was unsurprised by yesterday's developments.

A central thrust of SMG's strategy, she said, has been to maintain its independence from Granada Media, which sits on an 18% stake of the company.

Granada Media caused a stir last year when SMG said it was interested in buying radio group Ginger Media.

Yesterday's deal makes a merger of equals of Carlton and Granada Media more likely in two years' time when legislation allowing further consolidation in ITV is passed, Ms Tilbian said.

webTitle: Pyrrhic victories of a City crackdown

fields.headline: Pyrrhic victories of a City crackdown
fields.standfirst: Watchdog should act with caution
fields.trailText: Let's not mince words here. Companies routinely use City analysts to massage expectations of their performance. The most powerful analysts within particular sectors tend to have superior access to executives because companies want favourable coverage from the investment community. Analysts want preferential treatment because it gives them an edge which they can turn into profit through their investment clients.
fields.body:
Let's not mince words here. Companies routinely use City analysts to massage expectations of their performance. The most powerful analysts within particular sectors tend to have superior access to executives because companies want favourable coverage from the investment community. Analysts want preferential treatment because it gives them an edge which they can turn into profit through their investment clients.

The same goes for newspapers. Journalists want scoops. Their "profit" is being ahead of the game - and if that means reining back on the objectivity front, well...

One daily paper routinely tells corporate financiers and the like that a sizeable exclusive story will get prominence, an accompanying background feature and a piece of "independent" analysis. The so-called Friday night drop for Sunday newspapers, meanwhile, is well documented.

The victims here are plain to see: investors who are late to receive price-sensitive information and those who are fooled by unprincipled journalism. The broad split is between City professionals who are plugged in and ordinary retail investors, who are not.

Howard Davis, chairman of the City's principal watchdog, wants to blow the whistle on all this. He has noticed the Regulation FD rule on fair disclosure introduced on Wall Street this week, where companies are explicitly banned from releasing information selectively. He wants to remind everybody that selective leaking is already illegal here, and that a crackdown is on its way.

Mr Davis and his regulatory army are in a growth industry. Incidents of media manipulation, selective City briefings and blatant insider dealing are for them a daily occurrence.

But there are costs in tackling this. Messing with the established flow of information tends to create information "shocks", such as profit warnings, which draw knee-jerk reactions in the markets and destabilise companies and their staff. There is also the danger of spending huge amounts of money trying to fix the unfixable. For City professionals the market is their job; for most retail investors the market is a hobby. The average low bet punter will never be in the same loop as someone sitting in the middle of a dealing room.

Mr Davies might remember the old central heating system analogy when it comes to information flows. The City's pipes are a bit too full of water, but so long as the pressure release valves are easily located and in good order, the system works. If you start capping these valves the leaks will simply appear in the places you least expect.

One or two might even appear in these pages.

Losec's lost lead

Lying in bed at night, AstraZeneca chief executive Tom McKillop must sometimes ponder whether life would have been easier if the company had never invented Losec - the ulcer treatment which has become the world's top selling prescription drug.

Conceived in one of Astra's Gothenburg laboratories in the early 1970s, the product ranks alongside Ikea sofas, Abba and Arsenal winger Freddie Ljungberg as one of Sweden's greatest contributions to modern civilisation.

The drug has been phenomenally successful but as it nears the end of its life, Mr McKillop has to spend much of his time tramping around the City insisting there is more to the company than curing tummy aches.

His argument appears thinner than ever after yesterday's events. A shortfall of between $200m (£138m) and $300m has emerged in American sales of Losec and, although profits will still meet forecasts, the company's market value fell £1.5bn on the news.

Any wobble from Losec causes another crack in analysts' fragile confidence in Nexium - the group's follow-up product. Nexium is at best a marginal improvement, and AstraZeneca will have a hard job persuading doctors to choose it instead of cheap, generic copies of Losec.

The most worrying aspect of yesterday's setback is that AstraZeneca seems to have been completely foxed by its competitors, who surprised the company simply by slashing the price of their rival drugs. AstraZeneca failed to anticipate such moves and has been unable to respond effectively. This does not bode well for the Anglo-Swedish firm's chances of managing the delicate introduction of Nexium in the US.

To make matters worse for Mr McKillop, the European commission is still investigating whether the company has been "abusing its dominant position", and the finest legal minds of the world are struggling to persuade judges that the company's patent protection on Losec should be extended.

Although the company has a very promising heart drug in late stage clinical trials, its immediate future looks about as steady as a flatpack blonde wood wardrobe.

webTitle: Dick Morris on the US elections

fields.headline: Laid-back Bush leaves it to TV ads
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore may be coming back. Down just a few days ago by 5-7 points in most US polls, he shows signs of surging back into contention, narrowing the Bush lead to three points or less in three national polls and tied dead even in three others.
fields.body:
Al Gore may be coming back. Down just a few days ago by 5-7 points in most US polls, he shows signs of surging back into contention, narrowing the Bush lead to three points or less in three national polls and tied dead even in three others.

Gore, relentlessly aggressive, is savaging Bush's record as Texas governor every night in television ads in all swing states while the Republican candidate runs soft ads about his commitment to better education. Capitalising on Bush's overconfidence, the Democrat is making this a close race again.

George W. Bush has a tendency to take his victory lap too early. Too soon, he amasses a lead and starts to jog around the track expecting the cheers of the crowd. Over-confidence gripped him before and during the Republican convention.

He chose Richard Cheney as his running mate during this period, when it seemed that he could choose anyone and keep his lead. Instead, Gore used his selection of the first Jewish candidate, Joe Lieberman, as his vice-president to begin to catch up and surge in front.

Now, buoyed by a good performance in the presidential debates he was supposed to lose, Bush seems to be letting up too early, switching to soft media at the time he needs to turn it up a notch to stay ahead of the surging Democrat. While Gore relentlessly pounds on Bush's shortcomings in Texas, the Republican seems to be too complacent and laid back.

Gore may well have latched on to the issue that he can use to eat up the Bush lead: Medicare. Since Bush proposes to take the money Gore would spend shoring up the system that provides health care to the elderly and use it for a tax cut, the Republican is highly vulnerable to Democratic attack on the issue.

It is axiomatic that, in a political contest, you should use your advertising to attack the opponent and let your candidate stay on the high road. During the debates Gore led the attack, slashing away at Bush. He seemed obnoxious, overbearing, and boorish.

The election now boils down to an exchange of advertisements. In the ads Gore can make the points he failed to make in the debates. So what if voters don't like the announcer who delivers the message? The candidate can keep his hands clean while the advertisement guts his opponent. Gore, who failed to win the debates, may be winning the post-debate advertising.

In the opinion of many the contest is between a candidate who isn't up to it (Bush) and a candidate who doesn't get it (Gore). In my own opinion, it is between two good men, either of whom would be a fine president. In any case, the similarity of the candidates - each trying to hug the centre - makes it a very volatile race, with the lead seeming to change hands every few weeks.

The volatility, in part, stems from a virtual consensus among American voters. The vast majority feel that Bush is the better person but they agree more with Gore on the issues. They admire Bush's character, integrity, and persona more than they do Gore's.

They report that Bush is more "likable" than Gore but tend to see Gore as the better person to address such American needs as social security reform, Medicare, gun control, education, and the environment.

With this kind of split in the minds of most voters, a lead of a few points is most unstable. For all practical purposes, this race is tied and is likely to remain so until the bitter end. This contest is shaping up as one of the closest in US history. And the most exciting.

 Dick Morris was chief strategist for Bill Clinton in his 1996 re-election campaign. He now heads www.vote.co.uk.

webTitle: Exchange presses for end to stamp duty

fields.headline: Exchange presses for end to stamp duty
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange yesterday stepped up its campaign for the abolition of stamp duty on share trading, claiming it cost ordinary people paying into pension funds more than £3 a week.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange yesterday stepped up its campaign for the abolition of stamp duty on share trading, claiming it cost ordinary people paying into pension funds more than £3 a week.

The latest shot in the exchange's campaign comes days before Gordon Brown delivers his pre-Budget statement which might be the opportunity for change.

Investors are charged 0.25% on each share purchase. Don Cruickshank, chairman and acting chief executive of the exchange, told the Securities Institute last night that stamp duty was a "major strategic problem" for the exchange as it tries to fend off a hostile £800m bid from OM of Sweden.

"We are already seeing a proliferation of avoidance measures such as spread betting. Is this really what the government wants to encourage - high risk with no benefits whatsoever to the balance sheets of UK companies?" Mr Cruickshank asked.

He estimated that the total loss of trading by 2003 would be £1 trillion, the equivalent of 70% of the total value of shares traded last year.

"The UK is the only major financial market with such a tax. Great care should be taken not to take for granted the UK equity market's ability to cope with the extra cost.

"Patience is not inexhaustible and it is essential to remember that once markets are lost they are almost impossible to recapture."

Mr Cruickshank listed stamp duty as one of five strategic issues facing the stock exchange. The others were the lack of a single market for financial services in Europe; fragmentation of the behind-the-scenes clearing and settlement services; better regulation and a lack of reciprocity between the United States and Europe over allowing access to each other's markets.

fields.headline: Owen Elias Roberts
fields.trailText: A living language needs to get new words, but six decades ago Welsh was not doing so when it came to science, medicine and technology. Owen Elias Roberts, who has died aged 92, pioneered the interpretation of science in his native tongue.
fields.body:
A living language needs to get new words, but six decades ago Welsh was not doing so when it came to science, medicine and technology. Owen Elias Roberts, who has died aged 92, pioneered the interpretation of science in his native tongue.

His first book, Hela'r Meicrob (Collecting the Micro, 1945), was an introduction to microbiology, and in 1947 came Dirgelwch yr Atom (Mysteries of the Atom). Cyfrinachau Natur (Mysteries of Nature, 1952) won the National Eisteddfod of Wales prose medal, an achievement repeated in 1954 with a volume of science essays, Y Gwr o Ystradgynlais ac Erthyglau Eraill (The Man From Ystradgynlais and other Articles).

Roberts was born at Llanysatumdwy, Gwynedd. In his teens he arrived in Liverpool and studied part time at the technical college. He rose to head Broadgreen Hospital's laboratory.

He then began to write about gifted Welsh scientists. Cwyddonwyr o Cymry (Welsh Scientists 1956) was followed in 1980 by Rhai o Wyddonwyr Cymru (Some of the Scientists of Wales). On my suggestion in 1973 he wrote a biblical commentary with the theologian Harri Williams on aspects of the Book of Genesis. In 1980 came a biography of Dr John Dee (1527-1608), who made important contributions in astronomy and navigation.

Roberts was awarded an honorary degree by the University of Wales. He retired to Criccieth and then to Cardiff to be near his daughter and family. Into his active old age he travelled with his camera to North Africa, Middle East and Europe. Postwar Welsh writing owes him a great debt. He was, as literary critic, J Saunders Lewis observed, one of the masters. He is survived by his wife and daughter and two grandchildren

fields.headline: Bob Dawbarn
fields.standfirst: Jazz trombonist and music journalist who was the original Raver
fields.trailText: Jazz trombonist and music journalist who was the original Raver
fields.body:
Until the late 1950s the London weekly Melody Maker was the bible of dance-band musicians. But by that time, while dancebands were wilting before the onslaught of rock 'n' roll, the young readership for papers about music was growing. Hence the success of Maurice Kinn's New Musical Express, which prospered on a teen-oriented show business diet.

Bob Dawbarn, who has died aged 72, was one of the journalists who, in the 1960s, changed the Melody Maker into one of the most widely read and influential rock and pop publications. It was a paper that dealt with the British new wave, while retaining a grip on jazz, folk and the music business itself.

Dawbarn joined the MM in the mid-1950s, but it was the appointment of Jack Hutton as editor in 1962 - just before the Beatles' chart breakthrough - which transformed the paper and Dawbarn's place within it. A gossip column, "The Raver", was created. Written by Dawbarn, the column allowed him the licence to be acerbic about the rock/pop scene. The title came from the Ravers cricket team, a weekend outfit which drew on the jazz scene for its members, including Dawbarn and the Flook cartoonist and clarinettist Wally Fawkes.

Dawbarn was an engineer's son, and educated at Merchant Taylors School in Northwood, Middlesex. There, a fellow pupil was Mick Mulligan, with whom Dawbarn shared that late 1940s passion for Dixieland jazz. When, at the end of the decade, Mulligan formed the Mick Mulligan Jazz Band with himself on trumpet, Dawbarn was on trombone.

Earning a living as a full-time musician in the 1950s was a precarious business. The Mulligan band - immortalised by its vocalist, George Melly, in his autobiographical Owning Up - was no exception. Thus did Dawbarn enter journalism, where he acquired a phenomenal shorthand speed - which was put to good use with a north London court reporting agency. It was on the recommendation of Jack Hutton - a fellow journalist and part-time musician - that he joined the MM.

The Raver column provided Dawbarn with a platform, and gave the Melody Maker an edge its rivals conspicuously lacked. His annual Old Dawbarn's Almanac was eagerly awaited - and dreaded - in both jazz and rock scenes. All the while, he contributed perceptive, sometimes hilarious contributions to the MM's jazz coverage. Of American blues pianist Les McCann he wrote that "Les McCann M'Can't". In 1962 a then unknown Bob Dylan turned up, unannounced, at the MM's office. Dawbarn had him ejected - it was, after all, press day.

Elegance was not his forte. When a Raver column carried an appeal for the "Buy Bob Dawbarn A New Raincoat Fund", one reader turned up at the MM office to contribute 50p.

In 1970 Dawbarn's relationship with the Melody Maker ended. He was one of an entire generation on the paper who became the core of a start-up publishing company, Banner Press, which later transmogrified into Spotlite Publications, with Hutton as managing director.

Dawbarn's versatility was illustrated by his editing of two football publications, Striker and Inside Football. His passion for the game had been ignited as a member of the Melody Maker football team, which I had started in 1964 and which boasted Ray and Dave Davies of the Kinks, Kenny Lynch, Tom Courtenay and Ian Le Frenais among its alumni.

He retired to the Lake District with wife Carol in 1971 where, as well as freelance journalism, he ran the bar at the Kendal Arts Centre before moving on to manage a local public house.

Dawbarn had been replaced in the Mulligan band in the early 50s by sometime Lancashire wicket-keeper Frank Parr. He was a terrible trombonist, Parr observed, on hearing of Dawbarn's death. But he was a wonderful human being.

Bob Dawbarn is survived by Carol. They celebrated their golden wedding in February.

fields.headline: Jennifer Dawson
fields.standfirst: Her prize-winning novel about a woman with mental illness drew on her own experiences as patient and psychiatric social worker
fields.trailText: Jennifer Dawson, who has died aged 71, was a writer whose first novel, The Ha-Ha, won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize in 1961. She continued to produce novels, short stories and a children's book, but it was The Ha-Ha which made the greatest impact. This was not a little due to its subject matter: the story of a young woman with mental illness. It drew on Dawson's experiences, as a mental patient and as a psychiatric social worker. As she told the Times in a 1985 interview: "The story was really about a girl who did not have the knack of existing, and the images in it reflected my own preoccupations."
fields.body:
Jennifer Dawson, who has died aged 71, was a writer whose first novel, The Ha-Ha, won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize in 1961. She continued to produce novels, short stories and a children's book, but it was The Ha-Ha which made the greatest impact. This was not a little due to its subject matter: the story of a young woman with mental illness. It drew on Dawson's experiences, as a mental patient and as a psychiatric social worker. As she told the Times in a 1985 interview: "The story was really about a girl who did not have the knack of existing, and the images in it reflected my own preoccupations."

The Ha-Ha had started as a love story but became a robust protest against the mental health practices of the time - when patients' complaints had to be made to a "justice in lunacy", when they were forbidden to discuss their treatment with other patients and when all letters were unsealed and available for inspection. In such an unforgiving environment Dawson offered insight into a mind which saw the world as if "though a plateglass window".

Dawson knew about all this. She spent six months in Warneford Hospital, Oxford, following a breakdown in her third year at St Anne's College, where she studied history. She completed her degree, worked for Oxford University Press and spent time as a social worker in a Worcester mental hospital. Such was her insight that the book became a standard text for social workers.

After The Ha-Ha - republished by Virago Modern Classics in 1985 and earlier dramatised in Edinburgh and London by Richard Eyre - there came Fowler's Snare (1962), winner of the Chel tenham Festival Award. There was also a collection of short stories, Hospital Wedding (1978), and The Queen of Trent, a children's adventure story about canals, co-written with her friend Elizabeth Mitchell. She continued to write to the end of her life although her last novel - prompted by the company she kept on the bus that took her to hospital - was never published.

She came from a family of Fabian socialists in that tradition of open-toed sandals and vegetarianism. Her mother was a journalist and her father worked for the Labour party-backed Workers' Travel Association. One of five children, she was educated at the Mary Datchelor School in Camberwell, a well-established grammar school. But at Oxford, that was not enough. She had, she said, few clothes and little money and was suddenly confronted with upper-class students at ease in a rarified social milieu. Her dislike of aspects of Oxford life remained. Her last published book, Judasland (1989), reflected her anger at the patriarchal nature of that society.

She had been committed to the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament from its early days and had met her husband, Michael Hinton, an Oxford philosophy don, during the 1963 Aldermaston march. She remained active in the peace movement in the Oxfordshire village of Charlbury, where she lived for the last 20 years of her life. Two days before she died, one of her sisters found her old CND badge and brought it to her in the hospice. With it pinned to her night-dress, Jennifer Dawson said, "Now, I'm properly dressed."

Her husband died in February. They had no children.

Elizabeth Mitchell writes: A friend at the Oxford University Press told me of a young woman who, having lately left the Warneford Hospital, was now an assistant in her department. I was in the kitchen when the two of them arrived for supper and I think I must have been cooking red and green peppers, then newly available here, because for me Jennifer was forever afterwards associated with these richly sensuous and vivid fruits.

She too was vivid and clear-cut, both in appearance, with her expressive dark eyes and short, shiny black hair; and in temperament, suffering disconcertingly abrupt shifts between exuberance and bleakest misery. For her, as for the young Wordsworth, the very shadow of the clouds had power to shake her as they passed. She was reading widely and writing, too (I believe she had kept a journal ever since she could write), and The Ha-Ha was in preparation.

Talk with Jennifer was both arduous and delightful. Arduous because she was often hard to satisfy - "Unhook my gills", she would beg - and delightful because, imagination being perhaps the richest of her gifts, our truth-seeking would be interspersed by wildly speculative flights ending in laughter. She liked to privatise words. "Super bus" was the word we used to denote those who were suspected of having pretensions to style or fashion and who were socially adept.

We used the word somewhat dismissively, but our own occasional forays into "their" world were sometimes successful. When happy, Jenny loved to party, but her confidence was fragile and the evening could be ruined by a word or by "the way peopled looked".

I think that, like Blake, she believed that man was made for joy and woe, though the serenity or safety he found in this belief was not to be achieved until she was near the end of her life.

webTitle: Air traffic control bidders under fire

fields.headline: Air traffic control bidders under fire
fields.standfirst:
Conflict of interest row mars £500m privatisation
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Labour's Andrew Smith is a man of few words. However one phrase that may come back to haunt the government was uttered to party conference delegates before the last election.
fields.body:
Labour's Andrew Smith is a man of few words. However one phrase that may come back to haunt the government was uttered to party conference delegates before the last election.

Mr Smith was then the party's transport spokesman and his rousing speech attacked the Tories' plan to privatise Britain's air traffic control service, NATS. To cheers, Mr Smith proclaimed that "our air was not for sale".

As a leading member of Gordon Brown's Treasury team, however, Mr Smith has been happy to see the government push through plans to sell off NATS.

The Lords, perhaps mindful of Mr Smith's earlier boasts and worried over the proposed shake-up of the railways, are in a mood to block ministers' much vaunted Transport Bill - which would end the privatisation of NATS.

What is worse is that transport officials are openly questioning whether the four bidders for NATS each posed "conflicts of interest". The Department of Transport said the prospective buyers for the £500m partial privatisation "would have to show how they would meet this concern".

The department said that it had been holding meetings with the bidders and air traffic controllers to see how the issues could be resolved.

The new privatised service is due to be set up by the middle of the year. At stake is a business which earned £568m last year from supplying air traffic services to airlines and 12 British airports. The four bidders are:

&#149 an airline group, including British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and British Midland, who say they would operate on a non-profit basis to ensure that there is no threat to safety standards. Critics point out that if these carriers own NATS they could in theory charge rivals more to use air traffic services;

 Lockheed Martin, which supplies the computer systems at Swanwick, the new air traffic control centre due to open in 2002. Computer glitches have delayed the opening for four years;

 Raytheon, a US aerospace manufacturer, with little experience of operating air traffic control in Britain. If Raytheon's bid succeeds, it will have to consider replacing the Lockheed Martin technology at Swanwick with an unspecified new system. This could set back the opening of Swanwick by several years;

 Nimbus, a consortium which includes Arinc, a big supplier of satellite technology to NATS.

One of the stated aims of the proposed legislation is to split NATS from the Civil Aviation Authority by separating responsibility for safety from the service provider. But three of the bids would hand over control of NATS to one of its main equipment providers.

Paul Noon, leader of the air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said that all the bids being considered by the government either involved foreign state-owned providers or foreign companies.

"This destroys the argument that private sector status will enable NATS to become a world leader in overseas markets. Just the reverse will happen. They will eat us for breakfast."

webTitle: CBI says investment cuts are causing long-term damage to manufacturing base

fields.headline: Industrialists see only gloom ahead
fields.standfirst: CBI says investment cuts are causing long-term damage to manufacturing base
fields.trailText: Britain's industrial base is being eroded by manufacturers scaling back their investment plans, storing up huge problems for the future, the CBI warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's industrial base is being eroded by manufacturers scaling back their investment plans, storing up huge problems for the future, the CBI warned yesterday.

Reporting the results of its latest quarterly survey, the CBI said the outlook for orders and output was less gloomy than three months ago. But confidence continued to fall as squeezed profit margins stifled investment intentions and reduced employment.

On the basis of the survey, showing investment intentions falling for the 11th quarter in a row, the CBI forecast a drop of 6% in manufacturing investment this year following last year's fall of 15%.

"This is a major cause of concern, as it will lead to a shrinking industrial base and a reduction in the long-term supply capacity of the UK manufacturing industry," said Nick Reilly, head of the CBI's economic affairs committee.

"The ability of manufacturers to meet demand without inflationary consequences will in the long run be undermined and, comments made at the economic affairs committee emphasised the damaging long-term consequences for the UK economy unless there is a healthy mix of an efficient manufacturing base alongside a growing service sector."

Mr Reilly, chief executive of Vauxhall Motors, called on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to signal that interest rates had peaked.

Had it not been for the possibility that wage inflation would rise and consumer spending fail to slow sufficiently to keep the lid on inflation, the CBI would already be calling for a reduction in borrowing costs. "There's a real possibility that the next move should be downwards."

City analysts said the survey reinforced the message from other industrial sources which suggested that the sector, although improving, was still struggling to cope with strong global competition and the strength of the pound.

The survey showed export orders continuing to fall but at a slower rate, prompting a growing number of CBI members to revise upwards their view of the pound's fair value against the German mark, Mr Reilly said.

"There's certainly more people now who would be looking at nearer three marks [to the pound] than there was a year ago. But there's nobody that has it much above three. Today's rate [around DM3.40] is way off the map."

Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser, said official figures on Tuesday showing a trade surplus with the European Union for the first time in nearly five years only told part of the story. To combat the strength of sterling against the euro, many large British firms were sourcing production outside the region, resulting in a sharp rise in non-EU imports.

Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics, said the price of staying in export markets was drastically reduced profit margins.

Noting that the survey pointed to muted price rises in industry, Mr Loynes said: "There are few signs as yet that firms expect to be able to pass on the recent oil-driven rises in raw material costs. The bottom line is that, while the recent manufacturing upturn should continue in the near term, there are clear question marks over the sustainability of the recovery further ahead if the recent strength of global demand begins to fade."

fields.headline: Patrick Porteous
fields.standfirst: He won the VC for helping to spike German guns in the Dieppe Raid
fields.trailText: During the Dieppe Raid in August 1942, Colonel Patrick "Pat" Porteous, who has died aged 82, was a captain with Lord Lovat's 4th Commando. Its crucial task was to attack a German six-gun battery located some five miles west of Dieppe near Varengeville, which could bring fire down on the main landing of the 2nd Canadian Division.
fields.body:
During the Dieppe Raid in August 1942, Colonel Patrick "Pat" Porteous, who has died aged 82, was a captain with Lord Lovat's 4th Commando. Its crucial task was to attack a German six-gun battery located some five miles west of Dieppe near Varengeville, which could bring fire down on the main landing of the 2nd Canadian Division.

Lovat landed one small detachment on a narrow beach immediately below the gun battery and the remainder on a larger beach to the west, near Quiberville. The idea was to execute a wide flanking movement and attack the battery from the rear while it was pinned down by the other detachment attacking from the front.

Porteous, acting as liaison officer between the two groups, was wounded through the hand and upper arm, but despatched his assailant with his bayonet - thus saving the life of a British sergeant the German was about to shoot. Lovat's main assault on the rear of the battery then took place, across 250 yards of open ground and through barbed wire defences around the gun pits.

Under withering machine-gun fire Porteous dashed across the open ground, rallying the men who, inspired by his example, took the battery with a bayonet assault. Although wounded again, this time in the thigh, he directed the destruction of the guns before collapsing through loss of blood. The battery had been silenced, although at great cost. Porteous's VC was announced that October.

The son of an Indian Army brigadier general, Porteous was born at Abbottabad on the North-west frontier. Educated at Wellington, where he excelled at rugby union, he entered the Royal Military Academy Woolwich and was commissioned into the Royal Artillery in 1937. He served with the British Expeditionary Force in France, was evacuated from Dunkirk and joined No 4 Commando in late 1940. Following Dieppe, he was second in command of No 4 Commando when it landed in Normandy on June 6 1944.

Porteous's post-war career included service in Palestine, attendance at the Staff College, Camberley, followed by a period as a battery commander, and a posting in Germany. One of the most enjoyable jobs he had was as an instructor and company commander at Sandhurst.

This was followed by a two-year posting to Singapore. After this he returned to regimental duties and from 1960-63 he spent a particularly happy posting as commander of the Junior Leaders' Regiment RA.

Later appointments included three years on the general staff with the Directorate of Land/Air Warfare. Colonel Porteous's final posting was as commander of the Rheindahlen Garrison of the British Army of the Rhine, after which he retired from the army in 1970.

As well as being a first class soldier, Pat Porteous was a modest and unassuming man blessed with a wry sense of humour. Devoted to his family, he loved gardening and, in his younger days, had been a keen sailor. In his retirement he gave a great deal of time and energy to supporting and raising money for the Commando Association and the Army Benevolent Fund.

From 1993 he was vice chairman (UK) of the Victoria Cross and George Cross Association. Together with fellow holders of these two supreme awards, he attended the Queen Mother's 100th birthday pageant on July 19. His death leaves 22 living holders of the VC.

His first wife died in 1953. He is survived by his second wife, whom he married in 1955, and four daughters, one from his first marriage and three from his second. His son from his first marriage died in 1998.

fields.headline: Brown rejects 'irresponsible' Budget hand-outs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown signalled yesterday that he would resist mounting political pressure for "irresponsible and unsustainable" handouts in next month's pre-Budget report to avoid wrecking the economy.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown signalled yesterday that he would resist mounting political pressure for "irresponsible and unsustainable" handouts in next month's pre-Budget report to avoid wrecking the economy.

Putting down a marker ahead of his report on Wednesday November 8, the chancellor did not rule out the widely expected concessions to hauliers, the rural lobby and pensioners.

But he said he would stick to a cautious approach to managing public finances."We will proceed with caution and prudence and resist calls for irresponsible and unsustainable pre-election handouts from whichever quarter they come," said Mr Brown.

With the Treasury's coffers awash with cash, City economists are concerned that Mr Brown may be tempted to announce big tax cuts or spending increases to woo voters in the run up to the next general election.

But Mr Brown said he was determined not to repeat the mistakes of the late 80s boom when Nigel Lawson misread a temporary improvement in the public finances for a permanent one.

Mr Lawson's tax cutting budgets left a gaping hole in the public finances when the economy turned down in the early 90s.

Speaking in Montreal ahead of the G20 finance ministers meeting, Mr Brown said he would stick to his tough fiscal rules and continue to base the government's projections for the public finances on prudent and cautious assumptions about the economy's sustainable rate of economic growth.

"Our challenge is to put in place policies, from a platform of sound public finances, that promote higher productivity that will make us stronger for the long-term and deliver rising prosperity for all," said the chancellor.

Mr Brown has forecast a budget surplus of £5bn this year but with tax receipts running ahead of schedule it is likely to be nearer £15bn, according to City forecasters.

David Walton, of Goldman Sachs, says Mr Brown has scope both to cut taxes and increase spending.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Former Japanese POWs.Tony Blair gave a very strong hint that former Japanese prisoners of war could be in line for extra compensation. The PM told MPs he had a good deal of sympathy with the campaign mounted by the Royal British Legion and pledged that "it won't be very much longer" before a decision is made.

Bad day

Conservative party website. An attempt to besiege Labour's north eastern stronghold, including the Sedgefield constituency of the prime minister, muddled eight key constituencies between the Tees and the Scottish border, as well as getting two counties wrong. An 'action section' on the Tory website designed to help volunteer canvassers moved Durham city south to Darlington which in turn ended up in the north of the county, on the fringes of Gateshead. Cleveland was renamed Tyne and Wear and county Durham was muddled with Northumbria.

Today

Commons: Education and employment questions. Debate on defence procurement. Lords: Transport bill, report.

fields.headline: Cashing in on the kids
fields.standfirst:
Sean Dodson looks at pre-pay e-commerce
Net news
fields.trailText: Sean Dodson looks at pre-pay e-commerce
fields.body:
They are the consumers who feel most comfortable with online shopping. They have lots of disposable cash, like buying computer games, books and CDs and have plenty of time to shop around. They are potentially the net's best customers. But without credit cards teenagers cannot buy goods from the internet. That is, until now.

The way for e-tailers to tap into a market which KPMG estimated as being worth £2bn a year lies in an idea culled from pre-paid mobile phones. Most UK providers will lease a mobile phone only to a credit card holder. But most playgrounds and common rooms in the UK are abuzz with teenagers text messaging each other, most using "pay as you go" vouchers bought in shops.

Last week, Y-Creds, the UK's leading player was acquired by UKsmart, for an undisclosed sum, believed to be £5.2m. The company announced that it has set up an exclusive deal with the Post Office to sell its pre-paid vouchers over the counter.

Y-Creds has been operating a teenage payment system since January. This depended on parents or guardians "uploading" money from their credit cards. With the new system, teenagers will go to the Post Office, purchase a card, scratch off a hidden pin and then enter the pin number on to the Y-Creds website.

Teenagers will have to register and, says Kevin Sefton head of e-commerce at UK Smart, each transaction will be "age verified". This will prevent a 14-year-old buying a certificate 15 movie. Sefton says the voucher scheme will be in Post Offices by Christmas. The company plans to release 300,000 Smart Creds - £6m worth of "teenage spending power". But it will have to move quickly to achieve market dominance.

Companies like BT and Hewlett Packard are all rumoured to be developing "credit cards for kids" and last month a new company Splash Plastic launched its website at www.splashplastic.com.

Splash Plastic is backed by a number of leading venture capitalists, and financed to the tune of £6m. It uses "top up" swipe cards that can be refilled at the same pay points used by the utility companies.

In the US there are already has a number of teenage payment systems such as CyberMoola and Pocket Card. But Briand Beausoleil, marketing director of Splash Plastic thinks that thanks to the culture of "pay as you go" mobile phones, the UK is an ideal market place for a pre-paid system.

"The distribution networks for paying utility bills like gas and electric are already in place," he says. "This is something that the mobile phone companies are just beginning to tap in to and we want to ride in on the crest of that wave."

Unlike Y-Creds, Splash Plastic has no barrier to entry and no need for registration. This does not mean that teenagers can then go off and download a load of porn from the net. If all goes to plan, the company will launch early next year with nearly twice as many retail points for their cards as there are National Lottery terminals.

Both companies stress that their systems are marketed at teenagers but there is no age limit to entry. And with nearly one in four of UK citizens unable to get a credit card, it might not just be teenagers opting to pay as they go on the net.

fields.headline: Weblife: Learning languages
fields.standfirst:
Do you really want to talk to the wide world? John Eason looks at sites that can teach you new tongues
Net news
fields.trailText: Do you really want to talk to the wide world? John Eason looks at sites that can teach you new tongues
fields.body:
We like to boast that we can surf the world using the web. The sad truth for a lot of us is that we can - as long as the web speaks English. But there are a lot of sites out there which can help us to broaden our linguistic horizons.

One, for example, contains a section with the delightful title - at least to English ears - De klank van de Nederlandse Klinkers. It means "the sound of Dutch vowels". I found the site two nights before a flying visit to Brussels when I thought it might be courteous to extend my knowledge of Dutch beyond "two beers please" ("tweetal bier wees zo goed").

The Nederlandse Klinkers appear on Chris Sonnemans's splendid www.learndutch.org. This site shows where the web can score over a book. You can click on words to hear what they sound like and learn the language of Rembrandt, Spinoza and Vermeer (and don't forget Hans Brinker, the little boy who stuffed his finger in the dyke) by following the adventures of the folk in the Crossroads cafe (no relation to the ancient TV soap).

If you are going abroad and want to learn a few phrases in a hurry, the Travlang site is indispensable. It covers 74 languages from Afrikaans to Zulu giving you basic phrases for shopping, eating, travelling and telling the time and date - and lets you hear how they sound. It also provides a huge range of online dictionaries and pointers to other language websites.

Should you be bound for Russia, it might be useful to find out what some of those street signs mean. Alexei Ivanov offers a colourful collection of 144 signs at http://russian.about.com/homework/russian/library/blsigns. htm with translations.

For a more in-depth view of the Russian language, with guidance on how to download Cyrillic fonts, try www.lidenz.ru/links.html which has a series of links to online Russian courses. Check out the delightful online picture dictionary at www.visi.com/~swithee/dictionary/welcome.html. Click on the picture of a sheep to hear the word.

More useful might be the correct pronunication for beer, wine and vodka. Winter sunseekers can find out how rusty their Spanish is before heading to the Costa del Sol at www.geocities.com/Athens/Thebes/6177/spantest/spantest_intro.htm.

This test devised by the University of Birmingham can take 20-40 minutes to complete. A running score is kept so you can duck out at any point if you feel that your score is becoming embarrassingly low. Click to the WebSpanol home page at www.geocities.com/Athens/Thebes/6177 to brush up your Spanish and find out which Beatles song begins: Cierra los ojos y te besaré.

For many, German without tears is unimaginable. But why not lighten those hours of ploughing through strong and weak verbs with a little light literature? At http://german.about.com/homework/german/library/weekly/aa071000a.htm you can find out how reading Harry Potter Und Der Stein Der Weisen (Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone) can improve your German. Chinese is a baffling language for Westerners, particularly because saying a word in a different tone can totally change its meaning. But you can learn Chinese online and master those tones at www.csulb.edu/xtxie/online.htm.

One wonderful resource here is the use of animated pictures showing you exactly how to draw the beautiful Chinese ideograms - particularly useful if you want to send a friend a card for the Year of the Snake which starts on January 24 next year or write to ask Jackie Chan for his autograph.

Even on holidays there are moments when we need to express our darker selves. Should you be stressed in Stockholm then a course in Swedish cursing at www.santesson.com/curshome.htm could be just the thing.

The more even-tempered might prefer the Swedish course at www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~arubin/swedish.html. Many opportunities to improve your French can be found at Bucknell University's French site including the words to numerous French songs. Unfortunately Bucknell offers no help with the songs of Renaud who uses slang extensively - his Mon Beauf, a hymn of hate to his brother-in-law completely blew away the otherwise excellent InterTran online translator . To freshen your French slang, try the running discussion (in French) at www.argots.com.

The best thing about the web is the number of free language courses out there. I have covered only a few. My advice is to type into a search engine like Google: "learn (your choice of language) online" and see what comes up. You might want to talk Turkey, study Swahili, learn Latvian or furnish yourself with Finnish. Just get out there and klank those klinkers.
